title: 2016 Cadillac CT6: Designer Walkaround
subTitle: Exterior design manager Taki Karras showed me around the new Cadillac flagship.
promoTeaserSmall: Exterior design manager Taki Karras showed me around the new Cadillac flagship.
promoTeaser: Exterior design manager Taki Karras showed me around the new Cadillac flagship.
metaKeywords: Cadillac at New York Auto Show
metaDescription: Exterior design manager Taki Karras showed me around the new Cadillac flagship.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Cadillac’s exterior design manager, Taki Karras,  met me at the New York Auto Show to walk me around the 2016 CT6, on my short list of must-see cars.

First, Taki’s name is Greek. I don’t know what it means, but I do know how to pronounce it. Not like a Greek taco. Not like the Easter Island torches. It’s ‘Tikey” like “Mikey.” He looks too young to have been at General Motors for fifteen years, but he’s had quite an auspicious career there, after graduating from DAAP, the prestigious college of Design, Architecture, Art and Planning at the University of Cincinnati.

The GM years have included stints as lead exterior designer at Pontiac, the Small Midsize Studio, California Advanced Studio, and at Cadillac before being elevated to Cadillac’s exterior design manager.

He is uniquely qualified to guide us on a walking tour of the car first hinted at in a sultry ad during the Oscars. We’ve been wanting to see more ever since.
Here it is.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/IqR4eOkIt4g" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
The 2016 Cadillac CT6 was introduced at the New York Auto Show earlier this month. See our show coverage of the CT6 here.

title: 2015 Chevrolet City Express
subTitle: An efficient small work van.
promoTeaserSmall: An efficient small work van.
promoTeaser: An efficient small work van.
metaKeywords: 2015 Chevrolet City Express; Chevrolet; Chevy; van; work van; American
metaDescription: An efficient small work van. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Front-wheel-drive compact work van
Price range: $22,950–$24,510
Trim levels: LS, LT
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 131 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/26 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Rear park assist (LT)
Notable standard features on this model: Theft deterrent system
Notable options on this model: Appearance package (adds body-color bumpers, chrome grille)
You might also be considering: Ford Transit Connect

If bringing tools to the job or delivering your product to customers is part of your work day, the vehicle you do it in is essential to your productivity and profit. This nimble little truck gets great gas mileage—24 mpg in the city, where you will likely be doing most of your work. It is designed to be easy to fit the things you are likely to want it to carry: pallets, doors, a six-foot stepladder, and the like. And the rear doors open wide—with a 60/40 split—to make whatever you haul around easily accessible. The back is tricked out with connection rings and mounts to make retrofitting it for shelving systems, racks, or other organization or storage systems easy. Shelving and storage accessories can also be purchased from Chevrolet. The cargo volume is an impressive 122.7 cubic feet.

The passenger area is basic, but it has what you need to get the job done. A twelve-volt outlet lets you keep your laptop running all day long. Thirteen storage spaces and a front passenger's seat that folds flat to make something like a desk turns that driving area into a small office on the move. There are plenty of options for making the exterior look just the way you want as well, so this van can represent and advertise your business as you work.

New for 2015

The City Express is an all-new vehicle for 2015.

title: 2015 Chevrolet Spark
subTitle: This subcompact is cartoon tiny and comes in vivid, cartoon colors.
promoTeaserSmall: This subcompact is cartoon tiny and comes in vivid, cartoon colors.
promoTeaser: This subcompact is cartoon tiny and comes in vivid, cartoon colors.
metaKeywords: 2015 Chevrolet Spark; Chevrolet; Chevy; hatchback; American
metaDescription: This subcompact is cartoon tiny and comes in vivid, cartoon colors. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-passenger, front-wheel-drive subcompact hatchback
Price range: $12,270–$26,820
Trim levels: LS, LT, Spark EV
Engine: 1.2-liter four-cylinder, 84 horsepower; 105-kW electric motor, 140 horsepower, lithium-ion battery, 18.4 kWh (Spark EV)
Transmissions: Five-speed manual or continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: Manual: 31 mpg city/39 mpg highway; continuously variable: 30/39 mpg; EV: 128/109 mpg-e
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: 4G LTE with Wi-Fi hot spot for three months/3GB of data
Notable standard features on this model: Heated leatherette front seats (2LT)
Notable options on this model: Seven-inch infotainment touchscreen
You might also be considering: Fiat 500, Ford Fiesta, Mazda 2

This car is just adorable. If you grew up—or wish you did—on Pixar movies, you will find it irresistible. And if you indulge your cartoon-color vision of the world and make this your ride, you will not be disappointed by its perky demeanor, parking agility, and high-tech options.

The Spark may be budget priced, but there are numerous optional modern amenities. Connect your phone via Bluetooth and access apps on the touchscreen display. Listen to Pandora, use BringGo for navigation, let Siri Eyes Free handle calls, searches, contacts, and everything else that might tempt you to look at your phone. An auxiliary power outlet in the center stack keeps your devices running. Passengers (or you, when parked) can use the car as a Wi-Fi hot spot thanks to OnStar with 4G LTE, which is capable of connecting up to seven devices. That hot spot is more reliable than your phone, too, because the antenna is built right into the car.

The Spark might seem vulnerable out there on the road, but it packs a lot of protection into a small space. In fact, it was named a 2014 Top Safety Pick by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. And, if something does go wrong, a rollover sensing system and safety cage made from high-strength steel, 10 standard air bags—including knee- and seat-mounted front air bags—will protect you while the OnStar automatic crash response system alerts first responders.

New for 2015

A 4G LTE connectivity with Wi-Fi hot spot; two new colors on the Spark EV.

More about the Chevrolet Spark

2016 Chevrolet Spark April 3, 2015

title: 2015 Chevrolet Suburban
subTitle: A supersize classic.
promoTeaserSmall: A supersize classic.
promoTeaser: A supersize classic.
metaKeywords: 2015 Chevrolet Suburban; Chevrolet; Chevy; SUV; sport-utility; American
metaDescription: 2015 Chevrolet Suburban: A supersize classic. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-to-nine-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive large sport-utility vehicle
Price range: $50,195–$64,980
Trim levels: LS, LT, LTZ
Engine: 5.3-liter V-8, 355 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: RWD: 16 mpg city/23 mpg highway; AWD: 15/22 mpg
Safety Ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Remote vehicle start
Notable standard features on this model: Forward collision alert, lane departure warning, safety alert seat with haptic feedback (LT)
Notable options on this model: Adaptive cruise control (LTZ)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Tahoe, Ford Expedition EL, GMC Yukon, Toyota Land Cruiser

If you often carry a full load of people and cargo, the Suburban might be the sport-utility vehicle for you. Power release second-row seats, power folding third-row seats, 121 cubic feet of cargo space, and seating for up to nine people? Capacity problem solved. But the Suburban has its own brand of style and offers plenty of creature comforts for discerning adults. The ride is smooth, for one thing. The Suburban LTZ has Magnetic Ride Control, a damping technology that reads the road 1,000 times a second and adjusts the damping in just ten to fifteen milliseconds. Choose from a suite of driver assist technologies that use cameras and radar sensors to warn you of risks on the road. Opt for the rear-seat Blu-ray entertainment system, to hush the brood while you navigate the terrain. Connect your phone and stream your own Pandora channel. And the interior is loaded with ingenious places to stow everyone’s gear including a clever password-protected bin behind the touchscreen, for phone (there’s a charger), wallet, sunglasses, or other valuables.

New for 2015

The Suburban is all-new for 2015.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/TbYwmhRbX5A" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Like so many talented women in automotive design around the world, Helen Emsley has lived for years in the relative obscurity of the color and trim studio. Eleven of her twenty-plus years were spent at GM’s Opel division before being sent to the U.S. as GM’s first-ever global director of color and trim, elevating both her status and the importance to GM of cohesive interior design among all its brands.

Real fame came when GM design boss Ed Welburn anointed Emsley (to her shock) to lead the interior design of the Corvette. The result was simply the most beautiful, rational, and comfortable Corvette cabin in recent history. Emsley was also made design director of full-size truck interiors, and she likes to point out that the Corvette was GM’s most iconic brand, and the large trucks its most lucrative. “I told Ed he’d better sell his stock,” she laughs.

Instead, Welburn made her global director of GMC design and user experience in 2013. Emsley approached our first meeting (and my attendant videographer) with a down-to-earth manner and self-deprecating humor that is apparent during our walkaround of the updated GMC Terrain mid-size crossover. Although the changes are modest for 2016, Emsley’s presence has made GMC a brand worth watching.

More to Read:

Fast Women: An Interview with Helen Emsley

title: 2015 Dodge Dart
subTitle: Edging ever closer.
promoTeaserSmall: Edging ever closer.
promoTeaser: Edging ever closer.
metaDescription: Edging ever closer. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan
Price range: $17,490–$24,590 (includes destination)
Trim levels: SE, SXT, Aero, Limited, GT
Engines: Turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder, 160 horsepower; 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 160 horsepower; 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 184 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual, six-speed automatic, six-speed dual-clutch automatic
Fuel economy: 1.4-liter, manual: 28 mpg city/41 mpg highway; 1.4-liter, automatic 28/40 mp g; 2.0-liter, manual: 25/36 mpg; 2.0-liter, automatic: 24/34 mpg; 2.4-liter, manual: 22-23/33–35 mpg; 2.4-liter, automatic: 22-23/31/35 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Remote trunk release
Notable standard features on this model: Hill start assist, electronic roll mitigation, four-speaker audio system, USB port
Notable options on this model: 8.4-inch infotainment touchscreen, nine-speaker audio system, heated front seats and side mirrors, Bluetooth connectivity, multifunction steering wheel
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Cruze, Honda Civic, Kia Forte

The knock against the Dart had been its lack of powertrain refinement, but strategic improvements were made last year to address the issue. The Dart SXT, Limited, and GT are powered by a sophisticated 2.4-liter four-cylinder that makes 184 horsepower and better positions the models against competitors. For 2015, there are optional modifications to the fuel supply system to gain Partial Zero Emission Vehicle status for Darts in the fourteen California Air Resources Board states. The Dart Aero has a turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder that can be matched with a six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission, taking advantage of the strong output of 160 horsepower and—best of the Dart bunch—184 pound-feet of torque. The Aero has active grille shutters and special underbody cladding to improve aerodynamic efficiency. (The active shutters are also standard on the GT and Limited and optional on SE and SXT.) A special badge and LED “racetrack” taillamps help distinguish the Aero. Inside, the Aero gets an 8.4-inch touchscreen display, a sharp-looking and customizable TFT instrument panel, and essential iPod and USB ports. The Dart GT is equipped for sporty performance with darkened features, dual exhausts, and eighteen-inch alloy wheels. Inside, you’ll find a heated steering wheel and front seats and perforated Nappa leather upholstery.

New for 2015

The 2.4-liter four-cylinder qualifies Dart as a Partial Zero Emission Vehicle; touchscreen infotainment is updated for Android compatibility; Dart SE Convenience Group package is offered at a discount; new standard sixteen-inch alloy wheels on the SXT.

title: 2015 Dodge Durango
subTitle: Paying attention to details.
promoTeaserSmall: Paying attention to details.
promoTeaser: Paying attention to details.
metaDescription: Paying attention to details. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Price range: $31,490–$41,990 (includes destination)
Trim levels: SXT, Limited, R/T, Citadel
Engines: 3.6-liter V-6, 290/295 horsepower; 5.7-liter V-8, 360 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 3.6-liter, RWD: 18 mpg city/25 mpg highway; 3.6-liter, AWD: 17/24 mpg; 5.7-liter, RWD: 14/23 mpg; 5.7-liter, AWD: 14/22 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in four categories, Poor in Small Overlap Front test; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Media hub
Notable standard features on this model: TFT instrument display, Bluetooth connectivity, 5.0-inch touchscreen, six speakers, rotary electronic shifter, paddle shifters, fold-flat front-passenger seat, 60/40 fold-and-tumble second row, three-zone automatic climate control
Notable options on this model: 8.4-inch infotainment touchscreen, twenty-inch wheels, power liftgate
You might also be considering: BMW X5, Mercedes-Benz ML-Class

We find the Dodge Durango’s look to be irresistible. Whenever we see one, we can’t take our eyes off its assertive face, muscular flanks, and “racetrack” LED taillamps. Like the Dodge Charger in the sedan category, the Durango approximates the capability of more expensive SUV competitors from Europe while undercutting their prices. The Durango has a high level of specification to satisfy just about any need. It comes on 4x2 or 4x4 architecture, seats seven, and tows up to 7,400 pounds while available sway control keeps the trailer in line. The available 5.7-liter V-8 produces 360 horsepower and an impressive 390 pound-feet of torque, yet because of cylinder deactivation it can operate as a V-4 engine under light loads for greater efficiency. There’s a long list of standard and optional safety, security, and convenience features. Splendid appointments and luxuries abound, as well. A seven-inch TFT instrument panel display is standard in all models. New this year, the available Beats by Dre audio system delivers premium sound via a twelve-channel amplifier and ten speakers. Playing opposing roles in the cast, the R/T is aggressive and a little hyper while the Citadel is all polished and glimmering.

New for 2015

Premium audio system; Rallye appearance package available on SXT and Limited; Blacktop package available on SXT, Limited, and R/T.

title: A 1.5-Gallon Car Wash?
subTitle: Is it possible? An invention called Gleamfire lets you wash without wasting, right in the driveway.
promoTeaserSmall: Is it possible? An invention called Gleamfire lets you wash without wasting, right in the driveway.
promoTeaser: Is it possible? An invention called Gleamfire lets you wash without wasting, right in the driveway.
metaDescription: Is it possible? An invention called Gleamfire lets you wash without wasting, right in the driveway.

pageElements.text: It’s a rite of spring, going out and washing your car in the driveway. In that respect, Michigan is lucky: we have a seemingly inexhaustible supply of fresh water, what with the Great Lakes and all. Still, we don’t want to waste it. Our friends in California, of course, are not able to waste water anymore, not unless they want to pay a $500 fine for washing their cars in the driveway.

So, about that home car washing thing. Even if you are in a place with an endless water supply, it’s just not very Earth-friendly to run soapy water down the street and into the storm drain. You’ll also use up to 100 gallons of water to wash your car using a hose. A car wash uses a lot less, but what about when you don’t want to spend the money or time driving to one?
Gleamfire is to hand washing what the dishwasher is to dishes in the sink: it’s a way to get the fun of driveway car washing without the water and soap management issues.

That’s the idea behind a project being promoted on Indiegogo that caught our eye. The Gleamfire Car Washing System is a large, vertical Super Soaker like device, but it is to hand washing what the dishwasher is to washing dishes in the sink: it’s a way to get the fun of driveway car washing without the water and soap management issues.

The Gleamfire gadget was the invention of a guy who owns a fish tank, and who lives in New England, where driveway car washing is barely a three-season thing. Using the filtration system he knew from aquariums, he invented this gadget so he could wash his car inside the garage in the winter.

It’s basically a cylinder with a filter, into which you insert a specially sized microfiber wash mitt. You pump the cylinder to work up a lather from a small amount of soap inside. Filters keep the mitt from getting gritty, which seems to be the secret sauce in this invention. The foam filters inside need to be replaced once a year, they say. The water is contained, and so is the soap. If you use a no-rinse soap product, you don't even need to get out the hose to rinse the car off afterward. How much nicer that is than repeatedly sticking your hands into a bucket of cold, increasingly gritty water.
Gleamfire's system uses only 1.5 gallons of water to work, which is the real secret sauce.
We couldn't get one yet, as they're still in the prototype stage, but we'll be trying it out as soon as we can.

The Indiegogo campaign lasts till late May and, so far, is only 1 percent funded, but they're only a few days in. The finished product is promised in 2016. As resources become more scarce and people have to get cleverer in how we use them, this is the kind of invention that people will increasingly turn to.

images.caption: Indiegogo project: Gleamfire car wash system.
The mitt doesn't keep the grit, Gleamfire makers claim.
Gleamfire gadget stands on its own.
Gleamfire filter needs replacing every 12 months.

title: 2015 Bentley Continental
subTitle: A handcrafted performance grand tourer.
promoTeaserSmall: A handcrafted performance grand tourer.
promoTeaser: A handcrafted performance grand tourer.
metaKeywords: 2015 Bentley Continental; Bentley; British; coupe; convertible
metaDescription: A handcrafted performance grand tourer. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-passenger, two-door all-wheel-drive coupe or convertible
Price range: $193,500–$339,725
Trim levels: GT V8, GT V8 S, GT W12, GT Speed, GT3-R
Engines: Twin-turbocharged 4.0-liter V-8, 500/521 horsepower; 4.0-liter V-8, 572 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 6.0-liter W-12, 582/626 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 4.0-liter: 13 mpg city/20 mpg highway; 4.0-liter turbo: 15/24 mpg; 6.0-liter: 12/21 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: All-wheel drive
Notable standard features: Wi-Fi, hidden lockable compartment to store electronics while charging
Notable options on this model: Red analog clock
You might also be considering: Aston Martin DB9, Audi R8, Maserati Quattroporte, Rolls-Royce Wraith

Old and new converge on the 2015 Bentley Continental GT. This luxury performance coupe has reinvigorated the stalwart brand, which is being embraced by a younger, hipper audience than Bentley normally courts. Setting the standard for luxury is bespoke, or custom, everything in the coupe. The buyer is presented with a seemingly infinite ways to outfit the Continental's interior and exterior: “hides” in fifteen different colors, seven real wood veneers, metal interior trims, and 120 exterior paint colors. And that’s just the standard set of choices. Everything you see and touch oozes money, including the Breitling-designed instrument panel and clock, the lamb's-wool floor mats, and the diamond-patterned quilted seats. But it’s not just about looking cool; the Continental is the quintessential grand tourer, meant to be driven on long stretches for long distances. There are five engine options, including a 626-horsepower W12 which, in a nod to the EPA, now shuts down six of its cylinders when they're not needed to improve fuel economy. All are paired to an eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. There may be cars that are sportier and better suited for the track, but they’re not as handcrafted as the GT.

New for 2015

Revised exterior, new 21-inch wheel option, new exterior color options, and the racing-car-based GT3-R model.

More about the Bentley Continental

2013 Bentley Continental GTC V8 July 29, 2013, video

title: 2015 Cadillac CTS
subTitle: Tech-minded luxury mid-size car.
promoTeaserSmall: Tech-minded luxury mid-size car.
promoTeaser: Tech-minded luxury mid-size car.
metaDescription: Tech-minded luxury mid-size car.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive luxury sedan
Price range: $46,340–$79,125 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Standard, Luxury, Performance, Premium, Vsport, Vsport premium
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 272 horsepower; 3.6-liter V-6, 321 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 3.6-liter V-6, 420 horsepower
Transmissions: Six- or eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.0-liter, RWD: 20 mpg city/30 mpg highway; 2.0-liter, AWD: 19/28 mpg; 3.6-liter, RWD: 18/29 mpg; 3.6-liter, AWD: 18/26 mpg; 3.6-liter twin-turbo: 16/24 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Tranffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Wireless phone charging
Notable standard features on this model: Cue media control system, remote start, rear park assist, OnStar with 4G LTE
Notable options on this model: Cue with navigation system, heated and ventilated front seats, head-up display, tri-zone climate control
You might also be considering: Audi A6, BMW 5 Series, Mercedes-Benz E-Class

As the centerpiece of the Cadillac brand, the mid-size 2015 CTS straddles the market between performance car and luxury sedan. It’s comes standard with a very capable 272-horsepower 2.0-liter turbo four-cylinder engine linked to a six-speed automatic transmission, but many buyers will prefer the power of the V-6s—a normally aspirated 3.6-liter and a 3.6-liter twin-turbo—mated to an eight-speed automatic transmission. The CTS offers a lot of standard technology for the money: Cadillac's Cue infotainment system (navigation optional), remote start, 4G LTE hot spots, and wireless device charging. Upgrades include heated and ventilated seats, leather everything, crash avoidance systems, and parking assist. When you pair OnStar with the head-up display, you will never get lost again. What truly sets the CTS apart from its competitors on the market is its styling. Its exterior sculpting is somewhat masculine, but it’s also subdued enough to appeal to those looking for a distinctive luxury vehicle that stands out from the crowd (read: doesn’t want to be a BMW, Audi, or Mercedes). Despite this muscular appearance, the 2015 CTS is the lightest car in its class, which means it drives like a sports car but still delivers on luxury and technology.

New for 2015

Wireless phone charger, perpendicular parking assist added to the parking assist system, new interior color and trim combinations, two new exterior paint colors, and OnStar with 4G LTE and built-in Wi-Fi hot spot (3GB/three-month trial).

More about the Cadillac CTS

2016 Cadillac CTS-V January 14, 2015

title: 4 Reasons to Keep Using Real Maps
subTitle: The folding map still has an important place in your driving life, the same way CDs haven't replaced vinyl records.
promoTitle: 4 Reasons to Keep Using Real Maps
promoTeaserSmall: The folding map still has a place in your driving life, just as CDs haven't replaced vinyl.
promoTeaser: The folding map still has a place in your driving life, just as CDs haven't replaced vinyl.
keywords: 4 Reasons to Keep Using Real Maps
metaTitle: 4 Reasons to Keep Using Real Maps
metaDescription: The folding map still has a place in your driving life, just as CDs haven't replaced vinyl.

pageElements.text: GPS and in-car navigation systems just may be the greatest thing added to cars since power steering. With them, your car can turn you into a dot on a moving map and smoothly direct you to any destination. No more wandering around, getting lost and squinting at dimly lit road signs; no more stopping at a gas station to ask directions. With an in-car navigation system, you are centered, directed, taken care of. Really, we are big fans of electronic map technology.
So why aren’t we suggesting you ask your GPS for directions to the nearest recycling center to throw away all your maps and atlases?

Because maps can still have a very important place in your driving life, if you’ll let them. You don’t have to give them up, since they are a packable, foldable supplement to whatever electronic mapping you have on board.
Here are our top four reasons to keep maps in your home, in your car, and in your trip-planning arsenal.
It’s tempting to beetle along, letting the GPS tell you what highway exit to take, but especially on a longer road trip, you’ll miss the larger sense of where you are.

1. No screen can replace maps’ ability to show the big picture. One of the frustrating things about a touchscreen navigation system is that you can’t easily zoom out and see, for example, the whole state of Maine or the whole Southwest, at least not while you’re driving. It’s tempting to beetle along, letting the GPS tell you what highway exit to take, but especially on a longer road trip, you’ll be missing a larger sense of where you are. This is even more important when you’re in the planning stages for a drive of more than a couple hundred miles. Open up a real paper map or atlas. At least look at a big-picture view online. But don’t overlook the satisfaction of marking out a route on a folding paper map with a highlighter; it never gets old.

2. Maps let you discover the unexpected detour and the interesting side road. Jack Kerouac didn’t have GPS. William Least Heat-Moon didn’t have a nav system. You may not have an itch to wander the blue highways and dives of the countryside the way they did, but when you’re traveling, you’re missing out if you ignore all possible paths to adventure. A paper map or road atlas makes these easier to spot because you aren’t laser focused on the quickest route to your destination. You know how the saying goes: not all who wander are lost.

3. Maps make you and your carmates work as a collaborative team. Remember the good old days of your parents fighting over which highway exit to take, while one angrily gripped the steering wheel and the other wrestled with a map? Well, you have GPS and a smartphone now, so you can enjoy navigating without all that stress. It can actually be fun now to let your passenger navigate with a map, since the outcome of the trip doesn’t absolutely depend on his or her map-reading prowess.

If your passengers are children, it can be incredibly educational to put them in charge of reading maps, and looking at the map to track your progress will keep them invested in the adventure of the trip (and they’ll spend less time asking, “Are we there yet?"). Often, maps have information that’s fun to read: things like the state bird, locations of museums and landmarks, and trivia about the region. Bonus: You can teach your kids how to fold a map correctly. Hours of fun!

4. Maps can be a memento of a great drive. You can’t frame your Google Maps link or your nav screen as a souvenir, but if you’ve taken a particularly memorable vacation trip, you can keep the physical evidence in the form of a map with your route marked on it. Someday people will come back to maps as a desirable alternative to screens, the way music lovers are coming back to vinyl records as a desirable alternative to CDs. There’s something so real about them.

More from Us on Road Trips

Our Favorite Road Trip Memories

18 Reasons to Road Trip with a Teen

A Teenager's First Road Trip

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Type: All-wheel-drive full-size luxury sedan
Base price: $82,125 (including destination charge)
This car: $91,495 (including destination charge)
Engine: Supercharged 3.0-liter V-6, 340 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic with shift paddles
Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/24 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated and cooled front and rear seats
Notable standard features on this model: Blind spot monitor, rearview camera, electronic traction control, burl walnut veneer, navigation with eight-inch touchscreen
Notable options on this model: Electric rear sun blind ($670); Illumination package ($1,700); Orona wheels ($3,500)
You might also be considering: 2015 Audi A8 L ($82,325); 2015 BMW 740Li ($78,950); 2015 Mercedes-Benz S550 4Matic ($95,325) (all prices include destination charges)
The L means it's long-wheelbase, which means it's the limo-est of limos, and yet it only weighs 4,100 pounds.

Key Points:

• The car you see here is the midrange XJ in the long-wheelbase version. The base 2015 Jaguar XJ starts at $75,125.
• The top-of-the-line 2015 Jaguar XJR Long Wheelbase starts at $119,925. (Prices include destination.)
• Jaguar has been going aluminum in its lineup to achieve lower weight and better fuel economy. The XJL AWD seen here comes in at a curb weight of just 4,151 pounds. That's 313 pounds lighter than the Audi A8L, 374 pounds lighter than the BMW 740Li, and 622 pounds lighter than the Mercedes S550 4Matic.
• Jaguar dieting reaches its pinnacle with the redesigned 2016 XF, which made its debut at the 2015 New York Auto Show earlier this month.
• With that redesign, the entire Jag lineup now features aluminum-intensive construction.
• All XJ engines feature Intelligent Stop-Start for improved fuel economy, but with gas prices as low as they’ve been, it’s hard to imagine that buyers in this category would be worried about pump prices.
• The Jaguar XJ with the 5.0-liter V-8 is fairly thirsty at 15 mpg city/23 mpg highway.
• Still, a sleek Jaguar says a lot about your image–and this car’s design is even considered daring in some circles.
• The long-wheelbase models provide five inches more rear-seat legroom than the standard model.
• Standard amenities on this model include fourteen-way power front seats, four-zone automatic climate control, heated and cooled front and rear seats, and more leather in the cabin.
• And the ride is like a magic carpet.

title: 2015 GMC Sierra HD
subTitle: A tough truck with a plush interior.
promoTeaserSmall: A tough truck with a plush interior.
promoTeaser: A tough truck with a plush interior.
metaKeywords: 2015 GMC Sierra HD; GMC; Sierra 2500HD; Sierra 3500HD; pickup; truck; American
metaDescription: A tough truck with a plush interior. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Rear- or all-wheel-drive heavy-duty pickup truck
Price range: $32,846–$49,135 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Sierra, SLE, SLT
Engine: 6.0-liter V-8, 322/360 horsepower; turbo-diesel 6.6-liter V-8, 397 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: N/A
Safety ratings: N/A
Our favorite standard feature: OnStar with 4G LTE and Wi-Fi (SLE, SLT)
Notable standard features on this model: Cruise control
Notable options on this model: Front- and rear park assist (SLT)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Silverado HD, Ford F-250 Super Duty, Ram HD

The outside of this heavy-duty truck is strong. Nearly two-thirds of the cab structure is made from high-strength steel and the frame is loaded with structural reinforcements to stiffen the body. Step inside though, and the interior is the antitheses of the truck’s tough exterior. The cabin is cushy, quiet, and inviting—from the soft-touch instrument panel to the center console that’s big enough to hold your laptop to the USB ports and 12-volt charging outlets to the inlaid door and dual-density seat foam seats.

But even the high-strength steel, fully boxed frame exterior has a few nurturing touches for its human: Integrated rear-bumper corner steps make it easy to climb into the truck bed. Four tie-downs in the bed help manage cargo easily. Available cargo-box LED lighting in the truck helps you see what’s in there so you don’t have to run for a flashlight. And an easy lift tailgate makes getting in and out frictionless and gentle on your bones.

The whole truck turns into a Wi-Fi hot spot, too, with the built-in 4G LTE connection. And since its antenna is built into the big frame of this truck, it gets a better signal than a smart phone. It will connect up to seven devices. So no more working late in the office because you spent a long day off the grid.

New for 2015

Redesigned exterior and interior, revised cab styles with larger rear doors, and new seat designs, OnStar with 4G LTE and standard built-in Wi-Fi hot spot (includes 3GB/three-month data trial).

title: 2015 Honda Accord
subTitle: A classic in the competitive mid-size car category.
promoTeaserSmall: A classic in the competitive mid-size car category.
promoTeaser: A classic in the competitive mid-size car category.
metaKeywords: 2015 Honda Accord; Honda; sedan; coupe; hybrid; Japanese
metaDescription: A classic in the competitive mid-size car category. - JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan or coupe
Price range: $22,925–$35,875 (includes destination)
Trim levels: LX, LX-S, Sport, EX, EX-L, EX-L V6, Touring
Engines: 2.0-liter four-cylinder/electric hybrid, 141 horsepower; 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 185/189 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6, 278 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual; six-speed automatic; continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 2.4-liter, manual: 24 mpg city/34 mpg highway; 2.4-liter, CVT: 26–27/35 mpg; 3.6-liter, manual: 18/28 mpg; 3.6-liter, automatic: 21/32–34 mpg; Hybrid: 50/45 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Transportation Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Bluetooth phone and streaming audio
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera with on-screen guides
Notable options on this model: Adaptive cruise control
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Hyundai Sonata, Nissan Altima, Toyota Camry

The Accord pretty nearly defines what it is to be a mid-size car. Available as a sedan or coupe, in regular or hybrid models, there's an Accord for just about anyone, and all are affordable and loaded with popular features. The Accord sedan has been a bestseller, especially with buyers under thirty-five years old, for over a decade. And while the Toyota Prius may be the Kleenex of green cars—the brand name that’s synonymous with the product category—Honda’s newer Accord Hybrid is no slouch either. It offers the highest EPA city fuel economy rating of any four-door sedan sold in America. State-of-the-art adaptive cruise control? Yep. Lane-departure warnings? Forward collision warning. Uh huh. Bluetooth connectivity? Check. Rearview camera? Touchscreen display? You get the idea. It’s got it. And with so many models and trim levels, choosing which Accord to get might be as complicated as narrowing down the entire marketplace of mid-size cars.

New for 2015

HomeLink universal remote on EX-L models; Honda's LaneWatch is now standard on EX Coupes; EX and EX-L now have auto-dimming rearview mirrors.

More on the Honda Accord

Video Review: 2014 Honda Accord Coupe

title: 2015 Honda CR-V
subTitle: Hugely popular compact SUV gets updated.
promoTeaserSmall: Hugely popular compact SUV gets updated.
promoTeaser: Hugely popular compact SUV gets updated.
metaKeywords: 2015 Honda CR-V Car Guide; Honda; SUV; crossover; Japanese
metaDescription: Hugely popular compact SUV gets updated. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Price range: $24,325–$33,775 (includes destination)
Trim levels: LX, EX, EX-L, Touring
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 185 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: FWD: 27 mpg city/34 mpg highway; AWD: 26/33 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Text message delivery
Notable standard features on this model: Heated front seats on EX and above
Notable options on this model: Honda LaneWatch on EX and above
You might also be considering: Hyundai Tucson, Nissan Rogue, Toyota RAV4

To call the CR-V a sales success is an understatement; it's at the pinnacle of Honda sales along with the Accord. And the 2015 model received some big improvements. It already laid claim to that Honda safety and efficiency. But now it’s got an even more powerful and efficient engine and a suite of active and passive safety features: blind spot monitoring, forward collision alert, lane departure warning system, and an excellent LaneWatch rearview camera.

Depending on model, you can also get leather trim on seats, steering wheel, and shift knob, plus heated front seats, a power tilting moonroof, and a power tailgate. But storage and seating is the real reason you want an SUV, and this one seats five and offers plenty of cargo space and clever places to stash your miscellany, including that cleverly redesigned center console.

New for 2015

Redesigned exterior and interior; more efficient and powerful 2.4-liter engine; seven-inch touchscreen display with smartphone-like functionality, active safety features, and a new Touring trim

More about the CR-V

Should You Buy It? 2015 Honda CR-V AWD

title: 2015 Jaguar XK
subTitle: A last blast for Jaguar’s grand tourer.
promoTeaserSmall: A last blast for Jaguar’s grand tourer.
promoTeaser: A last blast for Jaguar’s grand tourer.
metaKeywords: 2015 Jaguar XK; Jaguar; coupe; convertible; British
metaDescription: A last blast for Jaguar’s grand tourer. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear-wheel-drive luxury coupe or convertible
Price range: $85,495–$138,995 (includes destination)
Trim levels: XK, XKR, XKR-S
Engines: 5.0-liter V-8, 385 horsepower; supercharged 5.0-liter V-8, 510/550 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: V-6: 16 mpg city/24 mpg highway; V-8: 15/22 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Adaptive lighting system that swivels the headlights when cornering
Notable standard features on this model: Dual-zone automatic climate control, heated and ventilated front seats, front and rear park assist, rearview camera, navigation, Bluetooth
Notable options on this model: Heated windshield, suede-covered sport steering wheel
You might also be considering: BMW 6 Series, Mercedes-Benz SL-Class, Porsche 911

This is the last year for the XK, Jaguar’s venerable grand tourer. The model lineup consists of the base XK, the supercharged XKR, and the Nürburgring-developed XKR-S, each available as either a coupe or a convertible. In addition, Jaguar is producing a special edition of the XK called the Final Fifty, with performance upgrades and special styling touches. There will be 50 Final Fiftys built (no surprise, that), 25 convertibles and 25 coupes. The only available color is Ultimate Black.

Every two-plus-two, rear-wheel-drive XK comes with a powerful V-8 engine. The base XK get a normally aspirated V-8 with a substantial 385 horsepower. The V-8s in the XKR and XKR-S models are supercharged and produce an even more substantial—a blazing fast—510 and 550 horsepower, respectively. In any XK, all you need to do is stomp on the accelerator pedal to give yourself a thrill ride. However, what the XK really excels at is grand touring. Find a twisty road, roll down the windows or lower the convertible top (which can be accomplished in 18 seconds), and savor the pure fun of being behind the wheel. On the other hand, if that twisty road happens to be the Nürburgring or a racetrack, you can really go for it, especially if you’re in the XKR-S, which reaches 60 mph in a scant 4.2 seconds and tops out at more than 180 mph.

Like all Jaguars, the interior of the XK can be outfitted in a variety of veneers and leather furnishings, all of which are of top-notch quality and deliver the luxury you would expect. The touch-screen interface isn’t as advanced or as user-friendly as what you’ll find in other luxury marques, but it works well enough. In addition, the “plus two” accommodations are cramped—we’d suggest limiting occupants to a driver and one passenger, and leaving the back seat for storage.

New for 2015

Trim levels have been simplified, and standard equipment and option packages have been reconfigured. Adaptive headlights and HD Radio are standard.

title: 2015 Jaguar F-type
subTitle: A true successor to the E-type.
promoTeaserSmall: A true successor to the E-type.
promoTeaser: A true successor to the E-type.
metaKeywords: 2015 Jaguar F-type; Jaguar; coupe; convertible; British
metaDescription: A true successor to the E-type. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive luxury sport coupe or convertible
Price range: $65,995–$92,995 (includes destination)
Trim levels: F-type, F-type S, F-type V8 S (convertible only), F-type R (coupe only)
Engines: 3.0-liter supercharged V-6, 340/380 horsepower; 5.0-liter supercharged V-8, 495/550 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: F-type: 20 mpg city/28 mpg highway; F-type S: 19/27 mpg; F-type R and F-type V8 S: 16/23 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Automatic stop/start
Notable standard features on this model: Eight-inch touchscreen display, navigation, automatic climate control, heated side mirrors, auto-dimming rear-view mirror, ambient lighting
Notable options on this model: Carbon ceramic brakes (S, V8 S and R)
You might also be considering: BMW Z4, Chevrolet Corvette, Mercedes-Benz SLK, Porsche Boxster/Cayman

The F-type is something of a departure for Jaguar, which is mostly known as a luxury manufacturer. The F-type is a true two-seat sports car, one that can compete on an even playing field with the likes of Porsches and Corvettes, BMW M cars and Mercedes-Benz AMGs. For 2015, there is more to love about the F-type, as a coupe joins the convertible that debuted as a 2014 model.

The base F-type is powered by a 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 that makes 340 horsepower. There is plenty of standard equipment on the base model, including automatic xenon headlights (with washers!), full power accessories (seats, windows, mirrors), a tilt-and-telescope steering wheel, 18-inch wheels, and a touchscreen display to control various vehicular functions. Stepping up one level to the F-type S gets you the same V-6 but with 40 more horses, 19-inch wheels, larger brakes, an active sport exhaust, and Dynamic Launch Mode for track days. Both the base F-type and the S models are available as a coupe or a convertible.

The top-of-the-line convertible is the F-type V8 S, which has a 495-hp, supercharged V-8, 20-inch wheels, even larger 15-inch brakes, full leather, and 12-way adjustable seats with power lumbar support. At the very top of the F-type range is the new R coupe, whose supercharged 550-hp V-8 will power to 60 mph in a scant 4.0 seconds. The R coupe’s interior is trimmed with faux-carbon-fiber accents, a flat-bottom steering wheel, and metal brake and accelerator pedals.

You may have noticed that there are only two pedals, but wait for 2016, when a six-speed manual will be available, though only on V-6 models with rear-wheel drive. Yes, all-wheel drive will also be an option for 2016.

All of that doesn’t mean that you should wait for the 2016 models, though. The 2015 F-type is a top-notch sports car that handles with precision and is a blast to drive. One word of warning—all that handling comes courtesy of a fairly stiff suspension that can knock you around a bit on uneven pavement, but we think that’s a sacrifice worth making.

New for 2015

The Jaguar F-type is available as a coupe for 2015. It joins the F-type convertible that debuted in 2013 as a 2014 model.

More about the Jaguar F-Type

2014 Jaguar F-Type Designer Walkaround December 17, 2012

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/-6U1wrTqb6Q" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

2015 Volkswagen Golf SportWagen TSI SE

Vital Stats:

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact wagon
Base price: $27,815
Price as tested: $29,505
Engine: Turbocharged 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 170 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Safety ratings: Not yet rated
Tech features: Rearview camera, XDS Cross Differential System
Options on this model: Lighting package (ambient interior lighting, LED daytime running lights, bi-xenon adaptive headlights that swivel in the direction of a turn, $995; Driver Assistance package (includes forward collision warning, $895)
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/35 mpg highway
Chief competitors: 2015 Honda Crosstour ($28,410); 2015 Subaru XV Crosstrek 2.0i Premium ($24,145), 2015 Subaru Outback 2.5i ($25,745), 2015 Toyota Prius V ($27,575) (prices include destination)

Key Points:

• The Golf SportWagen replaces the outgoing Volkswagen Jetta SportWagen. It went on sale in April, the last of the new Golf models to arrive. • This is an alternative to SUVs and crossovers and occupies an unusual niche in the market, since there are relatively few wagon choices.
• The 2015 Volkswagen Golf SportWagen starts at $22,215 for the base 1.8T S model with a five-speed manual transmission (including destination).
• The top-of-the-line Golf SportWagen TDI SEL, the diesel version with automatic transmission, starts at $31,445 (including destination).
• Fuel economy on the diesels is better than the gasoline-engined model: the TDI with six-speed automatic transmission gets 31 mpg city/42 mpg highway. The SportWagen with 2.0¬liter turbo-diesel engine and six-speed manual transmission delivers 31 mpg city/43 mpg highway (EPA).
• The Golf SportWagen is $400 more than the Jetta SportWagen, but it features more standard equipment.
• With no all-wheel¬drive model, the Golf SportWagen is not a true competitor to Subaru wagons.

More to Read:

2015 Volkswagen Golf SportWagen: Should You Buy It?

title: 2015 Lexus IS
subTitle: Luxuriously fast sporty car.
promoTeaserSmall: Luxuriously fast sporty car.
promoTeaser: Luxuriously fast sporty car.
metaKeywords: 2015 Lexus IS; Lexus; sedan; convertible; Japanese
metaDescription: Luxuriously fast sporty car. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive sedan or convertible
Price range: $37,475–$47,025 (includes destination)
Trim levels: IS250, IS250 F Sport, IS350, IS350 F Sport
Engines: 2.5-liter V-6, 204 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6, 306 horsepower
Transmissions: Six- or eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: IS250, FWD: 21 mpg city/30 mpg highway; IS250, AWD: 20/27 mpg; IS350, FWD: 19/28 mpg; IS350, AWD: 19/26 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in two categories; ; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Siri Eyes Free
Notable standard features on this model: Heated front seats in AWD models
Notable options on this model: Heated steering wheel in AWD models, pre-collision system, adaptive cruise control, automatic high beams, a lane-departure alert, blind-spot monitor with rear cross traffic alert
You might also be considering: Audi A4, BMW 3-series, Cadillac ATS Sedan

strong>The Lexus IS is an elegant, powerful series of rear-wheel-drive sedans (all-wheel drive is also available) that are loaded with creature comforts. There is even an IS C hardtop convertible; push a button, and it transforms from a hardtop coupe to a convertible in twenty seconds. 

The power is all V-6, with a choice of 204-horsepower and 306-horsepower powertrains, rear- or all-wheel drive. And controlling that power is silky smooth, with the multi-link rear suspension and finely tuned electronic power steering. The eight-speed Sport Direct Shift automatic transmission uses advanced G-force Artificial Intelligence so the gear changes feel seamless to you. Or, if you like the feeling of power in your own hands, shift yourself with the paddle shifters.

The F Sport package sharpens handling and looks sharper both inside and out. It even sounds more like a racing car, with an intake sound generator that creates a more sporting engine note.

New for 2015

LED fog lamps, Siri Eyes Free, heated/ventilated front seats added to F Sport trim (all-wheel drive F Sport also gets heated steering wheel), revised interior trim, and the backup monitor adds dynamic grid lines.

title: 2015 Lexus LS
subTitle: Power and roomy beauty in one sedan.
promoTeaserSmall: Power and roomy beauty in one sedan.
promoTeaser: Power and roomy beauty in one sedan.
metaKeywords: 2015 Lexus LS; Lexus; sedan; hybrid; Japanese
metaDescription: Power and roomy beauty in one sedan. JeanKnowsCars.com

Price range: $73,485–$121,365 (includes destination)

Engines: 4.6-liter V-8, 386 horsepower; 5.0-liter V-8/electric hybrid, 389 horsepower
Transmissions: 8-speed automatic, continuously variable
Fuel economy: LS460: 16 mpg city/24 mpg highway; LS460, AWD: 16/23 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated

Notable options on this model: Heated wood steering wheel, five-mode air suspension
You might also be considering: Audi A8, BMW 7 Series, Mercedes-Benz S-Class

The LS originally made a splash by bringing serious power, in the form of a standard V-8 engine, to the luxury class. This year, it is doing it again by making a 386-horsepower 4.6-liter V-8 and an eight-speed automatic transmission, creating a luxury sedan that delivers plenty of smooth power to that ultra-comfy driver’s seat.

For 2015, there's a new multimedia system, app suite, Siri Eyes Free, and an upgraded navigation system with traffic and weather information. The voice-enabled Lexus Enform apps let you search Bing, make restaurant reservations, get movie tickets, and listen to your own tunes on Pandora, iHeartRadio, or Slacker, search Yelp, and more all without ever picking up your phone. The car’s driver assist technologies will keep an eye on the road and do a lot to prevent an accident: The advanced pre-collision system will avoid or lessen the impact from collisions and stop you from hitting pedestrians. It operates at city-driving and highway speeds. At speeds lower than 24 mph, the car will come to a complete stop if that’s what it needs to do to prevent an accident. (But you’ll never notice it until that moment.)

New for 2015

Multimedia system with enhanced navigation features, Lexus Enform App Suite adds Slacker and upgrades to iHeartRadio 4.0, Lexus Enform Remote, dome lamps use LED bulbs, dynamic gridlines added to backup camera.

title: 2016 Subaru BRZ
subTitle: The thinking person's sports car.
promoTeaserSmall: The thinking person's sports car.
promoTeaser: The thinking person's sports car.
metaDescription: The thinking person's sports car.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-plus-two-passenger, rear-wheel-drive sport coupe
Price range: $26,190 – $28,485 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: Premium, Limited, Series.HyperBlue limited edition
Engine: 2.0-liter horizontally opposed four-cylinder, 200 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual; six-speed automatic with manual mode and paddle shifters (optional on Limited)
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/30 mpg highway (manual); 25/34 mpg (automatic)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS): Not yet rated (2015 model was a Top Safety Pick)
Notable standard features: Rearview camera, brake assist, leather-covered steering wheel and shift knob; keyless entry and push-button start (Limited); Alcantara upholstery (Limited)
Notable options: Automatic transmission ($1,100)
You might also be considering: Honda Civic Si, Mazda MX-5 Miata, Mini Cooper, Scion FR-S

The BRZ is an unusual Subaru, coming from the company known mainly for its more practical all-wheel-drive vehicles. This is a small, lightweight rear-wheel-drive sportster that was developed jointly with Toyota (which makes the Scion FR-S sibling to the BRZ) and introduced in 2003. It is named for its boxer (horizontally opposed) four-cylinder engine and its rear-wheel drive. Known for its low center of gravity and no-frills fun to drive, the BRZ is not known for its luggage capacity (a whopping 6.9 cubic feet of cargo volume) or its back-seat comfort. That's not what you'd buy this car for. Option packages aren't, either. Get the Limited model if you want a trunk-mounted spoiler, heated front seats, Alcantara upholstery, and keyless entry with push-button start, among other features. The Premium doesn't have any of these, even as options. All BRZs get Starlink infotainment with a 6.2-inch screen, Sirius XM satellite radio, and smartphone integration. One option is the six-speed automatic transmission with manual mode and paddle shifters, which adds $1,000 to the price and improves fuel economy. For added visual flair, you could go for the limited-edition Series.HyperBlue BRZ. It adds black alloy wheels, black exterior mirrors and badges, and blue stitching on the upholstery.

New for 2016:

Series.HyperBlue special model, limited to 500 copies, priced at $28,485, including destination charge
Rearview camera standard on all models

title: Four 2016 Models You Can See This Spring
subTitle: A few of next year's cars you'll be able to see at the dealership before summer.
promoTitle: Four 2016 Models You Can See This Spring
promoTeaserSmall: A few of next year's cars you'll be able to see at the dealership before summer.
promoTeaser: A few of next year's cars you'll be able to see at the dealership before summer.
metaTitle: Four 2016 Models You Can See This Spring
metaDescription: A few of next year's cars you'll be able to see at the dealership before summer.

pageElements.text: It used to be the case that you’d have to wait for fall to go test drive the new models at the car dealership. Not anymore. Some of the earliest 2016 models are just starting to hit dealerships now, giving you an advance look on the safety technology and styling you’ll be seeing on the roads soon.

Interested in shopping for a new car—or just seeing what the automakers have thought of next? Here’s a selection of brand-new models. These are all vehicles you can go see at your local dealership and take a test drive between now and summer.  All prices are for the base model and include destination charge.

1. 2016 Volvo XC90

In dealerships: Spring 2015
Starting price: $49,895

2016 Volvo XC90 T8 Twin Engine Plug-In Hybrid

In dealerships: Viewing and test drives now; on sale in the fall
Starting price: $69,095

There’s no shortage of SUVs on the market, but this one is special, especially to people who are already Volvo fans. The proof? There have been 16,000 orders for Volvo’s all-new seven-passenger luxury SUV before it even hit showrooms. Late last fall, an online-only sale of 1,927 (for Volvo’s founding date) individually numbered First Edition models sold out in 47 hours.

As you’d expect from Volvo, there’s a standard City Safety package, with two world-first features that can help prevent common accidents by warning the driver and applying brakes to avoid a crash, or at least to reduce its severity.

The interior is luxurious beyond any previous Volvo with every version getting standard leather seats, real wood trim, navigation system, panoramic sunroof, and full-size adult seating all the way to the third row.

Even more exciting, Volvo’s bringing a plug-in hybrid version, which it bills as the world’s first seven-passenger entry in that category. The XC90 T8 Twin Engine’s electric-only range is seventeen miles—then it automatically switches to the supercharged and turbocharged 2.0-liter engine, which makes 394 horsepower and can take you from 0 to 60 mph in 5.7 seconds. All that, and a hand-blown Orrefors crystal gearshift knob. Look out, Tesla.

2. 2016 Honda HR-V

In dealerships: May 15
Starting price: $26,720

Sport-utility vehicles started big, but these days, crossover vehicles are getting more compact and citified. Honda is rolling out this brand-new one, smaller than the extremely popular CR-V, to face off against subcompacts like the Buick Encore, Kia Soul, and Nissan Juke. It has a 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine making 141 horsepower, teamed with a continuously variable automatic transmission.

The HR-V’s strongest suit is how much stuff you can fit inside it. Fuel economy is admirable at 28 mpg in the city, 35 mpg on the highway for the front-wheel-drive version. You get 32 mpg on the highway even if you choose the all-wheel-drive version. All that, and the clean looks and quality reputation of a Honda.

3. 2016 Scion FR-S

In dealerships: June 11
Starting price: $26,075

Toyota’s youth-oriented division has improved its FR-S sport coupe for 2016 without completely overhauling it. A rearview camera is now standard, and so is a seven-inch infotainment touchscreen with audio and voice recognition. This car is for people who love to drive, so it comes standard with a six-speed manual transmission, but you can get a six-speed automatic with paddle shifters and Dynamic Rev Management for an extra $1,100. Two new colors, Ablaze (red) and Oceanic (blue), update the FR-S for the new model year.

On September 1, you may want to go back to your Scion dealer to see two brand-new models, the 2016 iA sedan--Scion’s first--and iM hatchback. The iA will start around $16,000 and the iM will be priced starting under $20,000.

4. 2016 Fiat 500X

In dealerships: Early summer
Starting price: $20,900

If you think the Fiat 500 is cute but maybe a little too small for your needs, you might be interested in the all-new 500X. This is a front-wheel-drive crossover vehicle that seats up to five and is available with all-wheel drive (a $1,900 option). There are Trekking and Trekking Plus versions that look more like little SUVs, as well as Pop, Easy, and Lounge models that carry the Fiat 500’s Italian city-car styling into the bigger body style. All come with a turbocharged 160-horsepower, 1.4-liter engine with a six-speed manual transmission, or an optional 180-horsepower 2.4-liter four-cylinder teamed with a nine-speed automatic transmission.

There’s a full slate of optional safety features to explore on the 500X, including forward collision warning with full stop, lane departure and blind spot monitoring systems, and rear cross-path detection.

images.caption: Orrefors crystal shift knob on 2016 Volvo XC90.

title: 2015 Toyota Prius Three
subTitle: Let me tell you what I really think about the ubiquitous hybrid.
promoTeaserSmall: Let me tell you what I really think about the ubiquitous hybrid.
promoTeaser: Let me tell you what I really think about the ubiquitous hybrid.
metaDescription: Let me tell you what I really think about the ubiquitous hybrid.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger hybrid hatchback
Base price: $26,590 (including destination)
Price as tested: $28,315 (including destination)
Engine: 1.8-liter four-cylinder/electric motor/nickel-metal hydride battery, 134 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic

Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus (Prius and Prius v)
Tech features: Rearview camera, stability control, traction control, Smart Stop Technology brake override system (brings vehicle to stop in cases of unintended acceleration)
Options on this model: Solar Roof package ($1,500) includes power moonroof with solar-powered ventilation system and remote air conditioning system with sliding sunshade; carpet floor mats and cargo mat ($225)
Fuel economy: 51 mpg city/48 mpg highway
Chief competitors: 2015 Chevrolet Volt ($35,170), 2015 Ford Fusion Hybrid ($26,010); 2015 Honda Accord Hybrid ($30,125) (prices include destination)

Key Points:

• The Toyota Prius family of vehicles includes the Prius One (fleet only, starting at $24,100); Prius Two ($25,025), the Prius Three shown here, and the Prius Four, Five, and Persona Series.
• What began as a single model fifteen years ago is now a model line that also includes the larger Prius v wagon, city-friendly Prius c, and Prius Plug-in Hybrid.
• Most expensive is the 2015 Prius Plug-in Advanced, priced at $35,730 (all prices include destination).
• The Prius family alone accounts for over 40 percent of total hybrid vehicle sales volume in the U.S., according to Toyota.
• All hybrids on the market are now measured against the Prius, especially since it now has such versatile body configurations.
• The Prius’s quirky—some say dorky—exterior may not be for everyone.
• It is a regular on the EPA’s list of the most fuel-efficient cars in America.
• The Prius Three we tested has the Touch Tracer Display. Touch sensors on the steering wheel switches display a duplicate image on the instrument panel in driver’s line of sight to reduce distraction.
• What’s up next for Toyota? The automaker will be taking green to the next level with the 2016 Toyota Mirai fuel-cell vehicle. It will start at $58,325 and comes to U.S. dealers in the fall.
• Additional markets will follow as the hydrogen refueling structure in the U.S. expands.

subTitle: In or out of its shell.

promoTeaser: In or out of its shell.
metaDescription: In or out of its shell. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 2-passenger, rear-wheel-drive sports coupe or convertible
Price range: $30,800–$50,210 (includes destination)
Trim levels: 370Z, 370Z Sport, 370Z Sport Tech, 370Z Touring, 370 Nismo, 370Z Nismo Tech, 370Z Roadster, 370Z Roadster Touring, 370Z Roadster Touring Sport
Engines: 3.7-liter V-6, 332 horsepower, 3.7-liter V-6, 350 horsepower
Transmissions: 6-speed manual, 7-speed automatic
Fuel economy: Coupe, automatic: 19 mpg city/26 highway mpg; Coupe, manual: 18/26 mpg; Roadster, manual: 17/24 mpg; Roadster, automatic: 18/25 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not rated; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Smart key with pushbutton start
Notable standard features on this model: Automatic on/off HID headlamps, LED daytime running lights, LED taillamps, 6-speed manual transmission, multilink suspension with tuned shock absorbers, automatic temperature control, Bluetooth connectivity with hands-free calling, stability control, active head restraints, 18-inch wheels, vented front and rear brakes
Notable options on this model: Nineteen-inch wheels, heated, leather-trimmed sport seats, navigation, rearview camera
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Camaro, Ford Mustang, Hyundai Genesis Coupe

The Nissan 370Z represents a sports car bargain, and that’s always been the case since its 240Z predecessor appeared 45 years ago. It has a sports car’s classis front-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout. With a short 100.4-inch wheelbase and overall length of just 167.5 inches, you know it will get through the cones at your local autocross course. The 370Z has a highly aerodynamic body—the Sport and Sport Tech trim levels most of all. To keep down overall weight, aluminum is used in the hood, doors, and rear hatch. Power comes from a 3.7-liter V-6, which makes 332 horsepower (350 horsepower in the 370Z Nismo). The standard 6-speed manual gearbox can be ordered with a feature that blips the throttle for smooth downshifts. The available 7-speed automatic comes with a similar feature. While even the base model has great brakes, the 370Z Nismo has even more powerful ones to go with a specially braced and tuned suspension and viscous limited-slip differential for that extra edge in handling. The 370Z Roadster has a power-operated, fully automatic top in black or Bordeaux with a fabric liner and glass rear window with integrated defroster. This year’s new 370Z Touring Sport Roadster is equipped with some of the Nismo’s components for give it an edge over its competitors, of which there are few.

New for 2015

370Z Sport, 370Z Sport Tech, and 370Z Touring Sport Roadster join the model lineup, revised suspension tuning, and navigation is now standard on 370Z Touring.

title: 2015 Nissan GT-R
subTitle: Nearly unlimited performance, limited availability.
promoTeaserSmall: Nearly unlimited performance, limited availability.
promoTeaser: Nearly unlimited performance, limited availability.
metaKeywords: 2015 Nissan GT-R; Nissan; coupe; sports car; Japanese
metaDescription: Nearly unlimited performance, limited availability. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 4-passenger all-wheel-drive coupe
Price range: $103,365–$151,585 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Premium, Black Edition, Nismo
Engines: Twin-turbocharged 3.8-liter V-6, 545 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 3.8-liter V-6, 600 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/23 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Active noise cancellation
Notable standard features on this model: Navigation, Bluetooth connectivity, configurable multifunction display, rearview camera, smart key with pushbutton start, leather upholstery with suede inserts, leather-wrapped steering multifunction steering wheel, heated front seats, all-wheel drive, 20-inch wheels, 11-speaker audio system
Notable options on this model: Titanium exhaust system, cold weather package, ivory or red amber premium interior
You might also be considering: BMW M, Chevrolet Corvette Z06, Porsche 911

A cult car, rare and expensive, the 2015 Nissan GT-R is the result of great engineers and designers obsessing over every conceivable detail. Consider just a few examples. The stereo speakers are mounted in die-cast aluminum frames. Rather than iron sleeves, the V-6 engine’s cylinder bores have low-friction plasma coatings. The engine cover is a work of art, suitable for framing. This year, much attention was given to retuning the suspension components and brakes with the goal of better drivability around town. Who knows? The lucky owner of a GT-R might utilize the 8.8 cubic feet of cargo capacity for a trip to Costco. Additional sound deadening measures have also been taken, and active noise cancellation counteracts booming from the twin-turbo V-6, which produces 545-horsepower (600-horsepower in the GT-R Nismo). Being capable of 196 mph, the GT-R boasts one of the most aero-efficient bodies (0.26 cd) thanks in part to the carefully designed rear spoiler and undertrays, and now the GT-R Black Edition features a handmade, specially coated carbon-fiber spoiler. For that shopping trip, the driver might tame the GT-R with the 6-speed dual-clutch gearbox’s Normal or Save mode, and wait to use the paddle shifters and rev matching when R-Mode is engaged on track day. New for 2015 and typical of the obsessive details we mentioned, the available Regal Red body color blends 24-karat gold-coated glass flakes into the paint. And the Ivory Premium Package interior covers the seats in hand-stitched, semi-aniline leather, which is also applied on the instrument panel, steering wheel, and shift knob. The GT-R Black Edition has a red-and-black interior with leather-covered Recaro front bucket seats. Now get in and drive—stop obsessing!

New for 2015

Recalibrated suspension and brakes, active noise cancellation, carbon-style instrument cluster, new tire compound and tread pattern, LED headlamps, and a new paint color: Regal Red.

title: 2015 Nissan Juke
subTitle: Crossing over to the sporty side.
promoTeaserSmall: Crossing over to the sporty side.
promoTeaser: Crossing over to the sporty side.
metaKeywords: 2015 Nissan Juke; Nissan; crossover; sport-utility; SUV; Japanese
