pageElements.text:
Type: 5-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $21,075–$30,845 (includes destination)
Trim levels: S, SV, SL, Nismo, Nismo RS
Engine: Turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 188 horsepower, Turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 211/215 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed manual, continuously variable
Fuel economy: FWD continuously variable: 28 mpg city/32 mpg highway; AWD continuously variable: 26/31 mpg; Nismo FWD: 28/34 mpg; Nismo AWD: 26/31 mpg; Nismo RS FWD: 25/31 mpg; Nismo RS AWD: 25/29 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Small front overlap: Poor; Moderate front overlap, Side, Roof strength, Head restraints and seats: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Bluetooth connectivity and hands-free texting
Notable standard features on this model: NissanConnect with Mobile Apps smartphone link, smart key with pushbutton start, 17-inch alloy wheels, 6-speaker audio system, rearview camera, stability control, active head restraints
Notable options on this model: All-wheel drive, 18-inch alloy wheels
You might also be considering: Ford Focus ST, Kia Soul, Scion xB

As one of the most delightfully strange vehicles offered by any manufacturer, the Nissan Juke makes you forget there was ever a day when people fretted about all cars looking alike. (It was about 10 years ago.) The Juke’s unusual face and profile eventually work their charms, and then you’re won over by subtle details like the rear door handles, which are integrated into the doorframe. Standing tall on large wheels, this little hotrod is playful and insouciant. And then there’s the driving experience. The Juke punches above its weight with a direct-injection, turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine, revised this year for better fuel economy, improved responsiveness, and lower emissions. It’s paired with a continuously variable transmission with a sport mode. Not only does the Juke bustle right down the road, but it also gives a Bronx cheer when passing gas stations. This five-seater is a front-wheel-drive vehicle with available all-wheel drive and up to 35.9 cubic feet of cargo space. The Juke S is well equipped with desirable feature content: connectivity and audio are strong points. The upmarket models add such items as a sunroof, leather, premium audio, and a 360-degree view. And you still haven’t spent a lot of money! The Nismo, names for Nissan’s motorsports arm rides on 18-inch wheels and a tuned suspension, and the Nismo RS is further endowed with a punchier 215 or 211 horsepower four—front- or all-wheel-drive models, respectively—stronger brakes, a braced chassis, and Recaro front bucket seats, taking the Juke into territory that’s not really shared with any other vehicle.

New for 2015

Projector-headlamps with LED Accents, revised engine, standard smart key with pushbutton start, standard Bluetooth connectivity and hands-free texting, new colors: Solar Yellow, Cosmic Blue, Super Black.

title: 2015 Nissan Titan
subTitle: The offbeat alternative.
promoTeaserSmall: The offbeat alternative.
promoTeaser: The offbeat alternative.
metaKeywords: 2015 Nissan Titan; Nissan; truck; pickup; Japanese
metaDescription: The offbeat alternative. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 5- or 6-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive pickup
Price range: $30,735–$39,265 (includes destination)
Trim levels: S, SV, Pro-4X, SL
Engine: 5.6-liter V-8, 317 horsepower
Transmission: 5-speed automatic
Fuel economy: RWD: 13 mpg city/18 mpg highway; AWD: 12/17 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Moderate overlap front, Head restraints and seats: Good; Roof strength: Acceptable; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Traction and stability control
Notable standard features on this model: Air conditioning, 18-inch wheels, tilt-adjustable steering wheel, 60/40-split fold up rear bench seat, skid plates (4x4), removable locking tailgate, front seat active head restraints, wide-opening rear doors (King cab)
Notable options on this model: Remote keyless entry, 20-inch wheels, overhead center console, sliding back window, tow hitch receiver and trailer brake prewiring, Bluetooth connectivity, premium audio, heated front seats, leather-trimmed seats
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Silverado, Ford F-150, Toyota Tundra

The Nissan Titan has always been a great-looking pickup. Its face is bold but not outrageous, and the body design incorporates a few swoops and flares. Even though the 2015 Titan closes out the product cycle and an all-new Titan is in the offing, the original’s good looks are holding up just fine. The Titan is offered in extended King Cab or Crew Cab body styles with rear- or available 4-wheel drive. Boasting the largest standard engine among full-size pickups, this workhorse will tow up to 9,500 pounds. It includes traction control and stability control for surefire hill climbing and cornering on slick roads. The locking removable tailgate is a nifty standard feature, and the available locking bedside storage compartment and Utili-track cargo carrying system enhance the cargo box’s usefulness. Inside its cab, the Titan masters the pickup category’s mobile office requirements; the center-console’s workstation is as versatile and convenient as they come, and the front passenger seat folds flat for what serves as a desk. In back of either King or Crew Cab, the 60/40-split rear seats flip up to provide extra cargo space. The SV Value package puts the Titan on 20-inch wheels, hangs step rails on the cab, and places captain’s chairs in the front row. Then it piles on the infotainment and connectivity features. The PRO-4X girds the Titan for rock-busting duty, adding a transfer case skid plates, and high-performance shock absorbers. For all its virtues, though, the Titan runs far behind the pack in fuel economy, so be prepared to frequent the pump.

New for 2015

Revised interior trim, available power-adjustable driver’s seat lumbar support, new 20-inch alloy wheels, and two new exterior paint colors: Arctic Metallic blue and Magnetic black paint.

title: 2015 Mazda 3
subTitle: More than the average compact car.
promoTeaserSmall: More than the average compact car.
promoTeaser: More than the average compact car.
metaDescription: More than the average compact car. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan or hatchback
Price range: $17,765–$27,415 (includes destination)
Trim levels: SV, Sport, Touring, Grand Touring
Engines: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 155 horsepower; 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 184 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual, six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.0-liter automatic sedan: 30 mpg city/41 mpg highway; 2.0-liter manual sedan: 29/41 mpg; 2.5-liter automatic sedan: 28/39 mpg; 2.5-liter automatic sedan w/i-ELOOP: 29/40 mpg; 2.5-liter manual sedan: 25/37 mpg; 2.0-liter automatic hatchback: 30/40 mpg; 2.0-liter manual hatchback: 29/40 mpg; 2.5-liter automatic hatchback: 27/37 mpg; 2.5-liter automatic hatchback w/i-ELOOP: 28/39 mpg; 2.5-liter manual hatchback: 26/35 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: MazdaCONNECT infotainment system
Notable standard features on this model: Push-button start, cruise control, Bluetooth phone and audio connectivity
Notable options on this model: Sunroof, dual-zone climate control, navigation, rearview camera
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Hyundai Elantra, Toyota Corolla, Volkswagen Golf

Shopping for a compact car used to be an exercise in lowering your expectations. Fuel-efficiency and price were what drove most buyers, and compacts were generally bare-bones cars with a modest list of standard equipment and few options. That is no longer true. Case in point: the Mazda 3. The 3 is Mazda’s best-selling vehicle in the United States, and while it sits as the low end of the brand’s model line, it now offers features like pushbutton start, a rear-view camera, power seats, and multimedia connectivity, which were previously reserved for more upscale models.

What is even more important, though, is that the Mazda 3 is fun to drive. With excellent acceleration, a balanced suspension, and sharp steering and braking, the Mazda 3 is among the most enjoyable compact cars to drive on a day-to-day basis. The 155-horsepower, 2.0-liter and 184-horsepower, 2.5-liter engines can be paired with either a six-speed manual or a six-speed automatic. You’ll get slightly better mileage with the automatic, but the manual offers you the chance to have the kind of interactive driving experience that an automatic just can’t match. For maximum fuel efficiency, Mazda offers an optional i-ELOOP regenerative braking system that converts the car’s kinetic energy to electricity as soon as the accelerator is released.

The Mazda 3 is available as either a four-door sedan or a four-door hatchback. There are four trim levels, each of which is preceded by an i (2.0-liter) or an s (2.5-liter), depending on the engine. The sedan has a sizable 12.4-cubic-foot trunk, but for maximum cargo flexibility opt for the hatchback, which has 20.2 cubic feet of space behind the rear seats, and 47.1 cubic feet with the back row folded flat.

New for 2015

A manual transmission can now be paired with the 2.5-liter engine. Minor changes to the standard and optional equipment list.

Our favorite standard feature: Rearview camera (except for manual Sport model)
Notable standard features on this model: Cruise control, push-button start, tilt and telescope steering wheel
Notable options on this model: Power moonroof, lane-departure and forward obstruction warnings, radar cruise control, navigation, eleven-speaker sound system
You might also be considering: Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Hyundai Santa Fe Sport, Jeep Cherokee, Subaru Forester, Toyota RAV4

For everyday practicality, it’s hard to beat a compact crossover like the Mazda CX-5. With seating for up to five people, the CX-5 offers a spacious interior and 34.1 cubic feet of cargo room behind the second row. That capacity expands to 65.4 cubic feet when the second row (which can also be split 60/40 or 40/20/40, depending on trim level) is folded.

Besides being spacious, the CX-5’s interior is well designed and functional, with soft materials on the door trim and upper panels plus accents of piano black and satin-finish chrome. The gauges are well placed and easy to decipher, and the three-spoke steering wheel has controls from which you can easily adjust the cruise control and audio systems. The elevated driving position is welcome in heavy traffic, and the seats—power adjustable in Touring and Grand Touring models—are comfortable and supportive.

The two available engines mirror those in the compact Mazda 3: a 155-horsepower 2.0-liter and a 184-horsepower 2.5-liter. Both four-cylinder engines perform well in the smaller, lighter Mazda 3, but we’d opt for the 2.5-liter with the 350-pound-heavier CX-5. There will be a small sacrifice in fuel efficiency (about 1 mpg), but the extra power will be welcome when merging and passing. There are two available transmissions—a six-speed automatic that can be had in any trim level and a six-speed manual that is only available with the 2.0-liter engine. You can also order your CX-5 with either front- or all-wheel drive.

The CX-5 is available in three trim levels, starting with the Sport and moving up to the Touring and Grand Touring. No matter which you pick, you’ll find that the CX-5 exhibits better steering, braking, and suspension balance than you might expect from a vehicle in this class.

New for 2015

The 2.5-liter engine replaces the 2.0-liter on Sport all-wheel-drive models and keyless entry and ignition are now standard on the Touring and Grand Touring.

title: 2015 Porsche 911
subTitle: Life begins at fifty.
promoTeaserSmall: Life begins at fifty.
promoTeaser: Life begins at fifty.
metaKeywords: 2015 Porsche 911; Porsche; Carrera; Targa; coupe; convertible; German
metaDescription: Life begins at fifty. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 2+2-passenger, rear-wheel-drive coupe or convertible
Price range: $85,295–$195,595 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Carrera, Carrera S, Carrera GTS, Carrera 4, Carrera 4S, Carrera 4 GTS, Targa 4, Targa 4S, GT3, Turbo, Turbo S
Engines: 3.4-liter flat 6, 350 horsepower; 3.8-liter flat 6, 400/430/475 horsepower, turbocharged 3.8-liter flat 6, 520/560 horsepower
Transmissions: Seven-speed manual, seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: Carrera/Carrera S/Carrera 4 automatic: 20 mpg city/28 mpg highway; Carrera/Carrera S/Carrera 4 manual: 19/27 mpg; Carrera 4S/GTS/Targa 4 automatic: 19/26 mpg; Carrera 4S/GTS/Targa 4/Targa 4S manual: 18/26 mpg; Targa 4S automatic: 18/25 mpg; GT3: 15/20 mpg; Turbo/Turbo S: 17/24 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated by either NHTSA or IIHS
Our favorite standard feature: Seven-speed manual transmission
Notable standard features on this model: Heated seats, xenon headlights, tilt-and-telescoping steering wheel, navigation, Bluetooth
Notable options on this model: PASM (active suspension management), PTV (torque vectoring), PCCB (ceramic composite brakes), sport exhaust, Sport Chrono package
You might also be considering: Audi R8, Chevrolet Corvette, Jaguar F-type, Nissan GT-R

Porsche has been building the 911 for more than half a century, and in that time it has seen continual advancements in power, handling, and high-tech driving aids. Everything about the 911 has become more civilized in the last fifty years, but it has remained true to its sports car roots. There are seemingly innumerable variations of the 911 to appeal to enthusiast drivers of all stripes. It can be had as a hard-top coupe, a soft-top convertible (Cabriolet), or a retractable roof coupe (Targa). It comes in rear- or four-wheel drive, and its six-cylinder engine can be either normally aspirated or turbocharged. All 911s (except for the two-seat, track-focused GT3) are two-plus-twos—which comes in handy when ferrying small children or a set of golf clubs—but this sports car is really most comfortable with no more than two passengers.

The base model is the rear-wheel-drive 911 Carrera, powered by a 350-horsepower, 3.4-liter six-cylinder engine. The 911 Carrera 4 is virtually identical to the base model, except with all-wheel drive. Moving one step up the model chart to the Carrera S and Carrera 4S gets you a 3.8-liter engine that makes 400 horsepower. Power improves incrementally from there, topping out at a truly impressive 560 horsepower in the 911 Turbo S. There are two available transmissions, a seven-speed manual and a seven-speed PDK automatic. Sadly for those who prefer a three-pedal setup, the PDK is the only transmission in the three highest-end 911s: GT3, Turbo, and Turbo S. (Porsche argues that the PDK is faster than a manual, and therefore the right choice for its highest-performance models. We beg to differ.)

The 911 starts at a little more than $85,000 and comes with a fair amount of standard equipment, including bi-xenon headlights, rear parking sensors, heated mirrors, dual-zone climate control, leather upholstery, navigation, and Bluetooth. Be careful when selecting options, as Porsche is notorious for its hefty fees for add-ons—$4,000 plus for the PDK automatic, $8,500 for ceramic composite brakes, several thousand dollars for various interior finishes. They even charge you $300 for putting the name of the car on the doors. In other words, you’ll be hard-pressed to leave the dealership with a 911 that costs less than six figures.

However, that cost is about the only thing that might dampen your enthusiasm for the 911, a car that, even fifty years on, is the very definition of sports car.

New for 2015

The 430-horsepower 911 GTS is added to the lineup for 2015, as is an optional rearview camera.

title: 2015 Porsche Macan
subTitle: The Cayenne’s peppy little brother.
promoTeaserSmall: The Cayenne’s peppy little brother.
promoTeaser: The Cayenne’s peppy little brother.
metaKeywords: 2015 Porsche Macan; Porsche; SUV; sport-utility; crossover; German
metaDescription: The Cayenne’s peppy little brother. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $50,895–$73,295 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Macan S, Turbo
Engines: 3.0-liter V-6, 340 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 3.6-liter V-6, 400 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/23 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Not rated by either NHTSA or IIHS
Our favorite standard feature: All-wheel drive
Notable standard features on this model: Three-zone climate control, bi-xenons headlights, sport steering wheel
Notable options on this model: Adaptive damping, cargo management system, lane-keep assist
You might also be considering: Audi Q5, BMW X3, Mercedes-Benz GLK

After the sales success of the Cayenne SUV, adding a compact crossover to its model range was a no-brainer for Porsche. The Macan went on sale for the 2015 model year, and so far the only problem is that Porsche can’t build enough of them. In fact, the only Porsche that outsells the Macan is the Cayenne.

The fact that two SUVs sit atop the sales sheet doesn’t mean that Porsche has abandoned its sports car roots, though. Take the Macan on a curvy road, and it displays razor-sharp handling, with minimal body roll and exceptional turn-in. The cabin is comfortable and well put together, with quality materials and construction. All of the important controls are within easy reach, although the plethora of buttons on the center console can be confusing.

The base model is the Macan S, which has a 340-horsepower, 3.0-liter V-6 and comes standard with nineteen-inch wheels shod with all-season tires, an eleven-speaker audio system, a seven-inch TFT display, Bluetooth, three-zone automatic climate control, bi-xenon headlights, a multi-function sport steering wheel, piano black interior trim, split-folding rear seats, a power tailgate, and 17.7 cubic feet of storage capacity behind the rear seats (53.0 cubic feet with the rear seats folded).

The Turbo model gets a more powerful engine, adaptive damping, unique wheels, full leather upholstery, and an upgraded audio system. You can get some of the Turbo’s standard features as options on the Macan S, and there is also an extensive standalone options list for both models that includes high-tech performance items like torque vectoring, active suspension management, and ceramic composite brakes.

So far, the Macan has been a huge success for Porsche. In fact, most of the German automaker’s sales gains over the past year can be traced directly to this new model. Porsche recently stated that it would start ramping up production of the Macan. This is welcome news to prospective buyers, who have had to wait up to six months in some locations for their new vehicle. A wait, we might add, that they likely think was well worth it.

New for 2015

The Macan is an all-new model.

You might also be considering: Chevrolet Sonic, Ford Fiesta, Honda Fit

Roomy for a subcompact, the Hyundai Accent is well designed inside and out and presents a level of mechanical sophistication we’re not used to seeing for less than $20,000. Under the hood, the direct-injection 1.6-liter four-cylinder generates 137 horsepower, which is outstanding for a small powerplant. The balance between performance and efficiency is hardly compromised, though, and the sculpted, streamlined body helps to achieve up to 38 highway mpg. You choose between a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission; the latter comes with a selectable Eco mode that governs performance in favor of fuel economy. In addition to the sedan, the Accent is offered as a hatchback. The GS 5-Door has the same trim as the GLS sedan, but the Sport 5-Door, which replaces last year’s SE model, adds standard features such as a leather-wrapped multifunction steering wheel (and re-tuned steering), premium cloth upholstery, and auto-up driver’s side window. Outside, the Sport shows some attitude with sixteen-inch alloy wheels, LED headlamp accents, fog lamps, and a rear spoiler. Standard on every model, a suite of safety features includes active front head restraints and sophisticated stability and braking systems.

New for 2015

New grille, headlamps, and taillamps; outside temperature display; revised LCD audio display; new colors, wheels, and seat fabrics.

subTitle: Character actor.
promoTeaserSmall: Character actor.

Transmission: Six-speed automatic

Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Hands-free trunk opener
Notable standard features on this model: Leather upholstery, suite of electronically controlled active safety features, 12-way power driver’s seat, heated and ventilated front seats and heated rear seats, dual-zone climate control system, cooled glove box, Bluetooth connectivity, iPod/USB ports
Notable options on this model: 19-inch wheels, LED foglamps, HID headlamps, panoramic sunroof, carbon interior accents, power rear sunshade, manual rear-window shades
You might also be considering: Buick LaCrosse, Ford Taurus, Nissan Maxima, Toyota Avalon

Not many people know the Hyundai Azera. If this front-wheel-drive sedan were an actor, it would have a long and successful career doing character roles, like Wilfrid Hyde-White, who played Colonel Hugh Pickering in My Fair Lady. The Azera has nicely sculpted bodywork and a presentable face, a contemporary powertrain that can sing, and a newly upgraded infotainment system that masters all its lines. Weighing significantly less than many its competitors, it can also do the old soft shoe. For 2015, the Azera gets a minor face lift and fanny tuck with a new grille and bumpers. The standard eighteen-inch wheels have been redesigned. And the sedan adds a standard hands-free trunk opener for convenience and blind-spot detection with rear cross-traffic alert and lane-change assist for safety. Climbing inside over newly illuminated door sill plates and settling into the heated and ventilated leather front seats, we find the redesigned center stack includes an eight-inch touchscreen that can split between navigation and audio functions. The 14-speaker sound system brings out all the tenderness of "On the Street Where You Live." Included in the Azera Limited are a panoramic sunroof, power rear sunshade, manual rear side window sunshades, and ambient lighting. When you’re casting for a premium sedan, the Azera might not come to mind first, but you may find it perfect for the part.

New for 2015

Restyled front and rear; new 8-inch LCD screen and infotainment features; standard blind-spot detection, rear cross-traffic alert, and lane-change assist.

Need to make a bold, individualistic statement? Short of a Rolls-Royce Wraith, the Hyundai Veloster should be at the top of your shopping list. The Veloster has style that will alarm your stodgier family members while causing wonderment among your friends. This two-door, front-wheel-drive hatchback flaunts its striking and unforgettable silhouette, daring character lines, and radically sculpted forms. To provide mechanicals that back up the visual aggressions, the Veloster comes with a direct-injection 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine and 6-speed manual transmission. In the Veloster Re:Flex, the available 6-speed dual-clutch automatic with EcoShift feature deftly wrings out that extra mile per gallon. A special edition, the Re:Flex includes leather seats, unique projector headlamps with LED accents, LED tail lamps, and a premium audio system. It’s available in an exclusive Ice Pearl paint.

The Veloster’s available style package bundles a list of features, starting with 18-inch alloy wheels, chrome grille trim with black highlights, foglamps, and a panoramic sunroof. Inside, the style package includes a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, leatherette seat and door trim, and an auto-up driver’s window. The tech package has useful conveniences: navigation, parking assistance, automatic climate control and headlamps, and Proximity Key with push-button start. The Turbo R-Spec is slightly de-contented from the premium Turbo model, but going down the road, either of them will reinforce your relatives’ outrage and friends’ admiration, thanks to the turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine, which produces 201 horsepower.

New for 2015

The R-Spec model now comes with unique suspension, shifter, red exterior and interior accents. Special edition Re:Flex model.

More about the Hyundai Veloster

2016 Hyundai Veloster at the New York Auto Show February 17, 2015

This sleek, comfy big sedan gets a new look this year. At least if you view it from the back. It has a redesigned posterior. From the inside out, though, it continues to deliver that same Lincoln space, handling, and comfort. Lincoln Drive Control is now standard. That system controls things like the MKS’s continuously controlled damping and the adjustable suspension, the electric power-assisted steering, and active noise control.

This thing has plenty of power. (You probably knew that.) But if that’s enough get up and go for you, add the EcoBoost V-6 engine. It delivers 356 horsepower without sacrificing much in fuel economy. An EcoBoost-equipped MKS gets 17 mpg in the city and 25 mpg on the highway.

If tech is on your must-have-list you will be pleased with the SiriusXM Traffic and TravelLink, which is newly added to the car’s already nice SYNC with MyLincoln Touch connectivity system.

New for 2015

Newly designed rear deck lid, new exterior colors: Java, Magnetic, Bronze Fire and Luxe

This small utility vehicle, Lincoln’s first foray into this class, started as a concept car in 2013. It's packed with clever and luxurious features. The 2.3-liter EcoBoost engine keeps it moving. The nifty wraparound liftgate is super convenient, and the interior is drenched in stylish comfort. The high-design dash with Lincoln’s unique push-button gear shifter is perfectly suited to a lifestyle defined by the quality of the leather cradling your posterior and the sublime ease by which even the smallest tasks can be accomplished. The plush leathers here caress while the muscle atrophying ease of this push-button, pedal-powered machine assure that you will never have to consider exertion. The panoramic roof opens up the interior, letting in light and sky so you never have to go outside. Even your hands, far more sensitive than the after regions, are treated to a luscious leather-wrapped wheel.

Go ahead and crank the tunes because the THX II Certified Audio System will assail your ears with the soundtrack to your existence. Connect SYNC® with MyLincoln Touch to personalize your MKC ride merely by speaking to it your commands. Those wheels will be turning, too. Because you’ve got 285 horsepower under the hood and, if the comfort lulls you to sleep, the collision warning and lane keeping system will snap you out of it before disaster occurs.
If parking is too much trouble, the park-assist technology will guide you into tight parallel parking situations so you can look like a better driver than you are.

New for 2015

This car is a new model for 2015.

See our full review of the 2015 MKC.

Acura’s entry-level model was redesigned a couple of years ago and carries over mostly unchanged for 2015—which isn’t a bad thing. The ILX shares its underpinnings with the Honda Civic but has a character of its own, with unique sheetmetal and a cabin that is in keeping with its luxury aspirations. It also feels different to drive than the Civic, with a suspension that is tuned to give it a better ride over rough road surfaces.

There are three trim levels and two different powertrain options. The base ILX comes with a 150-horsepower, 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine that is mated to a five-speed automatic transmission. The base model is well equipped, with a multi-view rear camera to help in tight parking spaces, cruise control, heated side mirrors, heated leather-trimmed front seats, pushbutton start, and Bluetooth among its many amenities. There is also a Premium model, which adds satellite radio, an automatically dimming rear-view mirror, high-intensity discharge headlights, and fog lights. The Technology model gets all of the above, plus navigation, GPS-linked climate control, and a premium sound system.

The Technology model is also the only ILX that can be had with the 201-horsepower, 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine and a six-speed manual transmission for an extra dash of sportiness. With prices starting at less than $30,000, the ILX is aimed at young drivers who aspire to an uplevel marque, and if offers the sorts of features that younger buyers—and those who are looking for an entry-luxury bargain—might find intriguing.

New for 2015

Minor changes in feature content. The Hybrid model has been discontinued.

Four-door hatchbacks can be design disasters, crudely chopped from a block of steel. Or, like the Nissan Versa Note, they can be remarkably charming: well proportioned, and sculpted, with just the right stance. The Versa Note has an unusual presence for a car that’s only 163 inches long. (It also has an unusual amount of cargo space with up to 38.3 cubic feet.) In fact, the Versa Note, which was introduced for 2014, looked so good, we wondered why there wasn’t a dedicated sport model. This year, in addition to the high-trim Versa Note SL, there is now a Note SR. Unfortunately, the SR doesn’t have a turbocharged engine to put muscle behind the sporty look, only the same normally aspirated 1.6-liter four cylinder making 109 horsepower as the other models. Otherwise, the SR sure does fill the part, with a unique, dark headlight accents, fog lamps, and a whisking tail topped by a rear spoiler. Inside, the seats are covered in faux suede, and the standard level of infotainment and connectivity is high. There’s also a rearview monitor and a clever adjustable load floor in the cargo area. The new Note SL rides on handsome 16-inch alloy wheels and is loaded with features like a smart key with push-button start and a class-exclusive 360-degree monitor. In whatever trim level, the Versa Note goes about its business with joie de vivre, making itself as useful as possible.

New for 2015

Expanded model lineup with SR and SL trims, available 360-degree monitor, NissanConnect with Navigation and Mobile Apps, hands-free texting, rearview camera, and an adjustable load floor.

title: 6 Ways to Take Care of Tires in Summer
subTitle: Be ready for summer road trips by checking, maintaining, and being ready for whatever happens to your tires.
promoTitle: 6 Ways to Take Care of Tires in Summer
promoTeaserSmall: Be ready for summer road trips by checking, maintaining, and being ready for whatever happens to your tires.
promoTeaser: Be ready for summer road trips by checking, maintaining, and being ready for whatever happens to your tires.
keywords: 6 Ways to Take Care of Tires in Summer
metaTitle: 6 Ways to Take Care of Tires in Summer
metaDescription: Be ready for summer road trips by checking, maintaining, and being ready for whatever happens to your tires.

pageElements.text: Before you head out on a road trip—and especially if it’s a driving vacation where you’ll be racking up serious mileage—you know you need to make sure your vehicle is in good shape. (You do know that, right?) And that starts with the tires. You don’t want to find yourself at the side of the road with a blowout in the middle of your trip. At the very least, if that does end up happening, you want to have planned so that you can take care of the problem with minimal hassle.
Here’s your six-point checklist of tire maintenance tasks to complete before you pack the cooler and the kids and head out this summer.

1. Rotate the tires.

No, this is not a sexy subject, but it’s critical. You should rotate your tires on a regular schedule so they’ll wear evenly, ride better, and last longer. Have this done about three times a year, or when your car goes in for an oil change. There are different recommendations for front-wheel-drive, rear-wheel-drive, and all-wheel-drive vehicles; check your owner’s manual for details.
If you really want to geek out like we do, Tire Rack has a service log form you can download to keep track of everything you do with up to three sets of tires.

2. Keep tabs on tire pressure.

If you care about fuel economy, you need to care about tire pressure. The federal government’s fuel economy website points out that you can improve your gas mileage as much as 3.3 percent just by keeping your tires properly inflated.
Underinflated tires are also more susceptible to damage, which can be even costlier.

Looking at them won’t tell you if your tires need air. About once a month, and definitely before leaving on a road trip, use a tire pressure gauge and make sure you have the right amount of air in your tires. The maximum pressure will be printed on the doorjamb of the driver’s door, and also on the front of the tire itself, near where the tire meets the wheel. Check tire pressure early in the day on cool tires; pressure will go up with heat, giving an inaccurate reading. Using a tire pressure gauge is easy; take the valve cap off each tire, place the gauge onto the stem, and press down until the tire stops hissing and you get a reading from the gauge, either on a bar or a digital screen. Make it a habit.

3. Manage the spare situation.

Many cars these days have either a small temporary spare or no spare tire. That’s a nod to the fact that tires are less likely to fail than they used to be; in fact, 85 percent of spare tires never get used at all. But....do you want to be out on an unfamiliar highway without a change of tire this summer? Probably not. Make sure you have at least a temporary spare on board, and get it checked to make sure it will work in a pinch. Even better, practice changing the tire so you know how. (And make your household’s teenage drivers do the same, if you have them.) If you have a temporary spare, read the directions. Usually you shouldn’t drive more than 50 mph and no more than 50 miles on it if you do have to use it. It’s really just to get you to a place where you can get a full-size tire put back on. For more about spare tires, check out our Jean Knows Cars video on the subject.

4. Replace your tires before they need replacing.

Get out a quarter and do a tread depth check. Put the quarter upside down inside several tread grooves in various places on the same tire. You have 4/32” of tread depth left if any of Washington’s head is covered by the tread. Any less than that, and it’s time to start tire shopping. By the time you get to 2/32”, you should definitely replace your tires.

5. Have emergency supplies on board.

Don’t succumb to the temptation to take emergency equipment out of the car to make room for your road-trip luggage. Have a working tire jack (one that you know how to use; see item 3 above). Have emergency flares and an orange triangle to use in case of a breakdown.

Another essential emergency item: a road service membership card. You can get a membership in your state’s AAA club road service for a nominal fee of around $50 per year, and that will entitle you to call an 800 number and get a tow truck to your vehicle to fix that flat for you, or tow you to a nearby service station to get it repaired. Even if you only need road service once, it more than pays for itself. State Farm and other providers also offer road service. Get yourself a card, or, if available for your vehicle, sign on for OnStar emergency services in the car.

6. Pack for preparedness.

If you’ve ever seen someone unloading absolutely all their belongings onto a rainy freeway ramp at midnight to get to their emergency supplies, you know you do not want to be that person. So don’t be. Make sure you keep emergency equipment in a duffel bag and pack that into your vehicle last.

Sunrise: Svedoliver/istock/Thinkstock

Tire Images: www.tirerack.com

title: 5 Things to Do with Google Maps
subTitle: Fly over the Pyramids, find the best traffic hours in Miami, make and share your vacation route!
promoTitle: 5 Things to Do with Google Maps
promoTeaserSmall: Fly over the Pyramids, find the best traffic hours in Miami, make and share your vacation route!
promoTeaser: Fly over the Pyramids, find the best traffic hours in Miami, make and share your vacation route!
keywords: 5 Things to Do with Google Maps
metaTitle: 5 Great Things to Do with Google Maps - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Fly over the Pyramids, find the best traffic hours in Miami, make and share your vacation route! Plus more.

pageElements.text: Are you a Google Maps fan? Really, who isn't these days, even though there is a slight downside to this brilliant technology: It can take practice to find and figure out the many icons and choices. It can feel like playing a video game sometimes, clicking on a mysterious arrow or icon to see what wonders might open up. If you are planning a road trip, though, or just idly dreaming of future destinations, there is much to find in Google Maps that goes far beyond directions from Point A to Point B. Here are five of our favorites.

1. Make Your Own Map and Share It

Google's My Maps lets you design your own route, name it, notate it, and even place destination markers in the colors of your choice. Then you can share the map the same way you share a documents in your Google Drive, or send a link. Here's an example of a pretty straightforward route. Once you've named and saved it ("Laura's Quebec Trip"), you can repeatedly go back and stalk your own vacation, zooming in to find points or interest or changing the drive route as much as you want before it's time to go. A handy ruler tool in the toolbar lets you measure distances quickly by clicking and dragging from one point to another.

There's a lot more you can do, like add layers with different sets of directions, places to visit, or side trips; import spreadsheets and files; and change the design and color scheme. Details are here.

2. Go Back in Time

The time machine feature lets you see a destination in Google Street View as it appeared as far back as 2007. Not too exciting so far, but imagine the possibilities as the years go by. First, go to Google Street View. You do that by finding the little yellow icon of a person at bottom right of your screen, then dragging it over to the place you want to see up close. Now that you are viewing the location in Street View, look at the top left corner of the screen; if you see a clock face icon, click on it to see images from past Street View image sweeps of the location. It's fun to see how a neighborhood or cityscape has changed in just a few years, or how it looks at different seasons. Imagine the time-lapse view you can get of various world locations, such as the reconstruction of the World Trade Center. Or look at Street View history of your own house, if available; there are three views of mine, showing a change of seasons and different cars parked in front.

3. Get Real-Time and Predictive Traffic Information

At top left on your Google Maps screen, click on the small map icon to the left of the words "Getting Around." It will open traffic information that shows up on the map: green lines on your route for currently fast-moving traffic, or red lines for currently slow or bottlenecked areas of your route.

And it gets better. You can also choose "Typical Traffic" for a day of the week and time of the day. Wondering just how terrible your trip will be if you are in the middle of a city at 5 p.m. on a Monday? This will predict it for you.

4. Zoom Around inside a Building or Landmark

Not only is there Street View for the outsides of buildings; Google also has Indoor Maps that show you around landmarks and tourist attractions, including this view of Madison Square Garden. At bottom right of your screen, there's a level-switch icon that takes you upstairs or back downstairs. Check out Google's global list of Indoor Map sites.

5. Take a Virtual Trek

Great photographers and adventurers are sharing their fabulous journeys with Google Maps. From an up-close view of Tanzania where Jane Goodall's institute is studying chimpanzees to the vertiginous landscape of Nepal, home of the Sherpas, you haven't lived (online at least) until you've taken a look at this breathtaking use of Google Earth.

images.caption: My Maps feature lets you design and share your travel plans and dreams.
Time machine function at top left shows previous Street View images. Fascinating!
Look inside venues like Madison Square Garden, level by level.
Find out what roads are clogged and see typical road use at your chosen  time and day.
Google facilitates breathtaking images of the world's wildest and most beautiful spots.

subTitle: Sartorially elegant, stalwart sedan.
promoTeaserSmall: Sartorially elegant, stalwart sedan.
promoTeaser: Sartorially elegant, stalwart sedan.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive sedan or hatchback
Price range: $50,700–$93,850 (includes destination)
Trim levels: 528i, 535i, 535d, 550i, ActiveHybrid 5, M5
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower; turbocharged 3.0-liter six-cylinder, 300 horsepower; turbo-diesel 3.0-liter six-cylinder, 255 horsepower; turbocharged 3.0-liter six-cylinder/electric hybrid, 335 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 4.4-liter V-8, 445 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 4.4-liter V-8, 560 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual, eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 528i: 23 mpg city/34 mpg highway; 528i xDrive: 22/33 mpg; 535i: 20/30 mpg; 550i: 17/25 mpg; 535i xDrive: 20/29 mpg; 550i xDrive: 16/24 mpg; ActiveHybrid 5: 23/30 mpg; 535d: 26/38 mpg; 535d xDrive: 26/37 mpg; M5 manual: 15/22 mpg; M5 automatic: 14/20 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Small overlap front: Moderate; Moderate overlap front, Side, Roof strength: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Navigation
Notable standard features on this model: Moonroof, three-year subscriptions to the BMW Online, BMW Apps, and Advanced Real Time Traffic, automatic side mirror tilting, ten-way memory seats with lumbar support
Notable options on this model: Heated front and rear seats and steering wheel, rearview camera, head-up display, side and top view cameras, active blind-spot warning system, night vision with pedestrian detection
You might also be considering: Audi A6, Infiniti Q70, Mercedes-Benz E-Class

The BMW 5 Series is the 3 Series all grown up: bigger, roomier, faster, and better equipped, as well as with a higher price. Like the 3 Series, you can get it almost any way you want it, except instead of a wagon, you have a Gran Turismo model with an elongated body and a hands-free hatch door that increases the trunk cargo capacity. Old-school driving enthusiasts will appreciate that this mid-size sedan is still available with a six-speed manual—on the M5 only—as well as an eight-speed automatic transmission, and there are nearly as many engine options as body styles, including a recently added diesel, an updated V-8, and a hybrid. As you would expect from a sophisticated performance sedan, the list of standard features is extensive, including the iDrive infotainment system with voice-activated functions, navigation, a high-resolution display, and a three-year subscription to BMW Online, BMW Apps, and Advanced Real Time Traffic. On the downside, most of the safety technology, like the crash avoidance systems, adaptive cruise control, night vision with pedestrian detection, and head-up display, are options that add thousands to the already steep base price.

New for 2015

Expanded standard features, changes to optional packages and interior trim materials.

title: 2015 BMW 6 Series
subTitle: The winner’s coupe.
promoTeaserSmall: The winner’s coupe.
promoTeaser: The winner’s coupe.
metaKeywords: 2015 BMW 6-series; BMW; coupe; convertible; Gran Coupe; M6; Alpina B6; hatchback; German
metaDescription: The winner’s coupe. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Four- or five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive coupe, convertible, or four-door hatchback
Price range: $77,050–$121,200 (includes destination)
Trim levels: 640i, 650i, M6, Alpina B6
Engines: Turbocharged 3.0-liter six-cylinder, 315 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 4.4-liter V-8, 445/540/560 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 640i: 20–21 mpg city/31–32 mpg highway; 640i xDrive: 20/29 mpg; 650i: 17/25 mpg; 650i xDrive: 16/24–25 mpg; Alpina B6: 16/24 mpg; M6 manual: 15/22 mpg; M6 automatic: 14/20 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not rated; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: iDrive infotainment system
Notable standard features on this model: Automatic stop/start, ten-way power-adjustable driver's and front passenger's seat with 4-way lumbar support, heated seats, adaptive LED headlights
Notable options on this model: Active front seats, smartphone integration, night vision with pedestrian detection, parking assist, heated steering wheel
You might also be considering: Audi A7, Infiniti Q50, Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class

Based on the legendary 5 Series sedan is the more stylish and low-slung 6 Series. Available as a coupe, convertible, and four-door Gran Coupe, the recently refreshed 6 Series received a refresh for 2015. It would take an expert to notice the slight changes to the exterior and interior cockpit, but it retains the sleek athleticism of a coupe that sends the message that this is indeed a driver’s car and not the family sedan. Unchanged in this model is the standard 315-horsepower, twin-turbo 3.0-liter six-cylinder engine mated to an eight-speed automatic transmission. Step up to the 650i, and you get the 4.4-liter twin-turbo V-8 with its generous 445 horsepower and 480 pound-feet of torque to play with. BMW’s all-wheel drive, called xDrive, is an option on all 6 Series models, but the only way to get the manual transmission is to pony up for the M6 with its 560 horsepower, twin-turbo V-8 that’s available in both coupe and convertible form.

New for 2015

Mildly revised interior and exterior, new paint colors, Dynamic Digital Instrument Cluster becomes standard, navigation now includes an iDrive touchpad controller, M Sport Exhaust becomes standard equipment on the 650i and 650i xDrive models, and launch control has been added to the standard sport automatic transmission. The Alpina B6 Gran Coupe is all new for 2015.
