Notable options on this model: Heated seats, heated steering wheel, navigation
You might also be considering: Audi TT, Mercedes-Benz SL-Class, Nissan 370Z, Porsche Boxster

The elongated hood, muscular lines and low, athletic stance are the hallmarks of the 2015 BMW Z4. The engine options for this roadster include a 240-horsepower, 2.0-liter in-line four-cylinder engine and a 300-horsepower, 3.0-liter in-line-six, turbo and twin-turbo, respectively. The sDrive35is gets a 35-horsepower bump from the twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter engine. There are also three transmissions: a six-speed manual, an eight-speed automatic, and a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic. The manual is only available on the base, rear-wheel-drive 28i while the seven-speed dual-clutch automatic is the sole transmission option on the 35i and 35is. This two-seater features a retractable hard top that stows in nineteen seconds at speeds of up to 25 mph, making it the perfect curve hugger in any climate.

New for 2015

Minor package and upholstery changes, one new exterior paint color, the sport leather steering wheel with paddle shifters is now standard on the 35i, and the 35i model is no longer available with a manual transmission.

title: Subaru Backs Dog Crate Crash Tests
subTitle: Dog-friendly carmaker and Center for Pet Safety want to make your car a safer place for your pet.
promoTitle: Subaru Backs Dog Crate Crash Tests
promoTeaserSmall: Dog-friendly carmaker and Center for Pet Safety want to make your car a safer place for your pet.
promoTeaser: Dog-friendly carmaker and Center for Pet Safety want to make your car a safer place for your pet.
keywords: Subaru Backs Dog Crate Crash Tests
metaTitle: Subaru Backs Dog Crate Crash Tests - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Dog-friendly carmaker and Center for Pet Safety want to make your car a safer place for your pet.

pageElements.text: If you’ve seen Subaru's dog-themed commercials, you know that the company loves our pets almost as much as we do. This summer, Subaru is continuing its partnership with the nonprofit Center for Pet Safety to do safety testing on equipment you use with your pet in the car. This time, the project is to crash test pet crates and carriers. In 2013, the Center for Pet Safety tested pet harnesses, and after finding surprising flaws with some products, they established official safety standards and compiled a list of certified harnesses. Now Subaru and the Center for Pet Safety aim to do the same with crates.

While I was happy to hear about Subaru’s new efforts to protect pets, I also felt something else: guilt. I realized I have not given my dog’s safety in the car the proper attention. After watching the crash test videos and seeing the statistics on vehicle crashes caused by unrestrained animals, I’m convinced I need to be more careful.

Here is an example of my (previous) bad behavior. On some evenings I crave ice cream, and what’s a girl to do other than load her eight-year-old black Lab into the back seat of her car and head to the nearest Baskin-Robbins? My dog, Clem, immediately thrusts his head out the open window and lets his big pink tongue hang out while the wind pushes his floppy ears back. When we arrive at the drive-through, I order and pull forward to greet the friendly cashier, who happens to have a soft spot for Clem. Okay, maybe he loves all dogs, but I prefer to think Clem is special. The cashier hands me my strawberry ice cream and, because, the Baskin-Robbins is connected to a Dunkin' Donuts, he also feeds a leftover doughnut hole to Clem. At this point, my dog has half his body out of the car window. We love this ritual and drive away happy as clams, but I haven't really thought about any safety implications for my pup. Heck, if I had a dime for every time Clem or our other six-month-old black Lab, Brick, jumped into my lap, crawled over a seat, or unknowingly tried to climb out the window while I was driving, I’d be a wealthy woman.

I Thought My Dog Crate Was Crash Tested?

Pet crate manufacturers have increasingly labeled their products as “crash tested,” but what does that really mean? According to Lindsey Wolko, founder and CEO of the Center for Pet Safety, it doesn’t mean much. “Just because a product has been crash tested, without a formal test protocol and ratings guidelines, there is nothing to use to measure a ‘pass,’” Wolko says. “It’s simply more market hype.” The fact is that pet safety equipment has not been tested using rigorous safety standards, and that's exactly what this Subaru/Center for Pet Safety effort is trying to change.
“We want to make pet parents aware of safety measures they can take to help protect their pets,” says Subaru's Michael McHale. Test results are expected in late summer.

Through studying and testing a variety of carriers and crates in crash scenarios, the two groups hope to establish performance standards for similar pet safety products. “We want to make pet parents aware of proper safety measures they can take to help protect their pets,” says Michael McHale, Subaru’s director of corporate communications. Test results can be expected late this summer.

Why Subaru Cares, and Why You Should, Too

With all seven of its 2015 models earning Top Safety Pick or Top Safety Pick Plus ratings from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, Subaru clearly makes safety a priority. However, more than 69 percent of Subaru drivers own at least one dog, so protecting pups in the car is also of the utmost importance to the company. Ad campaigns like “Dog tested, dog approved” and “Once you sit in a Subaru, you’ll stay” give away Subaru’s fondness for our furriest family members.

So it makes sense that Subaru would want to participate in this study, but is it worth your attention? According to Subaru, 56 percent of American pet owners, myself included, travel with their pets, and 20 percent do so with a pet in their lap. Paws to Click, an organization that promotes safer pet travel, says up to 98 percent of dogs travel unrestrained in cars, and there are 30,000 driving accidents per year as a result.

During Subaru’s 2013 study with the Center for Pet Safety, pet harnesses were put to the test, revealing some critical flaws. Many of the products’ failures could prove dangerous to you and your four-legged friend, meaning even if you do take steps to secure your pet, safety is not guaranteed. Thanks to the study, though, dog lovers have access to a more reliable source of safety advice. “Pet owners can now look to the CPS website and identify the top-performing products on the market,” says Wolko.

Awareness of pet safety in the vehicle does not mean the end of all fun when it comes to traveling with pets. Clem can still enjoy his doughnut hole from inside a crate or with a harness securely holding him in place, and that's what we'll be doing from now on.
Image at top: Ingram Publishing/Thinkstock

title: Ford Pro Trailer Backup Assist
subTitle: The 2016 Ford F-150 gets this fabulous thing. I tried it.
promoTeaserSmall: The 2016 Ford F-150 gets this fabulous thing. I tried it.
promoTeaser: The 2016 Ford F-150 gets this fabulous thing. I tried it.
metaTitle: Ford Pro Trailer Backup Assist - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The 2016 Ford F-150 gets this fabulous thing. I tried it.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I looked at a lot of new technologies during Ford's Further with Ford event in Palo Alto, California, this week, and what I liked about most of them is that they solve a problem and help the driver. One of the most miraculous was Ford's Pro Trailer Backup Assist, which will be an option for the 2016 Ford F-150 pickup that goes on sale near the end of the year.

If you’ve ever done it, or even watched someone else do it, you know that backing up a trailer is like trying to tie a bow tie while looking in a mirror. It’s not a natural or intuitive thing. You have to constantly countersteer the vehicle you're driving to maneuver the trailer into place. And you frequently look like a moron while you're trying.

The most embarrassing thing for a girl like me to do is to pull up to a boat ramp and not be able to back the trailer up, and have to give up and let my husband do it. I can only imagine how much worse it is for a man not to be able to back that trailer down a boat ramp. Everybody's seen it happen.

If you don't get it right (always when there are lots of people watching you, of course), the trailer suddenly locks up, and it's at a complete 90-degree angle to the vehicle you're driving, and you can't go backward anymore. Then you have to pull out and try again, pull out and try again. It’s just embarrassing. I have seen both men and women have this problem. And that’s what makes Ford’s new trailer assist so brilliant.

How It Works

Pro Trailer Backup Assist works very similarly to active park assist, also available on many Fords. And, even more than the park assist, it is a miracle.

There is a knob on the dash, to the right of the steering wheel, that you operate to steer the trailer. Your hands are off the steering wheel when it happens. It's awesome. You use the rearview camera and the mirrors to help. You steer the trailer, and the car reads those directions and countersteers itself.

You only control the gas and the brakes, while the truck steers itself and puts the trailer exactly where you want it to go. To get the trailer to move to the right, you turn the knob right, or clockwise. To get it to turn to the left, you turn it to the left, or counterclockwise. Simple, right? It only took me a minute to figure it out. Then I wanted to cry, I was so happy.

<iframe src="https://media.ford.com/content/fordmedia/fna/us/en/asset.embedded.html/content/dam/fordmedia/North America/US/2015/05/21/F150-Trailer-Backup-Final.mp4.html" height="340" width="500" ></iframe>

My co-tester was a woman under five feet tall. She didn’t want to try the Pro Trailer Backup Assist for herself, but I told her she had to. Well, she got into that big F-150 and backed that sucker up in one move. I said, “Now, aren’t you glad?”

The last time a manufacturer introduced a feature to help park or move large trucks was when General Motors introduced its four-wheel assist, called Quadrasteer, in the early 2000s. Being the owner of three full-size pickups, I absolutely loved it, but the price was so high that virtually no one bought it, and eventually they dropped it.

The key to the popularity of this as an option for Ford will depend heavily on the price. How many people who regularly tow trailers or boats really can't manage the trailer and will pay whatever it costs for their truck to manage the trailer for them? Ford spokesman Mike Levine told us it will be an option for every F-150 model (XL, XLT, Lariat, King Ranch, and Platinum), as an added-cost option for F-150s equipped with the Trailer Tow package. Pricing won't be announced until later this summer. The Trailer Tow package costs $695 on the 2015 F-150.

In my mind, this cool feature is for someone who has an occasional need to tow a trailer or a boat or a mobile home and feels uncomfortable with the somewhat complicated task of backing up a large vehicle that is attached to another large vehicle.  I don't imagine any Bass Pro Tour fishermen feeling they need to buy it, but for the rest of us, this is brilliant.

<iframe src="https://www.hashdoc.com/documents/47529/embed" width="728" height="600" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no" style="border:1px solid #EAE9EA; border-width:1px; margin-bottom:5px; max-width: 100%;"></iframe>

title: 5 Rental-Car Insurance Tips
subTitle: What your credit card and your own car insurance can and can't do to help you at the rental counter.
promoTeaserSmall: What your credit card and your own car insurance can and can't do to help you at the rental counter.
promoTeaser: What your credit card and your own car insurance can and can't do to help you at the rental counter.
metaDescription: What your credit card and your own car insurance can and can't do to help you at the rental counter.

pageElements.text: If you have ever rented a car, you’ve most likely used a credit card to pay for it. You may even have been aware that the card will help you in the event you get into an accident that requires an insurance claim. But you know how confusing choosing insurance can be. Who covers what? Is the card enough, or should you pay the pricey extra daily fees to buy the rental agency’s “damage waiver”?
Here are five things to understand about coverage before you make what could be a costly mistake at the rental counter.

1. Check with your credit card providers ahead of time.

In a recent study, credit card specialist CardHub analyzed the car rental insurance provided by the four major credit card networks: American Express, Visa, Discover, and MasterCard. The good news: all four provide some kind of insurance, usually secondary to your personal car insurance policy. AmEx got a 90 percent overall score as an insurance source from CardHub, while Visa came in last at 74 percent. MasterCard was the only company that did not extend rental insurance on every card it issues. On any card, check with your specific issuer to make sure you know what you can expect.

2. Make the right decisions when you rent.

To be covered by your credit card, you first have to decline the “collision damage waiver,” or insurance policy, offered at the rental counter. You also have to charge the entire rental on the card. Most cards have some stipulations regarding what they will pay for based on where and what you drive. None of the networks offers coverage for trucks, sports cars, or large vans, and three out of four will not cover vehicles priced over $50,000. There are other rules, like Visa’s regulation that excludes accidents that happen on dirt or gravel roads, and AmEx’s refusal to cover big SUVs like the Ford Expedition and the Toyota Land Cruiser.

3. Know what is meant by “covered damages.”

Tire or rim damage or destruction? It’s covered by American Express, MasterCard, and Discover, but not by Visa. If you need your rental card towed, all four card companies will cover that, although you should check with your card issuer to find out about distance limitations. Loss of use and the deductible on your own insurance policy are covered by every company except Discover. American Express offers a “premium” level of coverage, for damages up to $50,000 or $75,000, depending on which card you have, for a small added fee.

4. Check your own insurance policy.

Find out what your personal car insurance policy covers for rental cars. If you have liability and personal injury protection on your own policy, it should extend to your rental as well. Insurer GEICO advises that a homeowner’s or renter’s insurance policy that covers personal effects should also cover personal items that are stolen from a rental car. Before you go to the rental counter, make sure you have had that conversation with your own insurance agent.

5. Understand what purchasing insurance from the rental company will do for you.

It’s not always an automatic “no.” If you’re traveling abroad or don’t like the coverage offered from your credit card provider or insurance policy, you may want to consider paying for the collision damage waiver from the rental company for peace of mind. You might find it difficult, as we did, to get a clear picture of the cost by searching rental company websites. To get exact numbers for the rental you are about to sign up for, you should expect to ask for it directly from the rental agency when you sign the rental contract. All the more reason to know what other options you have ahead of time.

title: 8 Apps to Road-Trip Like a Boss
subTitle: Just about all you need is a smartphone, and you're ready for whatever happens out there.
promoTitle: 8 Apps to Road-Trip Like a Boss
promoTeaserSmall: Just about all you need is a smartphone, and you're ready for whatever happens out there.
promoTeaser: Just about all you need is a smartphone, and you're ready for whatever happens out there.
keywords: 8 Apps to Road-Trip Like a Boss
metaTitle: 8 Apps to Road-Trip Like a Boss - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Just about all you need is a smartphone, and you're ready for whatever happens out there.

pageElements.text: One of the best things about the modern road trip is how much you can do with your smartphone or tablet to make it go more smoothly. All it takes is a few quick downloads from your App Store or Google Play account, and off you go. We’ve chosen eight practical apps that will help make a road trip work for you. While some are well known, there are a few new or unusual apps on this list.

Using them, you can hit the open road, confident that you’ll be able to find a restaurant, hotel, swimming hole, and cheap fuel all along the way. All but one are free of charge, which is even better.

1. Urgent.ly

Available for: iOS 7.0 or later
Android

PRO: This is a kind of Uber for road service, especially a good idea for those in major metropolitan areas.. If you aren’t a person who already has any kind of road service membership (AAA or similar), this could be a lifesaver. This app will get someone to help you with a dead battery, lockout, or empty gas tank, and let your smartphone show you the progress of your savior service vehicle as it makes its way to you, for prices starting at $75.

Bonus for parents: if your teen or college student gets in a jam, he or she can use the app, and the FamilyView feature will alert you, get road service to your kid, and charge your credit card. Then you can observe the rescue from your phone and get a confirmation that service is complete.

CON: Of course, you can also get your kid an Associate Membership through AAA. AAA memberships vary by region, but a basic road service membership is generally under $70 per year, and an associate membership tends to be around an additional $15 per year, with some special promotions available. Check those prices before you download the app.

Click here to find out where service is available.

2. Dark Sky

Available for:
iOS 7.0 or later

PRO: This app leverages the newest iPhone’s barometer function to crowd-source accurate weather information. It’s kind of addictive to open it and get an instant forecast for your exact location, right down to whether rain will be light or heavy and when it will start and end. More traditional forecasts for the coming seven days are also on there, as are weather maps, and you can sign up for instant text alerts about weather problems or daily summaries at 7 a.m. You can also look up weather elsewhere and click on recommendations for things like “interesting storm in Battle Creek, Iowa.”

Most fun of all, you can report your take on the current weather to help improve accuracy for others. On a road trip, this is a fine way to get a read on what the weather is going to do where you are—and of course where you’re headed.

CON: So far, this app is only for Apple products (iPhone and iPad), not Android. It’s also not free, but the $3.99 price is justified on entertainment value alone or if you are any kind of weather buff.

3. GasBuddy

Available for:
iOS 6.0 or later
Android
Windows Phone
BlackBerry

PRO: This is one of the all-time favorite apps drivers use in the car. There’s practically unlimited information about fuel prices, where the gas stations are, and what kind of fuel you can get for what price. You can sort by regular, midgrade, premium, and—brilliant for those who are always looking for a place to buy it—diesel fuel. Plus, you can get this for the dinosaur phone systems, Windows Phone and BlackBerry.

CON: Not the prettiest, cleanest, or most modern interface for your phone; you’ll be wading through extraneous stuff. It has a bit of a carnival/cheap video-game feeling to it, with mixed-in ads and persistent giveaway offers for $100 of free gasoline. There’s a Leaderboard and Challenges where you win points if you report prices wherever you go. If you want to feel festive while you look for gas, this messy app will work for you.

4. Gas Guru

Available for:
iOS 7.0 or later
Android

PRO: Developed by the Yellow Pages people, Gas Guru has been freshly updated for the Apple iOS format, with clean lines and attractive, high-quality graphics. This app will find you the best gas prices wherever you travel, color coded from highest to lowest, in map or list form. It’s basic, simple, and gives you a lot of station choices. You can also search for diesel as well as regular, midgrade, and premium gasoline.

CON: Unlike the more interactive Gas Buddy, you can’t give your own direct commentary about gas prices you’ve found. Then again, this one is very simple to use, a good tradeoff.

5. iExit

Available for:
iOS 6.0 or later
Android

PRO: This app helps you figure out when you’ll next come to a Bob Evans, a veterinarian, a grocery store, or a rest area. It will show you up to 100 exits ahead of you on your route and let you search for deals and promotions on hotels and restaurants—and will let you choose and save your favorites so you don’t miss any Waffle Houses on the horizon. You can plan ahead by searching a highway you’re not currently on. It’s also free, while a competitor, The Next Exit, charges a $14.95 annual subscription fee.

CON: With construction being what it is, it’s hard to keep up with what you might find as you drive America’s highways. Although we didn’t try this app on an extended road trip, and although it was just updated in March, an app with this much information puts you at the risk that some of it might become outdated quickly. So use this not as gospel, but to supplement your eyes and ears—and your vehicle’s navigation system.

6. Waterkeeper Swim Guide

Available for:
iOS 5.0 or later
Android

PRO: If you’re headed for some of the world’s finest beaches and water areas, this is a good dreaming, planning, and navigating guide. It offers information for beaches from Goose Bay, Newfoundland, to Cabo San Lucas, Baja California, along with historical and visitor information. You can click on an “I’m Here” box to post your location on social media. The very best feature is “Current Status,” which tells you whether the water is rated safe for swimming. Information we checked out for the beaches near us had been updated within the past few hours.
CON: Every beach, everywhere, is not on the app, so this should not be your sole guide to places for swimming or boating. Check out your destination before you go to make sure it’s included.

7. Kayak

Available for:
iOS 7.1 or later
Android

PRO: There are many apps to find a hotel or a flight, but this one has been our longtime pick for a clean interface and a comprehensive set of results. You can track a flight, get price alerts, and find hotels, flights, and rental cars just about anywhere. Best of all, you can compare a huge number of choices easily.

CON: If you want a simple app, this isn’t it. This is an app for shopping only. You are routed over to complete a booking through another source such as Priceline.com, Booking.com, Hotels.com, and Hotwire.com. If you have a favorite among those, you might want to start there instead.

8. Hotels.com

Available for:
iOS 7.0 or later
Android
Windows Phone
Amazon Kindle Fire

PRO: Among the many choices for booking a hotel, we’ve found this one is straightforward and easy to use. You can set up your account and credit card details (or PayPal) and book easily from your phone, even for same-day bookings. The app, compared with the website, claims to offer “Your Secret Price” deals. You can also accumulate rewards points for repeated stays using the app. Unlike some other hotel apps with limited selections, this one will give you a true variety of choices from el cheapo to high luxury. It also can be downloaded to a Kindle Fire as well as for Windows Phone.
CON: If you want to find anything besides lodging, this app doesn’t have it; the name says it all.

images.caption: Dark Sky app gives you instant weather for your location or elsewhere.
The world weather globe is the prettiest part of Dark Sky app.
Gas Guru app helps you find good gas prices.
Gas Guru app is freshly updated.
iExit app lets you find a plethora of services along your route.
iExit app finds fuel stops for you.
iExit app lets you find special deals in the area you're traveling to or through.
Kayak travel app has car rental, flight, and hotel comparison search.
Kayak travel app will send you to your choice of travel websites for the actual booking.
Hotels.com is an easy-to-use app for lodging.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz C-Class
subTitle: The car that gets everything right is all new for 2015.
promoTeaserSmall: The car that gets everything right is all new for 2015.
promoTeaser: The car that gets everything right is all new for 2015.
metaKeywords: 2015 Mercedes-Benz C-class; Mercedes-Benz; Mercedes; sedan; coupe; German
metaDescription: The car that gets everything right is all new for 2015.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four- or five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive sedan or coupe
Price range: $39,325–$72,825 (includes destination charge)
Trim levels: C250, C300, C350, C400, C63 AMG, C63 S AMG
Engines: Turbocharged 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 201 horsepower; turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 241 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6, 302 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 4.0-liter V-8, 469/503 horsepower; 6.3-liter V-8, 451 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: C250 Coupe: 22 mpg city/31 mpg highway; C350 Coupe RWD/AWD: 20/28 mpg; C63 AMG Coupe: 13/19 mpg; C300 Sedan RWD: 25/34 mpg; C300 Sedan AWD: 24/31 mpg; C400 Sedan: 21/29 mpg; C63/C63 S AMG Sedan: 18/25 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Collision prevention system
Notable standard features on this model: Push-button start; 7.0-inch display; multifunction steering wheel
Notable options on this model: Air suspension; active blind spot assist; active lane-keeping assist; panoramic sunroof
You might also be considering: BMW 3 Series, Audi A4, Lexus IS, Cadillac ATS

The 2015 Mercedes-Benz C-Class is the bread-and-butter vehicle for the luxury German automaker, and for good reason: it gets everything right. Longer and wider—yet 200 pounds lighter—than the previous generation, the compact sedan grew a bit for 2015 to keep up with market trends and its customers’ growing proportions. It’s available in a coupe or sedan and with a range of engine options, from a relatively efficient 201-horsepower, turbo 1.8-liter 4-cylinder to the 503-horsepower, twin-turbo 4.0-liter in the range-topping C63 S AMG. There is little to complain about with the interior, except perhaps the Comand infotainment system, which is an acquired taste and thankfully optional on some models. But if you want the advanced features like Wi-Fi hotspot and head-up display, you’ll have to learn to love it.

New for 2015

The C-Class is all-new for 2015.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz CLA-Class
subTitle: Your starter Mercedes?
promoTeaserSmall: Your starter Mercedes?
promoTeaser: Your starter Mercedes?
metaKeywords: 2015 Mercedes-Benz CLA-class; Mercedes-Benz; Mercedes; sedan; German
metaDescription: Your starter Mercedes?

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel drive sedan
Price range: $32,425–$49,425 (includes destination)
Trim levels: CLA250, CLA45
Engines: 2.0-liter 4-cylinder, 208 horsepower; 2.0-liter 4-cylinder, 355 horsepower
Transmission: 7-speed automatic
Fuel economy: CLA250 RWD: 26 mpg city/38 mpg highway; CLA250 AWD: 24/33 mpg; CLA45: 23/31 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Bluetooth audio
Notable standard features on this model: Keyless entry, twelve-way memory seats, collision-prevention system, rain-sensing wipers
Notable options on this model: Park assist, blind spot warning, lane-keeping assist, panoramic sunroof, 18-inch wheels, performance suspension, illuminated grille badge
You might also be considering: Acura ILX, Audi A3, Volkswagen CC

The CLA-Class is the entry-level Mercedes and, as such, is designed to appeal to younger buyers. The base model, the CLA250, is equipped with front-wheel drive—all-wheel drive is optional—and a 2.0-liter four-cylinder that produces 208 horsepower. Price-wise, it may be the most accessible of the Mercedes lineup, but it has a long list of standard features including a 12-way power-adjustable driver’s seat, a seven-inch LCD display, ambient lighting, Bluetooth audio streaming and mobile phone integration. Also standard on this bargain Benz is the advanced Collision Prevention system—typically an expensive option—that applies the brakes to avoid an impending crash with another car and the drowsy-driving detecting Attention Assist system. Rounding out the semi-autonomous vehicle technology is the optional parking assist system that uses sensors to help you parallel or perpendicular park, which is notable since these advanced features are rarely an option in entry-level vehicles. That said, most creature comforts you’ve come to expect are optional, including heated seats, navigation, and voice-activation. And while the standard MBrace integrates your mobile phone with your car’s infotainment system, getting any of the approved apps to appear in the LCD or integrate with the system controls requires you to pony up for a monthly subscription, which is easy to pass on since you shouldn’t be playing with your phone that much anyway. Another interesting option: an in-dash DVD/CD player that allows you to watch DVDs while the car is in park. As with any low-slung coupe (four-doors or otherwise), you don’t buy it for its rear seat. But the inclusion of two cupholders in the fold-down center armrest is a nice touch of comfort for the back-seat passengers whose heads are likely butting up against the sloping roofline.

New for 2015

New steering wheel design and changes to package features.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz E-Class
subTitle: A wide range of body styles and power choices in a car that is the heart of the Mercedes lineup.
promoTeaserSmall: A wide range of body styles and power choices in a car that is the heart of the Mercedes lineup.
promoTeaser: A wide range of body styles and power choices in a car that is the heart of the Mercedes lineup.
metaKeywords: 2015 Mercedes-Benz E-class; Mercedes-Benz; Mercedes; sedan; wagon; coupe; convertible; hybrid; diesel; German
metaDescription: A wide range of body styles and power choices in a car that is the heart of the Mercedes lineup.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four- or five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive sedan, coupe, convertible, or wagon
Price range: $52,725–$104,125 (includes destination)
Trim levels: E250 Bluetec, E350, E400, E400 Hybrid, E63 AMG, E63 S AMG
Engines: Turbocharged diesel 2.1-liter 4-cylinder, 195 horsepower; 3.0-liter V-6, 329 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6/electric hybrid, 302 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 4.7-liter V-8, 402 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 5.5-liter V-8, 577 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: E250 RWD: 28 mpg city/42 mpg highway; E250 AWD: 27/38 mpg; E350 RWD: 20/29 mpg; E350 AWD: 20/28 mpg; E350 Coupe RWD/AWD: 20/28 mpg; E350 Convertible: 19/28 mpg: E350 Wagon: 20/27 mpg; E400 Hybrid: 24/30 mpg; E400 Sedan RWD: 20/29 mpg; E400 Sedan AWD: 20/28 mpg; E400 Wagon: 19/27 mpg; E550 Coupe: 18/26 mpg; E550 Convertible: 17/26 mpg; E63 AMG: 16/23 mpg; E63 S AMG: 15/22 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Power tilt/sliding sunroof
Notable standard features on this model: Comand infotainment system, steering wheel mounted shift paddles, sport-tuned suspension, 14-way power adjustable front seats, rain-sensing wipers
Notable options on this model: Keyless entry, push-button start, rearview camera, panoramic sunroof, brushed aluminum pedals
You might also be considering: Audi A6, BMW 5 Series, Lexus GS350

The 2015 Mercedes-Benz E-Class is the jack-of-all-trades platform for the luxury German manufacturer. It’s available any way you like it—coupe, sedan, convertible, or wagon—and with a range of engine options, including a fuel-sipping 2.1-liter diesel. It even offers an uber-sporty 577-horsepower AMG-series wagon as a no-compromise family hauler. This mid-size car is handsomely equipped and receives many safety and technology features, such as the terse Comand infotainment platform, cross-traffic alerts, and an active collision prevision system as standard. However, creature comforts that have become almost expected, such as massaging heated and ventilated seats, remain pricey options. With 41.3 inches of legroom in the front and 35.8 inches in the rear, the cabin of the sedan is roomy, but not overly spacious. The 12.9 cubic feet of cargo capacity will amply serve most of your shopping needs, and if you require more space for your gear, you can opt for the wagon, which also offers the option of two additional rear-facing jump seats for occasional pint-sized passengers.

New for 2015

The E-Class was comprehensively revised for 2014, so changes to the 2015 lineup are minor.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz GL-Class
subTitle: Utility can be fabulous.
promoTeaserSmall: Utility can be fabulous.
promoTeaser: Utility can be fabulous.
metaKeywords: 2015 Mercedes-Benz GL-class; Mercedes-Benz; Mercedes; SUV; sport-utility; German
metaDescription: Utility can be fabulous.

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-passenger, all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Price range: $64,525–$120,375 (includes destination)
Trim levels: GL350 BlueTec, GL450, GL550, GL63 AMG
Engines: Turbo-diesel 3.0-liter V-6, 240 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6, 362 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 4.7-liter gasoline V-8, 429 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 5.5-liter V-8, 550 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: GL350 BlueTEC: 19 mpg city/26 mpg highway; GL450: 17/21 mpg; GL550: 13/18 mpg; GL63 AMG: 13/17 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Air-spring suspension
Notable standard features on this model: Power folding third-row seats, power tilt/sliding sunroof, rain-sensing wipers, crosswind stabilization system, 19-inch wheels
Notable options on this model: Active curve headlamps, on/off-road package, active parking assist, active lane-keeping assist, surround-view camera, panoramic sunroof, trailer hitch
You might also be considering: Audi Q7, Cadillac Escalade, Infiniti QX56

The 2015 Mercedes-Benz GL-Class is proof that utilitarian can also be luxurious. It’s available in a range of engine options to suit your lifestyle, including a relatively economical 240-horsepower, 455 lb-ft turbo-diesel V-6, to a hand built 5.5-liter twin-turbo V-8 that produces 550 horsepower and 560 lb-ft of torque. Most buyers will probably opt for the more conventional twin-turbo V-6 or 4.7-liter V-8 that occupy the middle of the engine range. Regardless of which engine you choose, there will be plenty of power and torque to haul your family, its gear, and a sporting craft to any reasonable destination. The interior and cargo area are generous as well. It has three rows of seats and can seat up to seven. Legroom is mercifully spacious in every row of this luxury liner, with 40.3-, 38.5-, and 35.0-inches in the front, second, and third rows, respectively. Cargo capacity isn’t lacking despite its three-row configuration with 16 cubic feet of storage with all three rows in use and 49.4 cubic feet with the third row folded flat: plenty of room to tote around that double wide jogging stroller and the dog. True to its luxury brand, it’s well equipped with many standard creature comforts and safety features, such as heated front seats, the Comand infotainment system, a power liftgate, a drowsy driving warning system. Extras include parking assist, a panoramic sunroof, a heated steering wheel, surround-view camera, and most important, a rear-seat entertainment system, which is a good way to keep the cabin quiet so you can enjoy this SUV’s hushed ride.

New for 2015

The GL450 gets a twin-turbo 3.0-liter V-6 engine; stop/start is now standard on GL450 and GL63 AMG.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLA-Class
subTitle: Mercedes crossover goodness at a reasonable price.
promoTeaserSmall: Mercedes crossover goodness at a reasonable price.
promoTeaser: Mercedes crossover goodness at a reasonable price.
metaKeywords: 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLA-class; Mercedes-Benz; Mercedes; SUV; sport-utility; crossover; German
metaDescription: Mercedes crossover goodness at a reasonable price.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $32,225–$49,225 (includes destination)
Trim levels: GLA250, GLA45 AMG
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 208/355 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: GLA250 FWD: 25 mpg city/35 mpg highway; GLA250 AWD: 24/32 mpg; GLA45 AMG: 23/29 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Power liftgate
Notable standard features on this model: Chrome roof rails, fourteen-way adjustable power driver’s seat, 18-inch wheels, steering wheel-mounted shift paddles, active collision avoidance system, rain-sensing wipers
Notable options on this model: Active parking assist, Comand infotainment system with navigation, rearview camera, lane-keeping assist, panoramic sunroof, Harman/Kardon audio system with twelve speakers, sport front seats
You might also be considering: Audi Q3, BMW X1

The compact crossover market is facing stiff competition from this newcomer. The 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLA is a nicely stocked pint-sized ute that offers many premium features as standard equipment to win buyers over. It’s ably powered by a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine with 208 horsepower and employs an automatic stop/start system to increase fuel economy without sacrificing performance. Legroom in the second row is tight at 33.9 cubic inches, but the tradeoff is more cargo room behind the second row than you’d expect to find in a small crossover: 11.8 cubic feet. And loading the GLA is easy thanks to a low lift-over height and power-operated liftgate—a welcome standard feature in the Mercedes version of an entry-level crossover.

New for 2015

The GLA-class is all new for 2015.

title: Apple CarPlay: What You Need to Know
subTitle: The iPhone experience for your car, soon to be widely available. What makes it so good.
promoTitle: Apple CarPlay: What You Need to Know
promoTeaserSmall: The iPhone experience for your car, soon to be widely available. What makes it so good.
promoTeaser: The iPhone experience for your car, soon to be widely available. What makes it so good.
keywords: Apple CarPlay: What You Need to Know
metaTitle: Apple CarPlay: What You Need to Know - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The iPhone experience for your car, soon to be widely available. What makes it so good.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: Your iPhone lets you operate at the speed of light: texting a crowd to set up your next merger or soccer game. Triangulating your destination accurately with nothing more than a street address. Paying for groceries and rent with a tap. Asking Siri to remind you to pick up the dry cleaning as you buy coffee.  But when you get in the car? It all stops. And you sit there staring at taillights. Even when you can pair your phone for hands-free calling using Bluetooth, it's often an awkward experience that's nowhere near as fluid as what the iPhone offers you.

That’s why Apple launched Apple CarPlay in 2014. Instead of disconnecting—or choosing between disconnecting and looking at your phone when you should be looking at the road—you can plug your iPhone in while you buckle up, once you download the Apple CarPlay app to your phone. The car will mirror what’s on your phone to the in-dash telematics system and keep you moving at lightning speed, even when the traffic is crawling.

Well, in point of fact, it’s more like a magnifying cosmetic mirror than a true reflection of what’s on your phone. Everything has been rebuilt for the larger in-car screen and the car experience, where you don’t want to do more than glance at that screen, and—more than on your phone—you are encouraged to ask Siri for whatever you need. Want to make a phone call, find coffee nearby, get your texts read aloud, or navigate to your destination? Push a button and ask Siri. She will take it from there. You phone, meanwhile, is somewhat disabled by a big splash screen, encouraging you to look up at the road and not down at your phone. That's a good thing.

The biggest difference between your phone and the in-car mirror of it is the apps you’ll find. Apps have to be rebuilt for the car experience before they’ll show up on that in-car screen. So only a small percentage of that massive collection you have will appear in the car. At the moment, Apple CarPlay supports most music and audio listening apps and a few others. But this is early days. More will come.
Audi, BMW, Chrysler, Dodge, Fiat, Ford, Honda, Jaguar, Jeep, Mazda, Mercedes-Benz, Mitsubishi, Nissan, Toyota, VW, Volkswagen, and Volvo will all be adding Apple CarPlay.

Up till now all this connected goodness has been all promise and little actual drivable reality. But that’s changing for 2016. The 2015 Hyundai Sonata is the first car on the road to boast Apple CarPlay (and Android Auto). But Chevrolet has announced that its mainstay Cruze and fourteen other models will have it in 2016. In many cars, the system uses your phone’s data plan for things like streaming music and navigation. But because Chevys have OnStar, you can opt to use that in-car data plan instead—a nice plus.

More carmakers are signing on to deliver Apple CarPlay to future vehicles. A long list of them have committed to adding the technology to cars: Audi, BMW, Chrysler, Dodge, Fiat, Ford, Honda, Jaguar, Jeep, Mazda, Mercedes-Benz, Mitsubishi, Nissan, Toyota, Volkswagen, and Volvo are among them. And the list will doubtless grow from there. That's good news for anyone who uses an Apple iPhone 5 and up.

If you are a smartphone addict, productivity guru, or just like using your phone, this is a feature you will want in any car you buy going forward. But make sure the car supports both Android Auto (this is common) and Apple CarPlay. You may know that you are an Apple diehard, but you might want to sell that car to an Android geek.

title: 2015 Infiniti QX80 AWD Limited
subTitle: A big, beautiful SUV that makes a statement. Is it right for you? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: A big, beautiful SUV that makes a statement. Is it right for you? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: A big, beautiful SUV that makes a statement. Is it right for you? Here's what we think.
metaDescription: A big, beautiful SUV that makes a statement. Is it right for you? Here's what we think.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-passenger, all-wheel-drive luxury sport-utility vehicle
Base price: $67,345 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $89,845
Engine: 5.6-liter V-8, 400 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 14 mpg city/20 mpg highway
Safety: Not yet rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2015 Mercedes-Benz GL550 4Matic ($90,875)
2015 Cadillac Escalade AWD Premium ($85,065)
2015 Lincoln Navigator L AWD ($69,055)
2015 Land Rover Range Rover LR-V6 Supercharged ($84,490)

Fun-O-Meter: 7

You may not be able to keep up with Infiniti’s across-the-board name changes—the 2015 Infiniti QX80 AWD was known as the QX56 until last year—but the new naming convention seems to have settled into a good place. The QX prefix denotes sport-utility vehicles, followed by a number that gets bigger (QX50, QX60, QX70) as the size of the ride increases.

The QX80, the flagship sport-utility vehicle of the Nissan luxury division, is as big and as luxurious as it gets. In a crowded marketplace of full-size luxury SUVs, it’s truly a standout, with an exterior design that has been a head turner ever since its debut in 2004. The QX80 received a major redesign in 2011, and that was nice. But the 2015 model we’re looking at now has curves in all the right places, with new front fascia, bumper, and grille. It’s big, it’s gorgeous, and it’s impressive.
The model we tested was even better for having the high-end interior appointments that come in the Limited package. It should feel premium: it’s a $10,000 option.

Sitting atop the Infiniti SUV lineup, the QX80 competes against the Mercedes-Benz GL-Class and G-Class, the Land Rover Range Rover, the Cadillac Escalade, and the Lincoln Navigator. On this high-end playground, it’s important to have a certain wow factor. The sticker price of $89,845 on the model I tested definitely qualifies as a big, fat wow. However, the base QX80 is priced at a more sedate $66,350—similar to the base prices of most of the competition. That wouldn’t include the G-Class (which starts at $116,325) and the Range Rover (with a base price of $84,490), indicating that people shopping in this segment don’t balk at a six-figure sticker.

A 400-horsepower 5.6-liter V-8, paired with a seven-speed automatic transmission, is sophisticated and powerful enough to smoothly take this 5,888-pound QX80 from a dead stop to full speed ahead and from fast to even faster with zero drama. We don’t have much in the way of hills to climb here in Michigan, but we have plenty of Interstate action to make the most of this luxury liner’s impressive passing power considering its hefty size. Not surprisingly, the QX80 achieves only 14 mpg in the city, 20 mpg on the highway, whether you choose the rear- or (as we did) the all-wheel-drive version. For those with towing in their plans, the QX80 can pull up to 8,500 pounds. I can only imagine what the extra tonnage would do to the fuel economy.
Did I mention the QX80 requires premium gas?

Minor detail. Let’s return to the QX80’s vastness, comfort, and all-around indulgent fabulousness. I was pleasantly surprised by the ride quality of the QX80, especially since our model had the larger (22 inch) wheels. Michigan’s rough roads were barely noticeable, and the QX80’s agile steering helped me avoid the largest potholes without jarring the occupants too much. Assisting in docking this land yacht is the standard Around View Monitor, with front and rear sonar and moving object detection. I personally am a huge fan of the 360-degree camera view, and the added visibility would be a plus to anyone towing.

Those who are not fans of the exterior styling should at least take a peek inside the premium interior of a QX80 with the Limited package and admire its dark Truffle brown semi-aniline leather interior with ultrasuede headliner, quilted seats, open-pore ash wood trim with a matte finish, and leather-wrapped steering wheel and door pulls. Every manufacturer should study the matte wood finish carefully; it is stunning. The Limited package also includes exterior swag such as dark trim details and blings out the running boards with stainless steel caps and lights.

Our test vehicle loaded up on technology, and added extra curb appeal with an amazing-looking wheel and tire package ($2,450). The Driver’s Assistance package ($2,100) includes such helpful technology as blind spot warning, backup collision intervention, and intelligent brake assist with predictive forward collision warning. Frankly, it’s a little disappointing that a vehicle in this price category offers advanced safety technologies as extra-cost options instead of standard equipment.

The options continue with a Theater package ($2,400) that includes heated seats and a pair of seven-inch color monitors, all for the occupants of the second row. Added up, the extras on the model we tested come to $22,450. You could skip all that and buy a second economy car to smooth over your carbon footprint.

Our particular QX80 had seating for seven, with a pair of captain’s chairs that can be tipped forward for access to the third row. If you need one more seat, you can swap out the middle-row buckets for a bench. The third row has seatbelts for three passengers, but if they are any bigger than a middle schooler you’ll need to crank up the stereo to drown out their complaining. Luckily, it’s a Bose thirteen-speaker premium audio system (fifteen speakers if you get the Technology package).

Absent the whining from the peanut gallery, the cabin is otherworldly quiet, cocooning passengers from almost all road noise. The quiet lasted until we kicked up the fifteen speakers’ worth of sound and turned the ride around town into a rolling club scene.
Once you load up the third row with people, there is only a smidge of room left to hold your luggage, but never fear: there’s always the roof rack.

The exterior for 2015 has standard LED headlights, turn signals, and foglamps. Add in those lighted running boards, and the QX80 is as distinctive in the dark as it does in the light of day. High Beam Assist is also standard. This feature uses a camera to read oncoming and upcoming traffic, automatically toggling between high and low beam. I love this feature, which was especially appreciated when driving in northern Michigan on a mostly deserted stretch of Interstate.

The Verdict:

With this big price, you are allowed big customer expectations. Both the cabin and the exterior must exude exclusivity. Not to worry: the QX80 is first-class-airline worthy. For those who like their vehicle to express their own uniqueness, the QX80 may provide the desired amount of aesthetic divergence from an ordinary big-box SUV.

The competition is fierce, though, so if you’re looking in the high-dollar, high-riding premium SUV category, try out all the competitors you can and make an informed decision. A natural alternative is the Mercedes GL-Class, which can give a bump in fuel economy. If you are mainly interested in cushy luxury, check out the Lexus LX570. And if prestige is top of your list, you might  give the Land Rover Range Rover or Range Rover Sport a good look as well.

But all said and done, it’s how you feel when you’re behind the wheel or looking at it out in the driveway, and if the curvaceous, strikingly unusual-looking Infiniti QX80 is your cup of premium tea, none of the competition will seem like good enough substitutes to you.

images.caption: 2015 Infiniti QX80 Limited AWD: detail on the stunning matte-finish wood trim.
2015 Infiniti QX80 Limited AWD: seven-speed automatic transmission.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/b8vSW5rRJcM" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

2016 Mazda MX-5 Miata Grand Touring MT

Type: Two-passenger, rear-wheel-drive convertible
Base price: $25,735 (base Sport model, including destination charge)
This car: $30,885 (including destination charge)
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine, 155 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/34 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Folding convertible top
Notable standard features on this model: i-Activsense package, including lane departure warning, rear cross-traffic alert, blind spot monitoring; Mazda Connect infotainment with voice command; nine-speaker Bose audio with headrest speakers; heated seats; seventeen-inch wheels; LED daylight running lights and headlamps
Notable options on this model: Keyless entry (standard on automatic-transmission model)
You might also be considering: 2015 Mini Cooper Convertible ($26,550); 2015 Porsche Boxster ($52,395)

Key Points:

• The MX-5 is wider, lower, and lighter than the outgoing car.
• Key exterior design cues include a low hood, blacked-out A-pillars and mirrors, and exterior LED lights.
• Interestingly, it makes 12 horsepower less than the 2015 model.
• The 2016 model has significantly improved fuel economy of 25 percent versus 2015 Miata, due to a weight reduction of approximately 150 pounds. The new Miata starts at 2,332 pounds with a manual transmission and 2,381 with an automatic transmission.
• Meanwhile, the price has increased on the base model by $945 versus the outgoing 2015 model.
• The Grand Touring tested here is the top-of-the-line model. The midlevel MX-5 Club starts at $29,420, including destination charge. • Consumer Reports calls this the “last truly affordable sports car.”
• The model you see in the video adds a long list of premium amenities including seventeen-inch bright alloy wheels, leather-trimmed heated seats, and automatic climate control.
• For the first time, a six-speed manual transmission comes standard, as well as LED headlights, USB audio input, and Bluetooth.
• Standard safety equipment includes four airbags, antilock brakes, stability control and traction control. Test car has standard blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert and a lane-departure warning system.
• So, what do you want for your next birthday?

title: 4 Ways to Buy a Used Car Online
subTitle: How to get your next car delivered from your keyboard straight to your home.
promoTitle: 4 Ways to Buy a Used Car Online
promoTeaserSmall: How to get your next car delivered from your keyboard straight to your home.
promoTeaser: How to get your next car delivered from your keyboard straight to your home.
keywords: 4 Ways to Buy a Used Car Online
metaTitle: Four Ways to Buy a Used Car Online - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: How to get your next car delivered from your keyboard straight to your home.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: No, it isn’t just you. Only seventeen out of 4,002 people surveyed by AutoTrader.com in 2014 said they are happy with the car-buying experience. Shoppers are taking the matter into their own hands, literally, using computers, smartphones, and tablets as car-shopping tools. Looking for the exact vehicle, negotiating the price, financing the loan, finalizing the paperwork—even having your car delivered to your driveway—can now be accomplished by dealing exclusively on the Internet.

Sound too good to be true? When it comes to buying any of the 40 million used cars sold in the U.S. each year, there are more options than ever if you're ready to let your Wi-Fi do the walking and your fingers do the talking. Your next used car can be purchased without ever meeting a salesperson, if you call on one of these four websites as your tool.

1. Beepi.com

Los Altos, California
Slogan: Every car is hand-inspected. Hand-wrapped. And hand-delivered.
Pro: Intuitive, easy-to-use website; 185-point inspection before a car is offered for sale; ten-day money-back guarantee; Beepi buys your car itself if it hasn't sold in thirty days.
Con: Added delivery fees can mount up if you live far from California; cars cannot be test driven in advance.

A virtual middleman between used-car sellers and wanna-be buyers, Beepi (pronounced "beep-eee, like the sound a car horn makes") offers two services: “Buy” and “Sell,” which is exactly where visitors are directed from the moment they log on.

Click “buy,” and you can search by make, model, and other filters, including model year, color, and price range. Available inventory pops up in full color, with pictures of the actual car for sale, along with its price and mileage. Click again, and you get more details on various features such as all-wheel drive—and email access to a human who can answer additional questions and guide you through to purchase.

Each used car that Beepi sells first undergoes a 185-point inspection by Beepi mechanics, comparable to many automakers’ certified pre-owned programs, only less expensive. Prices are guaranteed to be less than dealerships’ advertised pricing, which the site says is possible since Beepi isn’t burdened with the overhead of used-car lots and salespeople. The cars they sell are parked in homeowners’ driveways until they’re sold.
Several hundred cars are available at any given time and available for delivery anywhere in the United States.
Regardless of geography, Beepi delivers its cars via flatbed truck and topped with a giant bow.

Beepi delivers cars for free to customers in California, Arizona, Texas, and Florida. Residents of Nevada, Oregon, Washington, Utah, Colorado,  and New Mexico can also buy through Beepi, but they will pay a $999 fee. Located in another state? No problem. Beepi says it will deliver anywhere. We asked for some estimates, and a delivery to Michigan is $800 for a car, $1,050 for a truck or sport-utility vehicle. To New York, it's $1,000 for a car, $1,300 for a truck or SUV. Regardless of geography, Beepi delivers its cars via flatbed truck and topped with a giant bow.

Customers aren’t able to test drive the cars before buying them. But right afterward, you can take comfort in a ten-day, 1,000-mile money-back guarantee. If you decide within that time that the car isn’t for you, Beepi will send a truck and take it back for free.

Click “sell,” and the site determines the price that car ordinarily commands in your market. Beepi says the price is usually at least $1,000 more than you would receive if trading in a car at a dealer, although likely less than you would get if you sold the car yourself. And if your car doesn’t sell to a private party within a month of being listed on the site, Beepi will buy it from you.

2. Carlypso.com

San Carlos, California
Slogan: Buy your dream car. Up to 40% off. Delivered to you.
Pro: Good selection; low prices; transparent fee structure and what-is-listed-is-what-you-get pricing; thirty days to change your mind after purchase.
Con: Only available in California for now; cars cannot be test driven in advance; website not so easy to understand; cars can only be returned for mechanical defects within 30 days.

Available to used-car buyers as well as sellers with a used car to trade or just cash in, Carlypso is similar to other used-car buying sites in that it can be searched by price, make, model, color, and mileage. It isn’t as eye-catching or as easy to navigate as its competitors, but at least there’s a good selection and reasonable prices with a transparent fee structure.
Carlypso sources used cars from wholesale auctions, leasing companies, and corporate fleets, letting them charge lower prices than at dealerships.

Carlypso sources its used cars from wholesale auctions of vehicles owned by automakers, leasing companies, and corporate fleets in California and Arizona, allowing them to be offered at a lower price than at dealerships. The cars listed for sale remain in the lots of the entities auctioning them until a buyer bids on the car, at which point Carlypso makes the purchase on behalf of the buyer. That’s why the used cars for sale are often only available for a few days or even hours at the listed price.

Carlypso makes its money by charging a $750 fee for models costing less than $20,000 and $1,000 for cars valued at $20,000 and up. Those fees are included in each car’s listed price on the website. Deliveries, however, are not free, and vary depending on the distance the car needs to be shipped.

Although Carlypso's services are available only to buyers in California at present, a national rollout is in the works. The used cars Carlypso sells can not be test driven before purchase. At least they’re inspected by three independent parties before being delivered to buyers, which happens within five to seven days of purchase.

Buyers may return the car within thirty days for their money back if there are mechanical defects that weren’t detected through the inspections. If you buy but decide you simply do not like the car, you cannot return it unless you have pre-purchased a contract cancellation option, which involves a "restocking fee" that can be as much as $500.

Used-car sellers can list their vehicles through Carlypso as well. The company then dispatches a third-party detailer to clean the vehicle and attach a lock box to the license plate that contains the car’s key and enables test drives.

Potential buyers who sign up for the service swipe their driver's license or credit card to authenticate themselves and to unlock the box after reserving a time online for a test drive. A GPS unit remotely tracks the test drive as it’s taking place. The seller also receives a text that the car is being tested. If the test driver wants to buy the car, he or she bids online, and, if approved, pays cash or a cashier’s check into Carlypso’s account, after which the company mails a check and sends a text message to the seller indicating the transaction is complete.

3. Carvana.com

Atlanta, Georgia
Slogan: Skip the dealer; buy the car online.
Pro: Cars are priced below Kelly Blue Book valuation; 360-degree photo galleries of each car; seven-day money-back guarantee for any reason; if you pick up your car at the Atlanta headquarters, there's a gimmicky but fun "car vending machine" from which you take delivery.
Con: Cars can't be test driven before purchase; there's a delivery fee for most areas.

Used-car buyers pay a $1,500 to $2,000 premium just for buying a car from a dealership, much of it attributable to the overhead of a place to store the cars and a staff to sell them. Not coincidentally, $2,000 is the average amount of money Carvana says it saves its customers, because selling its cars online voids the need for such overhead.
In fact, Carvana says all of its cars are priced lower than Kelley Blue Book’s valuation, and it proves it by giving each car with its Kelley Blue Book price and its lower cost through Carvana.

Like other online used-car buying services, Carvana’s inventory is easily searched by make, model, body style, year, price, payment, mileage, color, drivetrain, and other features. Because the cars cannot be seen in person before purchase, each car is also accompanied by a 360-degree photo gallery showing details of its interior, exterior, and under the hood.

All the cars it sells are “Carvana certified,” meaning they are inspected and reconditioned before being resold through the site. Purchasing can be done online or through a "customer advocate" over the phone.

Deliveries take place within twenty-four hours of purchase, free for customers within 100 miles of Atlanta, Nashville, Dallas, Charlotte, N.C., and Birmingham, Alabama. Deliveries within 101 and 250 miles of the Carvana hub in Atlanta cost $199. Deliveries elsewhere in the nation are handled by a third-party delivery company; prices vary depending on location.
With Carvana, cars cannot be test driven in advance but can be returned within seven days of taking ownership for any reason, “no questions asked.”

Cars cannot be test driven in advance but can be returned within seven days of taking ownership for any reason, “no questions asked.”
In addition, Carvana offers a 100-day, 4,189-mile worry-free guarantee should an unforeseen mechanical problem crop up early in the used car’s new ownership.

If you're a buyer and have a car to trade in to Carvana, you can complete a questionnaire and get an online appraisal. Then you can apply Carvana’s suggested purchase price for a trade-in vehicle to the price of the used car you buy or receive a check. And if you need additional financing, Carvana will arrange that, too.

4. Vroom.com

Grand Prairie, Texas
Slogan: More power to you.
Pro: Good selection of more high-end cars; easy-to-understand website and pricing.
Con: $500 deposit required to hold a car (it's refundable, though); cars can be a bit overpriced.

With an inventory of about 1,400 cars sourced from auctions, dealerships, and private parties, Vroom sells everything from Ford’s bestselling F-150 pickup to exotic green cars including Tesla’s all-electric Model S. With an average car price of $36,000, Vroom skews slightly higher end. Among its bestsellers are Chevrolet Corvettes and Porsche 911s.
With Vroom, you can put a $500 refundable deposit on a car. Only then does a real human being enter into the picture to finalize the paperwork.

Like other used-car buying sites, vehicles are searched by make, model, body type, price, year, and mileage. Results are displayed clearly, with photos, actual mileage, a price and what that price translates into per month, including tax title and license fees, over the course of a five-year loan for your exact zip code.

If a car strikes your fancy, you can put a $500 refundable deposit on a car. Only then does a real human being enter into the picture to finalize the paperwork, which is overnighted to your home and returned to Vroom free of charge. Vroom, which is based in Texas, then delivers the car for free anywhere in the U.S. with a full tank of gas.
Buyers who are also trading in a car through Vroom can say buh-bye to their old wheels at the same time. Vroom will pick it up while they’re there.

But no purchase is required to sell a used vehicle through Vroom. If you’re just looking to offload an old Jetta, give Vroom the VIN and send them a few pictures, and they’ll respond with the price they’re willing to pay.

Lacking the middleman of a dealership, Vroom prices its cars below the average competition, it says. It makes its money through a small profit on the sale of each vehicle.  Each vehicle listed for sale is run through a 126-point inspection and reconditioned to a status called “Supremely Certified.” Vroom also says it will not resell cars that have accidents reported to CarFax or AutoCheck, although buyers should be sure to take advantage of Vroom's seven-day, 250-mile return policy and have the car checked by a trusted mechanic once it’s arrived.
Vroom cars also include a ninety-day, 6,000-mile warranty to cover repairs and 24/7 roadside assistance for one year.

pageElements.text:
2015 Honda HR-V EX

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive subcompact crossover
Trim levels: LX, EX, EX-L Navi
Base price (LX with six-speed manual transmission): $19,995 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $22,845
Engine: 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 141 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 28 mpg city/35 mpg highway
Safety: Not yet rated
My favorite standard feature: Heated front seats
You might also be considering: 2015 Chevrolet Trax LS FWD ($20,995), 2016 Mazda CX-3 ($20,840), 2015 Nissan Juke ($21,075), 2015 Subaru XV Crosstrek ($22,445)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/eACmnPq2VxE" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points:

• This is an all-new model for the U.S. market and one of the most highly anticipated entries in this hot segment.
• Others on the growing list of competitors are the Fiat 500X and Jeep Renegade. Hyundai is also considering a subcompact SUV that may arrive for U.S. buyers in 2017.
• The HR-V is based on the subcompact Honda Fit hatchback.
• Interestingly, the HR-V's wheelbase is only 0.3 inch shorter than the CR-V's, which explains the good back-seat legroom in the HR-V.
• However, the HR-V is 9.2 inches shorter in overall length than the CR-V.
• Cargo capacity is the big difference. HR-V is 24.3 cubic feet with rear seats in place, 58.8 cubic feet with seats folded, versus the CR-V at 35.2/70.9 cubic feet.
• More important, the HR-V’s 24.3 cubic feet of cargo space beats most of its competitors.
• Buyers in this segment are extremely price-sensitive, so the HR-V undercuts its subcompact-SUV competitors in base price.
• The top-end HR-V, the EX-L Navi, is priced higher than the beloved entry-level Honda CR-V, the automaker's bigger compact SUV, which starts at $24,325 (prices include destination charge).
• The base model with six-speed manual transmission starts under $20,000.
• The price tops out at $26,720 for the top EX-L Navi with all-wheel drive and continuously variable automatic transmission (CVT).
Buyers in this segment are extremely price-sensitive, so the HR-V undercuts its subcompact-SUV competitors in base price.

• All versions of the HR-V are equipped with a 141-horsepower, 1.8-liter in-line four-cylinder engine and either a six-speed manual transmission or a CVT. The engine is shared with the Honda Civic.
• All HR-Vs come with hill-start assist, stability and traction control, six airbags, and a rearview camera.
• The EX model we tested also has standard LaneWatch. The center console display shows the right side of the vehicle when you click on the right turn signal.
• The HR-V has nice cabin materials and decent storage bins. • There's an impressive list of standard equipment in the HR-V EX we tested, including Bluetooth phone connectivity, Pandora Internet radio, push-button start, and heated front seats.

2016 Honda HR-V EX's HondaLink infotainment screen.

title: 2016 Scion iA
subTitle: The Toyota youth brand's first sedan: Is it a good buy? Here's what we think.
