contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive four-door subcompact sedan
Base price: $17,595 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $18,184
Engine: 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 106 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic (six-speed manual is also available)
Fuel economy: 33 mpg city/42 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: not yet tested; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: not yet tested
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Honda Fit LX: $17,410
2015 Ford Fiesta S: $15,935
2015 Chevrolet Sonic: $16,320
Fun-O-Meter: 7

This would be the year to finally take a look at Scion, a sub-brand of mighty Toyota meant to coax a much younger, much more Internet-savvy buyer to the fold. Scion fired up nationally in 2004, after a sneak peek at the first Scions at the 2002 New York Auto Show, followed by a limited rollout of production cars to 105 California Toyota dealers in 2003.

Once the production versions of the xA, the tC, and the trendsetting xB treehouse on tiny wheels hit the market with full force, it looked like Scion would be the brand to watch. Built with legendary Toyota quality, offered at reasonable prices, and accompanied by a wide range of add-ons to build one your own way, the Scion brand took off like a rocket.
After peaking at just over 173,000 sold in 2006, sales finally fell to earth in the wake of the 2009 depression, dropping to just over 58,000 in 2014.

The all new 2016 iA—Scion’s first sedan—should help stop the slide. With a huge boost from Mazda, the sporty iA muscles its way to the top tier of the subcompact shopping list, alongside the Honda Fit and the Ford Fiesta.

It’s actually shocking how good this little car is to drive. It shouldn't be, though, because it's based on the Mazda 2 (the green car pictured here), only with a crazy-looking front end from Scion. There are a few other bits and bobs from the Scion/Toyota parts bin inside, but, in all but name, this is a Mazda 2.

The little Mazda 2 may be the lesser of all the great Mazdas, but I happen to like it. In the Scion lineup, it's a real standout, with a buttoned-down ride and electric steering with a very tight turning circle that makes you feel as if you’re piloting a go-kart.
With a huge boost from Mazda, the sporty iA muscles its way to the top tier of the subcompact shopping list, alongside the Honda Fit and the Ford Fiesta.
The fine suspension and tight steering are compliments of the Mazda 2. They’re so good that even the Scion guys wax eloquent about the competence of Mazda’s chief suspension engineer.

The iA I drove was equipped with a six-speed automatic transmission; a six-speed manual is also available. You would be right not to expect entertainment from the automatic transmission. But wait. There is a Sport button, and when you hit it, shift points are suddenly amped up, with an added growl. Okay, maybe it’s not an actual grrowwwl growl, but there’s certainly a noticeable uptick in the amount of excitement in the air.

The iA’s interior shares a Toyota aesthetic: clean and ergonomically correct, with a high level of quality craftsmanship, if carried out with pretty basic materials. This, too, is compliments of the Mazda 2. If you want to see a truly inspired interior, have a look inside the new Scion iM. Too bad the iM, with its laissez-faire steering, is not as fun to drive as the new iA.

Wrap your head around a satisfying, sporting little sedan, stuffed with this much premium content, for a base price of $17,595 (including destination charge) and a final price of $18,184, which includes $419 for navigation and $170 for door-sill protectors. If you've been in the market lately for a used car, you'll find it difficult to find a barely acceptable car for under $10,000, and once you go under that $10K, you aren’t likely to get a used car that’s in the Certified Pre-Owned category. Meaning you’re on your own, warranty-wise.

Instead, for an extra $7,600, you can get this iA: a brand-new car, absolutely loaded, made by Mazda and Toyota, that looks good. Okay, that last point is debatable. But it does have excellent fuel economy (33 mpg city/42 mpg highway with the automatic transmission).

Scion would certainly like to maintain its industry-low average age of buyer, which is among the absolute lowest in the industry. Scion saw it climb as sales fell. The funky little xB (shown here) was gunning for twenty-five-year-olds, but instead it attracted a large number of older women. Nothing like seeing your grandma driving an xB to make you look elsewhere for a new car.
Just saying.

This time, Scion is aiming at thirty-five-year-olds. (Who, if you think about it, are the exact same twenty-five-year-olds it marketed those first Scions to a decade ago.) Today’s young drivers are getting their licenses later (but girls earlier than boys), they are saddled with greater college debt, it's harder to find jobs, and therefore they are not so much in the market for a new car as they were when Scion first launched.

So, it's up to Millennials. I brought my own with me, Jean Knows Cars intern Annie Boniface. Annie is on the younger end of the millennial curve—she's a sophomore in college, studying to be a journalist. Annie is a little more hyper-aware of cars than the average nineteen-year-old college student because she's part of a large extended family of Alfa nuts. Although she doesn't share the rabid enthusiasm of her male cousins for arcane automotive minutiae, she likes cars and likes to drive, and she has a sharp eye and strong opinions. Here are a few closing words from our personal Jean Knows Cars Millennial on the subject of the Scion iA:

At first glance, the iA looks like a well-made and attractive car, if you ignore its guppy-like face. The car we drove was a beautiful navy that Scion calls Abyss, a color that I believe looks good on everyone. Moving inside, I immediately thought the $17,595 price tag was a mistake. The seven-inch Display Audio touchscreen caught my eye, and there were high-quality materials everywhere I looked from the dash to the seats to the floor.

When I drove the iA, a few features really stood out. There is a knob between the front seats that controls the infotainment screen, and I quickly started referring to it as the Wheel of Fun. I found it surprisingly intuitive and convenient. The iA's electric power steering was a dream, ultra-responsive and direct. Speaking of responsive, the gas and brake pedals required only a tap. The Sport mode was very noticeable, and actually hearing the revs made me feel, well, like a badass. Or as much of a badass as you can be in a subcompact sedan.
The Scion marketing people claim the target audience for the new iA is “practical Millennials,” and while I thought that sounded like BS at first, I have to admit I now kind of agree with them.
I am a Millennial, and if I was shopping for a car, I would add the iA to my short list just based on the quality I could have for under $20,000.

The Verdict:

The appeal for any age group comes back to two things, doesn’t it: the astonishing level of standard features, some of which you couldn't find on high-level, expensive luxury cars without paying a premium for, and the astonishing price
So, there you have it. Whether you’re a twentysomething or a person from a more mature demographic, this really should be the year you have a good look at Toyota’s Scion brand.

title: I'm 19! Of Course I'm a Good Driver
subTitle: And I have a few rules of engagement for parents and kids when they get in the car together.
promoTitle: I'm 19! Of Course I'm a Good Driver
promoTeaserSmall: And I have a few rules of engagement for parents and kids when they get in the car together.
promoTeaser: And I have a few rules of engagement for parents and kids when they get in the car together.
keywords: I'm 19! Of Course I'm a Good Driver
metaTitle: I'm 19! Of Course I'm a Good Driver - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: parents and children in the car
metaDescription: And I have a few rules of engagement for parents and kids when they get in the car together.

pageElements.text: The fight for the car keys between new and more seasoned drivers is one we can all appreciate. Perhaps you’re an adult who fears for dear life and silently prays the rosary when a young driver gets behind the wheel. Or maybe you’re like me; at nineteen years old I have been driving for three years. I grew up in a car family, though, and aunts and uncles like to joke that Boniface grandchildren come out of the womb driving. That certainly doesn’t put any pressure on my brother, Bobby (21); sisters, Julie and Megan (17 and 15), or me, especially when learning to drive under instruction from my dad, a car designer.

Regardless, you know the power struggle at hand. You can understand how stress can sour the sweetness of first getting your license. The peace treaty to end the War of the Driver’s Seat lies at the corner of compromise and understanding. To my younger cohort, we can do a better job of establishing ourselves as safe and competent drivers, and to the more experienced crowd, lightening up on your new driver will do wonders for both of you. Here are some tips to help you achieve all of the above.

For kids:

1. Avoid asking questions that sell short your ability and knowledge behind the wheel.
“Hey mom! I’m on my way home from work, but quick question. How far can I go once the gas thingy says empty?”
“Annie, what does your fuel range say? Where are you? You should have about thirty miles once it hits empty, but how long has it been low??”
“Oh, no. Okay, bye, Mom, I gotta go.” Click.

I am a big offender on this one. Even if I know the answer to my own problem or question, I still like to double check, and like our good friend Ed Sheeran, I suffer from a little syndrome called “thinking out loud.” I will return from college after not driving for five months, hop in the car, and to my mother’s horror, ask aloud, “Hm, which one is the brake again?” You can stop composing the petition to have my license revoked; I promise I know where the brake is. When getting back in the swing of things, though, I mentally and often verbally go over some basics, causing my parents to seriously doubt my driving abilities. I know I’m not alone here. If you’re like me, by simply holding in the rhetorical questions and Googling topics you want to double check, you can save yourself some embarrassment and your parents some worry.
2. Turn the music down.

I don’t care how fabulous a driver you are; if I am two lanes over and can hear the bass thumping in your car, I will steer clear. Adults especially take loud music as a sign of distracted driving. When you’re driving with older passengers, pick a station, set it to an appropriate volume, and leave it, at least until the next stoplight. If you’re alone in the car and simply need to listen to Taylor Swift at level 30, turn it down when you pull in to your neighborhood. Nothing screams “safe driver” quite like my little sister whipping into the driveway with Lil Jon’s “Turn Down for What” blasting through the open windows. In reality, she is a perfectly fine driver, but when you sit shotgun in a car operated by a seventeen-year-old whom you cannot even hear over the music, your life occasionally flashes before your eyes. Do yourself a favor and keep it down.
I can parallel park downtown without so much as a wrinkled forehead when my best friend is in the car, but with my dad in the car I struggle even to go the speed limit.

For adults:

1. Try to pay as much attention to your child’s driving as you would to any other adult’s driving.

Would you criticize your colleague’s hand placement on the wheel? Actually, would you even notice your colleague’s hand placement? Probably not, because you have some degree of faith in other adults’ driving abilities. Try to pretend, if only for a moment, that the teenager you are riding alongside is twenty-eight years old and perfectly capable. Hopefully, you will find fewer glaring errors in their driving once you exit that hyper aware state of mind. Personally, my confidence behind the wheel is inversely related to how much my passengers care about my driving. I can parallel park in downtown Birmingham without so much as a wrinkled forehead when my best friend is in the car, but when my dad sits in the front seat I struggle to even go the speed limit. Give yourself and your young driver a much-needed pressure relief.
2. When giving tips, keep your voice calm and casual.
Parents: When you come across a teachable moment in the car, give instructions in the same voice you would use for ordering lunch.

My mom is infamous in our family for tightly gripping the handle above her seat and calling to my dad in a panic-filled voice when one of the four kids drives during the newly licensed period. Anyone, regardless of age, would feel rather unconfident if their passenger suggested in a half yell that they slow down and maybe pull over so everyone can take a moment to collect themselves.

Recognize that teenagers are indeed new to the driving world and probably feel more nervous about that upcoming left turn than you do. When you come across a teachable moment in the car, give instructions in the same voice you would use for ordering lunch. Clearly express what you would like to see your young driver do, but keep your tone chatty and unconcerned. Yes, you want Panera to hold the onions on your salad, but if you spy some white and purple rings in the bowl you will not break into a lecture about disregard for safety and the diminishing value placed on focus in today’s generation. Same goes for riding with teenage drivers.

title: 2016 Hyundai Elantra
subTitle: The value and style its fans have come to expect is all still there.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan or four-door hatchback
Price range: $18,075 - $22,525 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: SE, Sport, Limited, Value
Engines: 1.8-liter four-cylinder; 2.0-liter four-cylinder
Transmissions: Six-speed manual or six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: SE manual: 27 mpg city/37 mpg highway; Sport manual: 24/34 mpg; SE automatic: 28/38 mph; Value automatic: 28/38 mpg; Limited automatic: 27/37 mpg; Sport automatic: 24/35 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: not yet rated for 2016; 2015 model was a Top Safety Pick
Our favorite standard feature: Trip computer
Notable standard features on this model: Cruise control, tilting and telescoping steering wheel, remote keyless entry, Hill Start Assist Control
Notable options on this model: Heated exterior mirrors, driver’s blind spot mirror, navigation system, sunroof
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Mazda 3, Toyota Corolla

A populist choice since its 2011 debut, in 2016 the Hyundai Elantra continues to bring the value and style customers have come to expect from this model. With a surprisingly elegant frame and smooth lines, the Elantra appeals to entry-level buyers but also to value-oriented buyers across the socioeconomic spectrum. Standard features like cruise control, a trip computer, and Hill Start Assist Control further add value and quality, while options like a sunroof and heated exterior mirrors make it even more comfortable. There are two engine choices, a 1.8-liter four-cylinder or a 2.0-liter four-cylinder, teamed with a six-speed manual (an increasingly difficult choice to find these days) or a six-speed automatic transmission. The Value Edition offers $1,000 in savings without doing away with fan-favorite features including leather steering wheel and shift knob, heated front seats, and a power tilting and sliding sunroof. The Sport model offers a sport-tuned suspension, aluminum pedals, heated front seats, a black chrome grille, and a special set of seventeen-inch alloy wheels. People come for the Elantra’s practicality and stay for the style and comfort.
New for 2016: Value Edition (offers $1,000 in savings).

title: Certified Pre-Owned Cars: 7 Steps to Success
subTitle: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.
promoTitle: Certified Pre-Owned Cars: 7 Steps to Success
promoTeaserSmall: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.
promoTeaser: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.
metaTitle: Certified Pre-Owned Cars: 7 Steps to Success
metaDescription: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.

pageElements.text: If you've shopped for a car in the past several years, you've surely heard about Certified Pre-Owned cars. Starting as a way to market higher-end used cars, the Certified Pre-Owned designation has now become commonplace at car dealerships. A Certified Pre-Owned (CPO) car is generally a car with a clean history, few past users, of relatively recent vintage, and with less than about 80,000 miles on the odometer. It undergoes an extensive pre-sale inspection, and problems are fixed by the dealer before it's offered for sale.
What's not to like? Of course, all of this means that your average CPO car is sold at a premium over a non-CPO used car, but for the peace of mind you get, it can be well worth the cost.
If you are interested in a used-car purchase, here are five things to know about CPO.

1. All CPO programs aren't alike.

Manufacturers run Certified Pre-Owned programs, but so do some dealers as well as organizations such as Enterprise car rental, the National Independent Automobile Dealers Association (NIADA), and others. You need to understand where the Certified Pre-Owned designation is coming from. The big advantage of seeking out a CPO used car, rather than any old car on the lot, is that the CPO car comes with a warranty. You want it to be the manufacturer’s own warranty, not the local dealer’s. Why? If the CPO program is through the manufacturer, not just the local dealership, any warranty repairs you do need can be performed anywhere around the country. That's a strong argument in favor of the automaker's program.

2. Used cars aren't just for those who can’t afford new anymore.

CPOs are increasingly popular among premium brands. CPO sales of Volvos were up 47 percent in the first half of 2015. Brands such as Mercedes-Benz, Jaguar, and Cadillac all have firmly established CPO programs, and even Porsche sold 1,206 certified pre-owned cars in April, its highest rate yet and up 18.8 percent compared to the preceding year. Earlier this summer, electric-sports-car maker Tesla started online sales of Certified Pre-Owned Model S cars that are starting to come back from lease programs. If you want a high-end car but don't want to pay a high-end price, a Certified Pre-Owned car might be the ticket for you.

3. The popularity of leasing means you’ll have lots of CPO choices.

With so many people leasing cars, dealers find themselves with an increasing quantity of reasonably “young” vehicles with one owner that are good candidates for a CPO sale. You could get a great deal on a low-mileage used car by taking advantage of that. Consider that CPO sales are up 12 percent through the first half of 2015, while new-car sales are up 4.5 percent. It’s no longer an unusual way to buy a car, and that’s good for the consumer.

4. The detailed inspection report is only one of several perks to look for.

A benefit of CPO programs is that the car you're looking at will come with an extensive inspection report (more than 150 points are checked out under most CPO programs), and you’ll get a Carfax (or similar) report on the vehicle’s history. Read them!

You can often finance a CPO purchase at or close to the same low interest rates you'd get on a new-car purchase. Other perks: the power to take a car back within a specified time limit if you're not happy with it, and sometimes, a free loaner vehicle if your CPO purchase comes in for repairs at the dealership. You might also want the roadside assistance that is usually offered, if you don’t already have AAA or another road service plan. So much better than trusting someone you met on Craigslist.

5. The warranty details and potential hidden costs need your close attention.

A Certified Pre-Owned car often comes with two kinds of warranties: the powertrain limited warranty that the car had as new, which is continued for the new owner; and a warranty on problems that come up elsewhere on the car, which may or may not cost extra. The "certified" in the Certified Pre-Owned title can mean different things in different programs.

For example, a CPO from Ford comes with a twelve-month, 12,000-mile comprehensive warranty on a long list of components—the kind that older cars might tend to need replaced, such as the alternator, ball joints, air conditioning compressor, and power door locks. All good news! However, there’s a $100 warranty deductible for each visit to the shop. For Toyota, the deductible on similar warranty coverage is $50; for Mercedes-Benz, it’s $0.

Dealerships and other CPO providers may also offer an extended warranty that you have to buy separately, which could be a substantial extra cost. Make sure you understand the terms, including the deductible, for repairs under the warranty, and whether any of the warranties are transferable should you sell the CPO car down the road.

title: 2016 Toyota Tacoma
subTitle: Toyota's bestselling pickup, revitalized. Is this compact truck right for you? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: Toyota's bestselling pickup, revitalized. Is this compact truck right for you? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: Toyota's bestselling pickup, revitalized. Is this compact truck right for you? Here's what we think.
metaDescription: Toyota's bestselling pickup, revitalized. Is this compact truck right for you? Here's what we think.

pageElements.text:
2016 Toyota Tacoma TRD Sport 4x4 Double Cab

Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive compact pickup
Base price (4x2 SR5 Access Cab) $26,285
This truck: $34,630 (includes destination charge)
Trim levels: SR, SR5, TRD Sport, TRD Off Road, Limited
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 278 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/23 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Entune Premium Audio with integrated navigation system (standard on TRD Sport)
Options I can’t live without: Crawl control, power moonroof
Notable standard features on this model: Sliding rear glass panel, composite inner cargo bed, lockable tailgate, push-button start, tilting and telescoping steering wheel, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift lever, windshield GoPro camera mount, Bluetooth, iPod connectivity, Siri Eyes Free, rearview camera
Notable options on this model: Tri-fold locking tonneau cover, mud guards, V-6 towing package
You might also be considering:
2016 Chevrolet Colorado LT Crew Cab 4WD ($33,430)
2016 GMC Canyon SLE Crew Cab 4WD ($35,285)
2015 Nissan Frontier SV-V6 Crew Cab 4x4 ($28,515)

After a decade of decline, compact pickup trucks are making a comeback, and Toyota’s Tacoma is at the head of the small but growing pack. That's good news for people who want the versatility of a truck but aren't interested in something with a large footprint.

To anyone following industry fortunes, this isn’t a big surprise. The Tacoma has been the big dog in this pack for the better part of the past ten years. With competition diminishing during that decade of dominance—Chrysler, Ford, and General Motors all dropped out—Toyota has seen no need to make major changes to its bestseller.

But the return of General Motors to the arena, with its all new Chevrolet Colorado and GMC Canyon, and the promise of an all-new Honda Ridgeline coming for 2017, have galvanized activity at the Tacoma truck works, and here’s the result, all new for 2016.

There are five trim levels: the basic SR work truck (from $25,030), the SR5 (from $26,285), the TRD Sport shown here (from $30,585),  theTRD Off-Road (from $33,850), and the top-end Limited (from $35,645).

All-new is always an elastic term in the auto industry, and it’s been stretched a little in this application. The foundations of the new truck are dimensionally identical to the outgoing version, suspension layout is basically unchanged, and the disc/drum braking system persists (despite disc/disc systems in competing trucks). The engine choices are similar: a 2.7-liter four-cylinder that makes 159 horsepower or a 3.5-liter V-6, replacing the previous 4.0-liter. The V-6, though, is truly new and contemporary in technology, raising output substantially, from the 4.0-liter’s 236 horsepower to 278.

There are three transmission choices: a five-speed manual that's standard with the four-cylinder, a six-speed manual that's standard with the V-6, and a six-speed automatic. And high-strength steel and selective stiffening have helped make the truck's structure more robust.

Fuel economy improves slightly, with EPA ratings that range from 19 mpg city/23 mpg highway with the base 2.7-liter engine, rear-wheel drive, and automatic transmission, to 19/24 mpg for the rear-wheel drive V-6 automatic. EPA ratings diminish with manual transmissions and/or all-wheel drive.
The four-wheel drive  is part time with a limited-slip differential and a two-speed electronic transfer case. Push a dashboard button, and you’re in high or low range.

This doesn’t seem to make much of a case for the four-cylinder engine, although there is a significant difference in MSRP.  The four-wheel drive-option is a part-time system, with a limited-slip differential and a two-speed electronic transfer case—just push a dashboard button, and you’re in either high or low range.

As you’d expect, the styling has been revitalized, with a front end treatment that’s more strongly reminiscent of the full-size Tundra pickup. The fender flares are a bit wider, putting a little more brawn into the look, and there’s 9.4 inches of ground clearance, to enhance suspension travel, part of an increased emphasis on off-road capability.

Inside, the Tacoma features a modern set of soft-touch and material upgrades, as well as more bright trim and increased infotainment and connectivity features. Most models come with cloth upholstery, but leather is available in the top-of-the-line Limited model.

Other new interior options include wireless charging, push-button start, dual-zone auto climate control, updated touchscreen audio, a blind spot monitor, rear cross-traffic alert, and a power moonroof.

Something that truck owners will appreciate is how much effort the development team spent on measures to reduce interior noise levels, including an acoustic glass windshield, improved seals, and more sound-deadening materials in the floors and headliners. Based on a day of preview driving on and off pavement, these measures seem to have been effective.

The new Tacoma will be offered in two body styles, both with a back seat. Access Cab seats four, using rear-hinged half doors for back-seat access. The Double Cab body style (shown here) has room for five, with four full doors. Rear seating is cramped in the Access Cab version, but the seats fold up to increase cargo capacity.

Speaking of cargo, there are two cargo bed lengths. Access Cab versions come with the longer of two at 73.3 inches (a little over six feet), while Double Cab models can be ordered with the long bed or the short (60.5 inches, just over five feet). The inner beds are fashioned from synthetic material, and thus don’t require bedliners, the tailgates are lockable, and there’s a little spoiler on the upper lip that Toyota claims enhances vehicle stability—without specifying what speed.

The tailgate also features a damped opening that eases it to horizontal, rather than slamming down. And the rear bumper design, carried over from the current Tacoma, makes it easy to climb into the cargo bed.

On pavement, the Tacoma is smooth, quiet, and mannerly, not what you’d expect of a truck, particularly one equipped for serious off-road use. Steering isn’t exactly sports-car precise, but as you may have noticed this isn’t a sports car.

Speaking of that, thanks to the more robust V-6, the Tacoma is now rated to tow up to 6,800 pounds, when equipped with the towing package. That’s a 300-pound improvement over the 2015 truck, and respectable for this size class—although it’s interesting to note that Toyota research places towing 22nd on the list of attributes Tacoma owners prioritize.

While the increase in V-6 power enhances the Tacoma’s work ethic, we have to say that it’s not particularly impressive in terms of stoplight getaway or passing on two-lane highways.

The Tacoma’s most impressive dynamic feature, showcased at this preview, was its new Crawl Control, available with four-wheel drive. For extreme up- or downhills, rock gardens, or deep sand, the driver simply engages Crawl Control and steers. The truck does the rest, at speeds between 2 and 5 mph.

The Verdict:

The Tacoma has ruled in this class for a long time, and figures to be a dominant player even with the arrival of impressive new rivals from General Motors. While it may not emerge as the absolute best in the mid-size comparison tests that are sure to come, and it lacks a diesel engine option (just introduced by GM), it offers twenty-nine different configurations, lots of features, Toyota’s reputation for durability and reliability, and high resale values.

Toyota puts heavy emphasis on the Tacoma’s off-road capabilities, something you’ll see in marketing messages for the new truck. The rationale, according to Toyota, is that some 40 percent of all Tacomas are acquired by young buyers who like to take their trucks to places lacking pavement or even roads. If that's you, the Tacoma is something to take a serious look at.

However, while the off-road versions may be a little extreme or irrelevant for the other 60 percent, there are other trim levels that are more mainstream—the SR5, well equipped, versatile, and affordable, and if luxury is important, the Limited model serves it up in competitive quantities.

Is a mid-size pickup right for you? Four- and five-passenger pickups have become popular as all-around haulers—the industry identifies them as lifestyle vehicles. Their usefulness and relatively tidy size (in contrast to full-size trucks) makes them attractive to men and women alike—and a sure way to enhance your neighborhood standing is to have one of these parked in your driveway. Your neighbors will be only too happy to put it to work.
Toyota's video from the Tacoma introduction

title: How Does a CVT Work?
subTitle: Everything you need to know to feel comfortable with a continuously variable transmission.
promoTeaserSmall: Everything you need to know to feel comfortable with a continuously variable transmission.
promoTeaser: Everything you need to know to feel comfortable with a continuously variable transmission.
metaTitle: How Does a CVT Work? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: buying a car with automatic transmission
metaDescription: Everything you need to know to feel comfortable with a continuously variable transmission.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: Did you know that about thirteen percent of new cars come equipped with a continuously variable transmission? To many people—possibly including you—that technology is an enigma. If you’ve heard anything about the CVT, it's likely that your feelings about it have been affected by the harsh opinions of hard-core car enthusiasts and late adopters, who may dislike or just distrust this type of automatic transmission.

Who likes CVTs? Auto companies, for a start. CVTs are currently available in vehicles from Audi, Honda, Hyundai, Mitsubishi, Subaru, Suzuki, and Toyota. General Motors and Chrysler are customers for the CVT made by one of Nissan’s suppliers.
What is a transmission that has no gears doing in so many cars, and how does it affect you?

Here's What a CVT Is

In simplest terms, a CVT, which is coupled to the engine, is a steel or aluminum case enclosing two grooved pulley wheels. Each pulley turns on its own shaft, and a rugged belt runs between them. One pulley receives the engine’s output and distributes it to the second pulley, which sends driving force to the wheels.

Inside the car, the driver selects Drive or Reverse, but otherwise there’s no need for shifting. In a way, having a car with a CVT isn’t so different from walking up the handicapped access ramp instead of climbing the stairs.

A CVT is compact, lightweight, and inexpensive. Without the teeth of large gears meshing with smaller ones, as in a traditional automatic or manual transmission, the car’s occupants feel no shift shock as it moves along.

And Here's How It Works

“Instead of the engine’s internal operating speed going up and down as you progress through fixed ratios, you vary the transmission ratios,” said Alex Fedorak, spokesman for Mitsubishi, which has CVTs in several vehicles.

Variability enters the picture when electronic calculations call for hydraulic pressure to be applied to the pulleys, making one wider and the other narrower. How wide or narrow depends on the driver’s input. At low speed, the pulley receiving the engine’s output widens and the other pulley narrows. When the car is barreling down the road, the opposite occurs.

The belt, which is somewhat V-shaped, climbs or drops between the pulleys’ widened or narrowed sheaves. This creates an effect similar to the different ratios between fixed gears. 
 
Thanks to the CVTs mediation, the engine’s internal operating speed stays more constant. As the result, though, the car tends to moo like an unmilked cow rather than roaring like a bull. Some have also noted an odd floating feeling, as if the engine and wheels aren’t precisely engaged.

And Here's Why It's a Good Thing

But the advantage of the CVT—why manufacturers are pushing them in the marketplace—is found in superb fuel economy.
For example, the 2016 Honda Fit LX with standard 6-speed manual transmission achieves 29 city/37 highway mpg. With the available CVT, fuel economy jumps to 33 city/41 highway mpg.
Also, Fedorak observes, “You can control emissions much more efficiently.”

But Here's What People Have Against It

Meanwhile, complaints about the unusual feeling of driving a CVT-equipped car are being addressed.

On Oahu three years ago, I sampled the Subaru XV Crosstrek, then a new model and one of the first to offer a “stepped” CVT. It allows the driver to use steering-wheel-mounted paddle shifters to manually select and hold simulated, electronically controlled fixed ratios. The feature proved useful when kicking down to a passing gear on the highway. In addition, the test course included a muddy off-road section where churning along in a low gear was desirable.

A stepped CVT can have other benefits as well. To keep the driver involved and take away the impression of indefiniteness, the Toyota Corolla S has a CVT that includes seven simulated ratios and a sport mode for more aggressive action among them. The Subaru WRX has a CVT with eight steps.

Fedorak moved to Mitsubishi in 2014, where he renewed his familiarity with CVTs and realized how much progress has been made in delivering performance like that of a conventional automatic transmission. “If you pay close attention to your tachometer, you’ll notice the difference,” he said. “It wasn’t real evident to me right away. That’s how good the programming of them has become.”
What about the longevity questions that have sometimes surrounded CVTs?
Fedorak says any of today’s CVTs “uses a belt that’s made out of steel links. It’s much, much, much more durable. The belts are nothing to worry about. They’re very sturdy, very massive.”

So, Should You Get One on Your Next Car?

So if the CVT performs well enough, why even think about it? Because there may be different requirements for service, like having the transmission fluid changed rather frequently. For instance, Nissan Cube owners engage in lively online debates over the question of service intervals, with some advocating fluid changes—which cost around $250—every 30,000 miles.

Otherwise, as the CVT delivers an improving driving experience and won’t leave you stranded along the road, there’s no reason to think about this transmission any more than the one in your washing machine. Oh, yes, it has a transmission, too.

title: 2017 Bentley Bentayga
subTitle: An SUV to end all SUVs makes a splashy debut at the Frankfurt Auto Show.
promoTeaserSmall: An SUV to end all SUVs makes a splashy debut at the Frankfurt Auto Show.
promoTeaser: An SUV to end all SUVs makes a splashy debut at the Frankfurt Auto Show.
metaDescription: An SUV to end all SUVs makes a splashy debut at the Frankfurt Auto Show.

pageElements.text:
Type: Ultra-indulgent five-to-six-passenger sport-utility vehicle
Release date: Early 2016
Estimated price: Starting just under $200,000
Competes against: Range Rover
What’s most interesting: All-new 6.0-liter twin-turbocharged W-12 engine making 600 horsepower and 663 pound-feet of torque

The Bentley Bentayga is a high-luxury sport-utility vehicle that can go anywhere, if you’re brave enough to take a vehicle this expensive everywhere. The all-new suspension has four on-road settings handle just about everything, operated through a single rotary dial. But wait, there’s more: an additional four off-road modes handle Snow & Grass, Dirt & Gravel, Mud & Trail, and Sand Dunes.

Inside, you’ll find everything you’d expect from a Bentley SUV: diamond-quilted leather seats “inspired by finely tailored hunting jackets.” Heated and ventilated seats with six massage program settings and up to twenty-two ways to adjust them. Wood-veneer trim all the way to the rear console and the optional picnic tables. Technology is the latest, including electronic infrared night vision.

Even more personalization comes from custom division Mulliner, which can fit a bespoke three-piece picnic hamper set that doubles as a set of outdoor seats, with a refrigerator compartment inside. Or choose a Breitling Mulliner Tourbillon, in rose or white gold with mother-of-pearl or ebony face and diamond indexes. Get this: the car has a dedicated drive to wind the watch for you.
Coming soon are a clean diesel and a plug-in hybrid version, plus a seven-seater Bentayga. Something for everyone (who has money)!

images.caption: 2017 Bentley Bentayga event seat and hampers.

title: 5 Cool Things about the 2016 Honda Civic
subTitle: 2016 model is sleeker and more tech laden.
promoTitle: 5 Cool Things about the 2016 Honda Civic
promoTeaserSmall: Wrap your heads around the fact that this is a Civic!
promoTeaser: Wrap your heads around the fact that this is a Civic!
keywords: 5 Cool Things about the Honda Civic
metaTitle: 5 Cool Things about the 2016 Honda Civic - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2016 model is sleeker and more tech laden. Wrap your heads around the fact that this is a Civic!

pageElements.text: The Honda Civic looked so small, so...economical, when it first reached the United States some forty years ago. Back then, its very size was revolutionary, and it quickly set about creating a fan base that has grown exponentially over the years.

How things have changed. The all-new tenth-generation Civic sedan was introduced in Los Angeles on Sept. 16. It's longer, lower, and sportier in appearance than anything a Civic buyer of the 1970s could have imagined. Thirty-five million people worldwide have bought a Civic; we have a feeling that number is going to take a jump once the all-new model comes out this fall.
If you had any doubt that Honda has just given the Civic's substantial customer base something to drool over, one look will convince you.
Or maybe five looks? Here are five cool things we noticed about the 2016 Civic.

1. There's a turbo. It's an all-new 1.5-liter four-cylinder teamed with a continuously variable transmission, tipped to exceed 40 mpg on the highway. You'll find it on the EX-T, EX-L, and Touring models. This is the first turbocharged engine on a U.S. Honda and will offer more power than any U.S. Civic has ever had that's not an Si model.
The standard engine on the new Civic is a 2.0-liter four-cylinder, which you can pair with a six-speed manual or a continuously variable automatic transmission.

2. It's a smartphone user's dream. Apple CarPlay and Android Auto are both enabled, letting you use your favorite apps—from Google Maps to your Apple music collection—from the Civic's 7.0-inch touchscreen.

3. It is amazingly spacious. Honda is really, really good at optimizing interior space, and the new Civic is no exception. The automaker has added 3.7 more cubic feet, including 2.7 more cubic feet in the trunk, and added two inches of rear-seat legroom over the 2015 model. The driver's seat rides lower in this wider, longer body, and even the center console is more capable with up to 7.2 liters' worth of enclosed storage capability up front.

4. It has the latest in advanced safety technology. Honda has rolled out its Honda Sensing suite of tech on its 2016 CR-V, Pilot, and Accord, and the Civic will have it available. Adaptive Cruise Control with Low-Speed Follow (a blessing in stop-and-go traffic, giving your right leg a rest while it safely creeps along for you) will make its first appearance on a Honda. There's also collision mitigation braking (automatically applying brake pressure when it senses that you're not hitting the brakes hard enough to avoid colliding with the car ahead of you) and road departure mitigation, an engineering marvel that uses the steering and brakes to help keep you from inadvertently driving off a marked roadway. It's triggered between 45 and 90 mph when you're drifting too close to the right lane marking line without your right turn signal on.

5. A Civic Type-R is coming. Yes, performance fans, the first ever Civic Type-R for U.S. buyers, promises American Honda communications chief Sage Marie. The rest of the lineup will include a coupe, a sportier Si model, and a five-door hatchback, all rolling out this fall after the sedan (and not yet shown to the public).
Pricing has not yet been announced.

title: 2016 Ford Explorer Platinum
subTitle: Should you spring for the top-end model of the all-new SUV? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: Should you spring for the top-end model of the all-new SUV? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: Should you spring for the top-end model of the all-new SUV? Here's what we think.
metaDescription: Should you spring for the top-end model of the all-new SUV? Here's what we think.

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-passenger, all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Base price (base Explorer with front-wheel drive): $31,995 (all prices include destination charge)
Base price (Explorer Platinum): $53,915
Price as tested: $54,760
Engine: Turbocharged 3.5-liter V-6, 365 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/22 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS): Good in three areas, Marginal on small overlap front crash test
My favorite standard feature: 10.1-inch infotainment touchscreen
Notable standard features on this model: 20-inch aluminum alloy wheels; power moonroof; 10.1-inch display screen; navigation; premium Sony audio; brushed aluminum and ash wood interior trim; perforated, heated and ventilated leather upholstery; adaptive cruise control; heated wood and leather steering wheel with power tilt and telescope; rearview camera; blind spot detection
Notable options on this model: Second-row captain's chairs with center console ($845)
You might also be considering: Acura MDX, Audi Q7, Buick Enclave, Infiniti QX60, Land Rover LR4, Lexus GX, Volvo XC90, Lincoln MKT
What’s this? A $54,760 Explorer? Really?

Well, why not? America has been demonstrating an increasing appetite for luxury in its vehicle selections, and Ford’s marketing mavens see an opportunity to cash in. Never mind that a luxury version of the Explorer steps on its corporate cousin, the Lincoln MKT, from the division that Ford is working so hard to revitalize.
So what distinguishes the Explorer Platinum from the Explorer Sport, the previous top-of-the-line version, base price (including destination charge) $44,445?

There are some details unique to the Platinum edition—a 10.1-inch center dash digital display; leather upholstery, including heated and ventilated seats up front and some fancy stitching; a 500-watt Sony audio system with twelve speakers; a heated wood-and-leather rim steering wheel; brushed aluminum interior trim; and a brushed aluminum Ford badge affixed to the center of the steering wheel hub.
That’s Nirvana leather, by the way.

But, mostly, stepping up to Platinum will net you just about everything available in the Explorer option catalog: all-wheel drive, dual power moonroof, navigation, you name it. The only extra-cost option on the model I drove is second-row captain’s chairs with a center console, $845.

To demonstrate the Platinum package, Ford put together an unusual rally, beginning in Vancouver, British Columbia, and finishing up in Albuquerque. It wound through nine cities, covering 1,278 miles and involving 187 journalists in the driving.

Our segment started at Big Sky, near Bozeman, Montana, and concluded near Jackson, Wyoming. The idea was to develop your own driving adventure—within the constraints of the starting point and destination, of course. Our adventure was a visit to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the Old Faithful geyser spout boiling water into the sky, saw a bison ambling down the middle of the road—no one was inclined to contest his right of way—and enjoyed the beautiful scenery.

A minor footnote was a Forest Service roadblock that required a minor detour to get to our destination hotel. This was caused by a visitation of black bears, who’d come down from the nearby Grand Teton mountains to munch on a bumper crop of wild berries. Unfortunately, we didn’t really get a look at the bears.

Through all of this, the Explorer Platinum comported itself competently and unobtrusively. The chassis engineers note specific suspension tuning for this edition, which we’d guess is a little softer than that of the Sport and a little firmer than the other Explorers. Be that as it may, ride quality was smooth, although smooth also applies to the highways we traveled as well as the operation of the six-speed automatic transmission.
Even with its biggest of Explorer engines—a 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6—acceleration can’t be called much better than adequate.

Even with its biggest of Explorer engines—a 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6—acceleration can’t be called much better than adequate. We dipped into the V-6’s power reservoirs frequently once clear of the national park, passing vacationers who were in no hurry, and making these passes required a fair amount of advance planning.

However, to be fair, this is a vehicle that weighs pretty close to 5,000 pounds, and our route entailed altitude—between 5,000 and 7,000 feet. Altitude is the enemy of horsepower, and we’re sure this fanciest of Explorers will perform more vigorously closer to sea level. It also dilutes fuel economy, but we didn’t check mpg for our trek. The EPA rates this setup for 16 mpg city, 22 highway, lowest in the Explorer lineup.

One other Explorer Platinum trait that merits mention: a lack of cabin noise. Ford cites noise reduction as a key development target for this edition, and we have to say mission accomplished. Quiet operation is a key component of vehicle comfort, and the Explorer Platinum is among the best in its class on this key metric.

The Verdict:

There's no doubt that the Explorer Platinum goes about its business with quiet competence, made better by the fact that it is loaded with luxury features. So, should you consider paying the substantial price premium for the top-of-the-line Explorer? You'll be paying a $10,000 premium over the Explorer Sport—which carries it into competition against some of the many prestige three-row luxury utes in this price class—but for those who want both luxury and a Ford Explorer, it's a good choice to have.

title: 2016 Alfa Romeo 4C
subTitle: Lightweight but serious, and seriously beautiful.
promoTeaserSmall: Lightweight but serious, and seriously beautiful.
promoTeaser: Lightweight but serious, and seriously beautiful.
metaDescription: Lightweight but serious, and seriously beautiful.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-passenger, rear-wheel-drive coupe or convertible
Price range: $55,495 - $69,995 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: 4C, 4C Launch Edition, Spider
Engine: 1.75-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 237 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/34 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Leather-wrapped steering wheel
Notable standard features on this model: Halogen projector headlamps, 7.0-inch infotainment screen, remote keyless entry
Notable options on this model: Dual racing exhaust, leather package, bi-xenon projector headlamps
You might also be considering: BMW M3, Chevrolet Corvette, Porsche Cayman

The Alfa Romeo 4C is a hot car. Boasting strong sweeping lines, a sleek profile, and classic styling, this vehicle will turn heads. Beyond that, it will provide a satisfyingly engaging experience behind the wheel, the main point of this carbon-fiber-bodied two-seater. A 1.75-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine, teamed with a six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission with Launch Control and paddle shifters, produces 237 horsepower. What's Launch Control? It's triggered when you press on the brake, fully push down the accelerator, and touch the left steering wheel paddle. Release the brake, and the Launch Control system controls the transmission, power, and traction for maximized acceleration.  Top speed: 160 mph. You can use the Driving Mode selector to choose All Weather, Natural, Dynamic, or Race modes. This is not a car for comfort but one for excitement. The 4C and 4C Launch Edition are coupes, while the Spider has a cloth top; a carbon fiber hard top is coming later in 2016. Personalization choices include track packages, six wheel options, and four choices of brake calipers, as well as extra-cost color options that give you more than one kind of red to choose from.
New for 2016: A carbon fiber hard top is planned for later in the year on the Spider.

More to Read:

2015 Alfa Romeo 4C Spider

title: Porsche Mission E Concept
subTitle: Porsche's electric-car plans come thrillingly to life in this concept.
promoTeaserSmall: Porsche's electric-car plans come thrillingly to life in this concept.
promoTeaser: Porsche's electric-car plans come thrillingly to life in this concept.
metaDescription: Porsche's electric-car plans come thrillingly to life in this concept.

pageElements.text: Without using the phrase "Tesla fighter," it's hard to fully appreciate the Porsche Mission E concept that was unveiled at the 2015 Frankfurt Auto Show. That's because this car, Porsche's first all-electric sports car, is promised to go on sale in less than five years, and is unmistakably going to be a strong Tesla competitor when it gets here.

Consider the specs. It will charge in fifteen minutes to 80 percent of battery capacity. Its full range on a charge is more than 300 miles. It has two permanent magnet synchronous motors (like the power behind this year's 24 Hours of Le Mans winner, the Porsche 919 Hybrid), making a total of 600 horsepower. It will go from 0 to 62 mph in less than 3.5 seconds. It has all-wheel drive, all-wheel steering, and an alluring aluminum, steel, and carbon fiber polymer body.

Porsche calls its dedicated charger the Porsche Turbo Charging system, a good riposte to Tesla's Supercharger moniker. This 800-volt port is what gives the Mission E its lightning-quick fifteen-minute charge time. You can also connect the Mission E to a 400-volt charging station.
Some of the coolest features on this concept include the use of cameras to replace side mirrors, and the use of holograms to adjust the five round instrument panel binnacles to the driver's position.

No matter how you feel about electric sports cars, you can't deny that competition will be good for the marketplace. Maybe, in the not-too-distant future, these will actually come down enough in price that the more budget-minded shoppers among us can justify owning one.

The Enclave ranks high in the highly sought after crossover/ sport-utility vehicle category. With Buick’s classic luxury and value and a classic design, this car will satisfy the wants and needs of a wide range of customers. The Enclave can seat either seven or eight depending on your desired configuration, so space is not a concern. The 3.6-lter V-6 delivers a nice hit of power, and a six-speed automatic is the only available transmission. The standard features on this vehicle are geared toward the family. A storage system under the rear floor, power windows, remote starter, and rearview camera all work to make mom or dad’s life just a little bit easier. The options class the Enclave up even further. pageElements.text: Practicality is probably not the first word that comes to mind when you think of BMW, and the X4 does not prove you wrong. With the same engines and wheelbases, the X4 and X3 feel like siblings, except if the two went to the fair the X4 wouldn’t be tall enough to get on any of the rides. With only 37.4 inches of rear headroom and shrunken cargo capacity, the X4 offers significantly less space than the X3. You’ll still get BMW’s high quality standard features, including heated mirrors, a power tailgate and Bluetooth, but if you want blind spot detection or a rearview camera, you’ll have to pay for it. And when comparing apples to apples, the X4 is more expensive than the X3. However, what the X4 lacks in practicality it makes up for in sleekness. You can retain your SUV-style commanding view of the road without anyone thinking for one second you’re a soccer mom.
New for 2016: Enhanced Bluetooth (Mobile Office, Bluetooth sync for second phone, iSpeech)

You might also be considering: Audi A4, Mercedes-Benz C-Class, Cadillac ATS

If there is one BMW you should be familiar with, the iconic, classic, longtime favorite of enthusiasts 3 Series is it. Available in sedan, wagon, or hatchback form and offering five different engines—including a diesel—and in rear- or all-wheel-drive (xDrive) form, the 3 Series can be molded to your wants and needs. There’s also good news for all of the stick-shifting fanatics out there; you can have a six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic transmission. The 3 Series is highlighting its sportiness even further in 2016 as the Sport Line now comes standard on the Gran Turismo, 328i, 328d, and 340i (xDrive included). Speaking of standard, rain-sensing wipers, automatic headlights, and BMW Assist eCall all come standard. Unfortunately, you’ll have to pay for features like rearview camera, active blind spot alert, and navigation. Owning a 3 Series is an adventure in driving excitement and offers an ability to be in tune with your vehicle that its adepts claim is shared with few other cars out there.
New for 2016: Sport Line is now standard on BMW 3 Series xDrive Gran Turismo, 328i, 328d, 340i (including xDrive); new 340i features new engine, new 330e plug-in hybrid.

title: 2016 Nissan Altima
subTitle: Number two in the segment and trying harder.
promoTeaserSmall: Number two in the segment and trying harder.
promoTeaser: Number two in the segment and trying harder.
metaDescription: Number two in the segment and trying harder.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Trim levels: 2.5 (base, S, SR, SV, SL); 3.5 (SR, SL)
Base price: $23,325 (price includes destination charge)
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 185 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6, 270 horsepower
Transmission: Xtronic continuously variable automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 2.5: 27 mpg city/39 mpg highway; 3.5: 22/32 mpg
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated; 2015 model was Top Safety Pick
Competition: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Mazda 6, Toyota Camry

The Nissan Altima is only one of a huge number of competitors in the popular mid-size sedan segment. Faced with so many other choices, a shopper would do well to wonder, what is so special about the Altima? Nissan answered that question by updating the look and performance of the Altima for 2016—and by adding a new SR model that's sportier both in look and feel.

The Altima now looks more like the flowing designs you see in the Murano and the Maxima. The change is particularly noticeable on the front end, with a V-shaped grille and new headlamps; LED lights are an available option. Inside, the interior also echoes the look of the Murano and Maxima with a redesigned center console and information display. The standard infotainment screen is 5.0 inches and includes Siri Eyes Free hands-free voice command technology on all but the base 2.5 model, but there's an optional 7.0-inch touchscreen infotainment screen with voice recognition, 3D-effect maps, and navigation; that comes on the 2.5 SV and SL and the 3.5 SL. The optional Nissan Connect with Mobile Apps offers hands-free text messaging and steering-wheel-mounted text commands (that say such things as "driving, can't text").

Safety technology is one good reason to buy a new car these days, and the Altima gets a new option that other mid-size sedans don't have (yet): predictive forward collision warning, which senses the velocity and distance of vehicles two cars ahead. There's also blind spot warning (standard on SV and SL models), intelligent cruise control and forward emergency braking (both part of the optional SL Tech package), and rear cross-traffic alert.

As their names suggest, the Altima 2.5 models have a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine, while the 3.5 models get a 3.5-liter V-6. The new-for-2016 Altima SR can be had with either engine and additionally gets eighteen-inch wheels and tires, a suspension stiffened and tuned for a sportier feel, and a set of paddle shifters for more fun.

Nissan proudly cites a strong upward trend in sales of the Altima, which is now number two in sales behind only the Toyota Camry. If you've overlooked this car in the past, you're increasingly in the minority these days.
New for 2016: The Altima has been redesigned for 2016; new sportier SR model available in both 2.5-liter four-cylinder and 3.5-liter V-6 versions.

More to Read:

2016 Nissan Altima Rolls Out, by Jean Jennings

images.caption: New for 2016: Sportier Nissan Altima SR.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
If you have a roadside assistance card in your wallet, maybe you think you’ve got any roadside emergencies covered. But even so, it’s important to know a few basic survival skills in case you ever find yourself stranded where a service truck can’t get to you or will take too long. Having jumper cables in the car is de rigueur in frigid northern climates, but these practical accessories are really an important part of anyone’s automotive emergency kit.

The skill of jump-starting a car sits right up there with knowing how to change a tire. You might not want to, but you should know how. Be the person who can handle the situation when you walk out of that night baseball game and realize you’ve left your lights on and killed the battery—or someone else has.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ZU7hGSZ1pA4" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Here are five steps to a successful jump start. Watch my video for the demonstration.

1. Get out the owner’s manual and look at the safety warnings.

Take them seriously! The manual will also help you locate the battery in case it has been placed in some strange location in your car (or the other person’s). Sometimes it's even in the trunk.

2. Prepare the two vehicles.

This will usually mean pulling the helper car as close as possible to the one with the dead battery, without having them touch. Then set the parking brake; turn off the ignition, lights, radio, and other accessories in both cars; and make sure nothing such as phones or iPods is hooked in to accessory ports in either vehicle.

3. Hook up the jumper cables, making sure not to let the metal ends of the cables touch each other.

Make sure to attach the cables to both cars in the correct sequence. Positive, red (marked +) cables hook up first. Do it in this (circular) sequence: (1) Attach a red cable to the positive terminal on the good battery. (2) Attach the other red cable to the positive terminal on the dead battery. (3) Attach a black, negative (marked -) cable to the negative terminal on the dead battery. (4) Hook the other black cable on to a clean metal part inside the donor car, away from the battery.
4. Fire up the donor car and let it run for a few minutes.

5. Fire up the car with the dead battery and let it run for a few minutes.

Keep the cables hooked up to both cars. Then remove in reverse order: negative (black) cables first, then positive (red) cables. Once you’ve got the car started, drive the car for at least fifteen to twenty minutes to help the battery recharge before you shut it off. If this doesn’t work after two to three attempts, call the tow truck for expert help!

title: 5 Cool Things about Tesla's Model X
subTitle: The long-awaited electric crossover  will go on sale in late 2016.
promoTitle: 5 Cool Things about Tesla's Model X
promoTeaserSmall: The long-awaited electric crossover will go on sale in late 2016.
promoTeaser: The long-awaited electric crossover will go on sale in late 2016.
keywords: 5 Cool Things about Tesla's Model X
metaTitle: 5 Cool Things about Tesla's Model X - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The long-awaited electric crossover will go on sale in late 2016.

pageElements.text: There are naysayers about Tesla, the car company that wants to do everything differently, but we are not among them. Definitely an oddball, Elon Musk is a creative oddball, and you can’t argue that he has just come up with another fascinating model that takes us further down the road to making the electric car look truly desirable.

Musk says the point of his car company is “to accelerate the advent of sustainable transport.”  Part of that mission is to show that any type of vehicle can be electric, which Tesla Motors has shown with its roadster and sedan—both critical and popular hits. Next up: the SUV, so here is the Model X. People want versatility, three rows of seats, towing capability, and spaciousness. Musk’s plan is to make that a sustainable choice, and who can argue with that?

Prices haven’t been announced yet, but Elon Musk said this week that it will start only $5,000 higher than the Model S, which is currently priced at $76,200 before tax incentives. “Lower-cost versions coming later,” he added in a tweet.
Here are five cool things to know about the 2017 Tesla Model X while waiting for its on-sale date in late 2016.

1. It seats seven and has the “utility” that a sport-utility vehicle requires. It also tows up to 5,000 pounds while carrying seven people and their gear. In that, even though it doesn’t look much like one, it’s a real utility vehicle. There is an accessory bike hitch that can be put on in seconds and carries up to four bicycles while allowing full access to the trunk area.

2. It has cool falcon-wing doors. Guess what inspired them? Not sci-fi, but the fact that Musk has a set of twins and a set of triplets, so he knows about the hassle of car seat wrangling. (Not that anyone thinks he installs them himself, of course.) Access to the second row is simplified with the doors up above the vehicle, and the second-row seats are quick to slide for full access to the third row of seats. Better still: The car has ultrasonic sensors in the roof that automatically compute the height of the ceiling and any obstacles to the side, so you don’t bark the tops against the garage walls.
While we’re talking about cool doors, the front doors detect your presence and open for you, then close for you once you’re seated in the Model X. An “invisible chauffeur,” as Musk described it.

3. More to the point, there are 257 miles of range between charges, and an indecent amount of speed. With all-wheel drive and that kind of range, you can still reach a top speed of 155 mph and go from 0 to 60 mph in 4.8 seconds. But the P90D model has Ludicrous mode, with which you get 250 miles of range and 0 to 60 mph in 3.2 seconds (“so fast it’s wrong,” Musk said).

4. The interior air quality is comparable to a hospital’s operating room. We tweeted this week about the frankly huge air filter and the Bioweapon Defense Mode setting, which gives you a completely protective interior environment in case of, you know, some kind of WMD attack. In the absence of that, you can enjoy the fact that the Model X cuts virus, bacteria, pollen, and pollution levels down to practically unmeasurable levels. And you actually are going to run into those in your travels. Our only question: How much is it going to cost to replace that immense air filter, and how often do you have to?

5. With five-star ratings in every category, it’s tipped as the safest SUV ever. The large battery pack extends across the base of the vehicle, lowering the center of gravity and serving as a load transfer mechanism in a side impact, so you have half the rollover risk of a traditional SUV. One look at the Model X tells you that, since it looks so unlike a historically tall-bodied SUV. It also has a huge crumple zone in front without an engine up there. Automatic emergency braking and side collision avoidance technology are standard features, too.

images.caption: The Tesla Model X with its falcon-wing doors open.
Tesla Model X has an immense moonroof.
Tesla Model X's attractive second row of seating.
Tesla Model X with bike or snowboard rack attached.
The Tesla Model X's doors have sensors to work around obstacles above and to the sides.
Tesla Model X's front doors act like a virtual chauffeur.
Tesla Model X's HVAC choices include one intended to protect against bioweapons.
Easily moved seats in the second row of the Tesla Model X.
Tesla Model X's enormous air filter.

title: 9 Driving Behaviors Everyone Hates
subTitle: (So don’t be that person.)

pageElements.text: In this age of smartphones and touchscreens, any driver would be forgiven for worrying about whether the other drivers around him or her are watching the road instead of texting or programming music using Pandora. It’s like flying—it’s so bad out there that you just have to lower your expectations (and heart rate) so you don’t lose your mind. That’s why it’s even more important to make your own driving be the change you want to see in the world. Start by eliminating these ten really bad moves, which at best may just be supremely annoying and at worst may provoke road rage. Here we go.
1. Inching forward at stop signs or corners, making the people driving past you think you are about to T-bone them. Don’t you hate that?

2. Tailgating. This is not the same as dipping into other drivers’ personal space for a brief interval before you get back to a safe following distance. What is that safe distance? That would be three seconds in perfect weather. One-one thousand, two-one thousand, three-one thousand.

3. Driving mindlessly below the speed limit when road conditions don’t indicate you need to. This will mean you have decided to ignore or be unaware of other drivers lining up behind you. On the interstate, this usually means you are on your phone, being the stupidest, most thoughtless, most dangerous driver on the planet.
4. Letting your mind wander—ever—but more specifically at a four-way stop so you aren’t sure when it’s your turn. The turn, by the way, always passes to the car to the right.
5. Whipping out your phone at a stoplight to check your texts and failing to notice when it’s time to go. Thoughtless wretch.

6. Using your horn as an instrument of terror. It’s for emergencies. It’s for a light tap if the car in front of you is engaging in behavior #5. It is not for a long, angry blast as you shoot past a line of cars holding you back from total road domination.

7. Practicing highway vigilantism—brake-checking or deliberately slowing down when another car is following too close, adjusting your speed specifically to keep someone else from passing you, revenge tailgating—is a really bad idea. Paybacks to other drivers who are breaking the social contract isn’t your responsibility. It’s really bad for your blood pressure and it’s how people get shot. Take a deep cleansing breath.

8. Getting into any relationship with another driver. It is bound to be a bad one. (Re-read #7.) No flipping the middle finger. No shouting out your window, especially horrifying to your passengers. And don’t let your passengers do it for you.

9. There is a special place in Hell for drivers who drive on the shoulder in construction and accident traffic to get to the front or to get off the next exit. There is also a really big fine if you get caught.
