pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive midsize sedan
Trim levels: LX, LX 1.6T, EX, SX, SXL
Base price: $22,665 (base LX, with 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine); $30,515 (SX) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $35,315
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine, 247 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/32 mpg highway
Safety: Not yet rated
Competitors (prices include destination charge):
2016 Mazda 6 Grand Touring ($31,015)
2016 Ford Fusion Titanium ($31,505)
2016 Volkswagen Passat SEL Premium ($32,610)

Fun-O-Meter: 8

Five years. That’s how fast the world of Kia has moved off its axis. When Kia launched its third-generation Optima in 2011, it signaled the beginning of something very big from the Korean company known for its inexpensive econocars and their forgettable sheetmetal. This suddenly lovely Optima was the first under the direction of the immensely talented new chief designer, Peter Schreyer, who left Audi at the top of his game. It was as remarkable a transformation as any Audi he’d ever done, from drab to fab so fast that it became Kia’s first model to reach 150,000 in sales in a year, which was a 480% improvement from 2010 sales.

As word spread and awards began to roll in (Cars.com’s Best of 2011, finalist for Motor Trend’s Car of the Year, nominated for Car and Driver’s Ten Best, among the most significant), Optima sales blew up, tripling in 2011 and then nearly doubling again in 2012, and holding steady right through this past September. Over the past five years of its life, the Optima’s second-best month was recorded in May of this year. That is serious staying power.

So if you think that this fourth-generation Optima hasn’t strayed far from the previous model, well, yeah. Or in the words of the top brass: “The current car has been great for us for five years. We just refined it. We didn’t want to screw it up. It’s the most important vehicle in our franchise.”

Ah, but it has changed, and changed for the better in so many ways. It has gained a skosh in every important dimension—length, height, and width. The amalgamation of a half-inch here and there and that 1.2-inch extra width makes the cabin more comfortable for life-size humans. It also adds cargo space, “optimizes” the car’s performance in new offset crash standards, and gives the Optima more presence all the way around. Inside, the dashboard area is beautifully laid out more thoughtfully than before. It is designed to be more horizontal, and that glorious eight-inch touchscreen has matte glass so it doesn’t have that reflectiveness that is so annoying in other cars.
Kia’s first ever bi-xenon HID lights can be optioned with Dynamic Bending Lamps. You turn the steering wheel, and those lights turn with you. They are fantastic.

The sheetmetal is changed only subtly. A sharp new version of Kia’s signature grille now flows perfectly into redesigned headlamps. Those headlamps are worthy of a special mention. They’re Kia’s first ever bi-xenon HID lights, and they can be optioned with Dynamic Bending Lamps. You turn the steering wheel, and those lights turn with you; it’s a technology I first tested on a 1983 Oldsmobile 98, then across the German carmakers, beginning with high-end Mercedes-Benzes and on down to the Volkswagen Golf. Congrats, Kia. They are fantastic.

Our SX test car is the second-highest of five Optima trim levels, seriously loaded for $30,515. It had only one optional package, but it was a doozy both in cost and content. For $4,800, the Premium Technology package includes a power front passenger’s seat, heated and ventilated front seats, heated outboard rear seats, and high-beam assist to go with the standard active-cornering HID headlights. It also includes a vast array of driver assistance technology, sensibly named to give you a good clue as to each one’s function, from the increasingly common smart cruise control, blind spot detection, and lane departure warning systems to rear cross-traffic detection, front collision warning, a 360-degree view surround-view mirror (which you will consider to be pure magic), and autonomous emergency braking, which can bring the Optima to a complete stop when it senses you aren’t cutting it. Did not test that.

Bundled right in the middle of all this tech and safety—and a goodly chunk of that $4,800—is a panoramic sunroof that completely covered the rear seating area, and Kia’s first offering of Harman Kardon’s most trick QLS surround sound system. This (also pure magic) super stereo has the ability to extract signals from an original recording and redistribute them for a clearer and more detailed sound; it uses an amazing patented technology that can rebuild audio signals lost in the digital compression process.

Can you tell I think this package is worth the price? Alternatively, you can jump up to the highest of Optimas, the SXL, for $36,615, all-in. It adds rich quilted Nappa leather trim and a wireless charging pad for your phone, a feature which becomes more desirable as Android Auto and Apple CarPlay become available “two to three months” into the launch stream of the new Optima.
The Optima was always known as a better than average sport. According to the 100-mile Rocky Mountain test loop I spent the day flying around, it is now serious business.

The Optima was always known as a better than average sport, but according to the 100-mile high Rocky Mountain test loop I spent the day flying around, it is now serious business. Blasting over Independence Pass at an elevation of 12,095 feet on the Continental Divide, I noticed zero effect on the engine’s power, even as I noticed the altitude’s totally yucky effect on my brain and lungs. Time to descend.

Coming down that mountain to Aspen (elevation 7,890 feet) was the ultimate test for the brakes and the new electric power steering. I love practicing carving the smoothest path possible on a mountain road. Downhill. At speed. It was sublime, thanks to the manumatic feature of the six-speed automatic which allowed me to flick the shifter up and down through turn after turn.

A lighter, stiffer chassis and the use of a lot more structural adhesive and high-strength steel in the body made a world of difference in the new Optima’s high-speed stability, super-connected steering response, and all-around sports car feel. I had a great day driving in unbelievable scenery, and my passenger did not throw up. Bonus.

The 2016 Optima is coming out of Kia’s plant in Georgia, so Southern showrooms will see the new Optima first in October, followed by the rest of the country starting in early  November to December. And if you’re more like the 40 percent of Optima buyers who traditionally buy the entry-level LX, you’ll be pleased to note that this base model has more standard features than ever, at the same $22,665 price.
I had a great day driving in unbelievable scenery, and my passenger did not throw up. Bonus.

The next five years will be another lightning round of change for Kia as it rolls out twenty-two new or significantly revised products, including hybrid and plug-in versions of the Optima that are coming out in early 2016. This is a good time to remember that Kia is currently in second place behind only Porsche in the prestigious J.D. Power Initial Quality Study. It is among Consumer Reports’ 2015 Top Ten in brand reliability. And it still comes with a ten-year/100,000-mile warranty—one of the best in the business.

title: Happy Halloween! 13 Orange Cars
subTitle: They’re wild, they’re cheerful. Why settle for vanilla when you can get pumpkin spice latte?
promoTeaserSmall: They’re wild, they’re cheerful. Why settle for vanilla when you can get pumpkin spice latte?
promoTeaser: They’re wild, they’re cheerful. Why settle for vanilla when you can get pumpkin spice latte?
metaDescription: They’re wild, they’re cheerful. Why settle for vanilla when you can get pumpkin spice latte?

pageElements.text: When you shop for a new car, do you go for the time-honored silver, white, or black exterior color? Millions of people do. Those are perfectly reasonable, sane, mature choices.
So boring.

If there’s ever a little voice in your head telling you to live a little, you’ll appreciate this gallery of brilliantly orange cars in every price range. At Halloween or any time of year, a car in orange will stand out, liven up the traffic, and make you smile. Just for fun, we’ve given them a Pumpkin-o-Meter rating, based on how good they look in orange. Prices include any extra charges for the orange paint job. Sometimes you just have to suffer for your art.

1. 2016 Ford Fiesta ST

Color name: Molten Orange
Base price: $22,440
Extra cost for orange? $595
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 7
Comments: Ford wisely saved this wild orange for the sporty model.

2. 2016 Chevrolet Trax LTZ

Color name: Orange Rock Metallic
Base price: $26,125
Extra cost for orange? No
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 6
Comments: Hot colors look great on little cars.

3. 2015 Fiat 500 Sport and 2016 Fiat 500X

Color name: Rame (500 Sport); Arancio (500X)
Base prices: $18,680 (500 Sport); $20,900 (500X)
Extra cost for orange? No
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 6.5
Comments: If any car should be a crazy color, the Fiat 500 is it.

4. 2016 Hyundai Veloster Turbo

Base price: $23,435

Base price: $74,543

9. 2016 BMW Z4

Color name: Valencia Orange
Base price: $53,245
Extra cost for orange? $550
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 4
Comments: An orange BMW? No. Just no.

title: Top Ten from the Tokyo Auto Show
subTitle: The weirdest and most fascinating concepts, plus a few more normal entries from the annual show in Japan.
promoTitle: Top Ten from the Tokyo Auto Show
promoTeaserSmall: The weirdest and most fascinating concepts, plus a few more normal entries from the annual show in Japan.
promoTeaser: The weirdest and most fascinating concepts, plus a few more normal entries from the annual show in Japan.
keywords: Top Ten from the Tokyo Auto Show
metaTitle: Top Ten from the Tokyo Auto Show - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The weirdest and most fascinating concepts, plus a few more normal entries from the annual show in Japan.

pageElements.text:
1. Daihatsu Nori Ori

What’s this? A miniaturized subway car? The design certainly seems to draw on that idea, and there’s almost enough room inside to stand up. The only thing missing is something for straphangers to hang onto. But the Nori Ori takes accessibility a step further. An access ramp extends when the sliding side doors are opened, and there are hinged doors at the rear, with enough room behind the seats for a wheelchair or two.

Ground clearance is minimal—if it weren’t so tall, the Nori Ori would be a lowrider—and the front end design looks like it was inspired by something in a Pixar movie. No word on power, and for all its accessibility this little Daihatsu's dimensions and low-slung chassis don’t seem feasible for production. On the other hand, tiny transportation pods make sense in Japan, and the Nori Ori wouldn’t really look too bizarre in the Tokyo traffic mix.

2. Honda Wander Stand

If you thought the Daihatsu Nori Ori was weird, this little rolling phone booth rates as otherworldly. Yes, there are wheels at all four corners, faired in under those little fenders. Yes, there is propulsion of some sort, probably electric, so you can probably wander, as the name suggests. Preferably on level ground. Maybe at the mall. Honda said the traditional rickshaw was the inspiration. Yes, there are seats in there, for two, and no, you can’t stand. The pod is designed to operate autonomously, so there’s no steering wheel. But there is a rotating joystick that allows some maneuvering, including laterally. Other control functions are accessed on a touchscreen.
Though bizarre, this personal mobility module concept isn’t totally out of the question for some sort of production version. Think retirement communities.

3. Lexus LF-FC

The core of this sexy grand sedan is fuel cell propulsion, with a fuel cell stack under the long hood, hydrogen tanks below the floor, and a battery pack at the rear. The battery powers a trio of electric motors, two inside each of the front wheels and a third driving the rear wheels. Lexus says the system will provide an “exhilarating driving experience.” Parent company Toyota says it is “getting ready to embrace a hydrogen-based society,” but if or when that comes to pass remains to be seen, and not soon.
Other cutting-edge techno elements of the concept package—a holographic center dash console, gesture control, and automated driving capability—are much closer to production reality.

Stylistically, the LF-FC was a Tokyo show traffic stopper with its sleek contours, tightly wrapped skin, low roofline, short overhangs, and sense of sophisticated muscularity. This is a big car, longer and lower than any of the high-end German cars that rule this class—the Audi A8, BMW 7 Series, and Mercedes-Benz S-Class. It’s also much longer and lower than the current Lexus LS, the company’s premier sedan. Aside from fuel cell power, we’ll see many of this concept’s features, including styling, when the next-generation LS sedan makes its debut in 2017.

4. Mazda RX

Is the world ready for a rotary-engine revival? Or were the mobs surrounding this sleek two-seater at the Tokyo show simply seduced by its elegantly sexy skin? Smart money says it’s the sheetmetal. A rotary engine was the unique core of Mazda’s identity from the late Sixties until the RX-8 went out of production in 2012. Mazda R&D has continued working to bring the engine back to market viability ever since. And company insiders insist that it’s going to happen, calling the revivalist engine the Skyactiv-R. Time will tell.

5. Mercedes Vision Tokyo

At a glance, the shape is vaguely minivan-esque in the Dustbuster style of the Pontiac Trans Sport and the Chevrolet Lumina APV. But the Mercedes-Benz Vision Tokyo's doors don’t slide, it’s far more slick, and of course it's far more sophisticated. The entire body, including the windows, is coated with silvery paint, and blue LED accent lights lend drama to the package. Power is delivered by a fuel cell system feeding electric motors. While there were no tech details on the powertrain, Mercedes suggests a potential range of 600 miles. The interior is distinguished by lounge seating, for a more communal environment and better access to a variety of electro toys.

The interior layout—Mercedes characterizes it as “a chill-out zone in the midst of the megacity traffic mayhem”—is viable because the Vision is fully autonomous and drives itself. However, should one of the occupants be seized with a need for actual control, a command causes a small seat to set itself up and a steering wheel pops out of the dashboard.

6. Nissan Teatro for Dayz

"Teatro" is Spanish for theater, and that’s apt since this concept has little to do with driving and a lot to do with infotainment. There are enough configurable video screens inside to rival a TV news studio, and the only conventional interior vehicle elements are the steering wheel and foot pedals. All the other controls are on touchscreens—no knobs, no switches—and it’s clear that driving plays a very subordinate role in this vehicle’s mission. When the Teatro is in motion, exterior digital screens can be programmed to convey mood or message, Goodyear Blimp style.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Um_GUzx7HfM" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

7. Nissan 2020 Vision Gran Turismo

Nissan enlisted the digigeeks of Gran Turismo, the computer supercar driving game, in developing this stunning sports car concept, hence the name—and the car’s virtual presence on Gran Turismo 6. But this is more than virtual reality. Yes, it was initially conceived strictly for video gaming, but then the London-based design team got a green light to take the car to the concept stage. The 2020 Vision Gran Turismo, in fact, is widely believed to be a blueprint for the next-generation GT-R, Nissan’s two-seat supercar. Expectations are for a hybridized powertrain, amplifying the 545-horsepower twin-turbocharged V-6 that propels the current GT-R.
The concept says 2020, but Nissan has long since announced that work is in progress on the GT-R make-over. Look for the new car to be in showrooms well before the end of the decade.

8. Suzuki Mighty Deck

Not to be confused with the Mighty Ducks, this Mini-size two-seater concept by Suzuki isn’t as bizarre as some of the concepts that turn up at this show—until you get to the rear. Instead of a hatchback, there’s a miniature pickup bed, with wood paneling. Not really big enough for a proper tailgate party, but that’s not an issue since Suzuki is no longer a player in the U.S. market. The interior is distinguished by a tiny center-dash instrument cluster and more wood paneling.

Suzuki has a history of zany names for its concept cars, and this show was consistent with that tradition. Besides the Mighty Deck, Suzuki displayed the Hustler, the Lapin, the Escudo, and the Hustler Scoot.

9. Toyota Kikai

You know the old saying that what you see is what you get, and that’s certainly true of this zany Toyota SUV concept. Pretty much every mechanical element is right out there for everyone to see—including the driver. From the pilot’s seat, which is in the middle of the vehicle, transparent floor panels reveal what’s going on with the front wheels and the lower suspension components. The upper portions of the suspension are atop the hood, giving driver and passerby of the suspension in action. The rear-mounted engine is also exposed, dressed up with a lot of chrome, including the exhaust plumbing, The interior is a Luddite’s delight—no touch screens, no digitalia, just a collection of good ol’ analog dials and conventional switches.
Kikai is the Japanese word for machine. Hmm. Wonder how you say dream machine in Japanese. That would be appropriate, since the prospects for Kikai production can be summed up thus: in your dreams.

10. Yamaha Sports Ride

A Yamaha car? Well, why not? Like any successful company it seeks to expand its horizons. Consider the Motobot, a Yamaha show property from the company’s R&D division. It’s a robot rider conceived to pilot a motorcycle at speeds up to about 125 mph. Spooky.

This snappy little two-seat sports car concept is more rooted in reality, as well as possible production. It’s not the company’s first street-legal four-wheeler; Yamaha unveiled a small two-seat commuter, the MOTIV, at the 2013 Tokyo show. But the Sports Ride is a lot more appealing, and far more advanced.

Developed by Gordon Murray Design Limited in Surrey, England, a racing-car shop with Formula 1 connections, the front-engine, rear-wheel-drive chassis is composed of carbon fiber. The car is dimensionally similar to the new Mazda MX-5 Miata, but some 650 pounds lighter. And Yamaha has plenty of potent motorcycle engines capable of making the car a serious rocket.
When or even whether the Sports Ride will actually find its way into production is a question Yamaha refrained from addressing at the show.

title: 2016 Nissan 370Z
subTitle: Stoking the eternal Z flame, forty-seven years on.
promoTeaserSmall: Stoking the eternal Z flame, forty-seven years on.
promoTeaser: Stoking the eternal Z flame, forty-seven years on.
metaDescription: Stoking the eternal Z flame, forty-seven years on.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-seat, rear-wheel-drive sport coupe
Trim levels: Base, Sport, Sport Tech, Touring, Nismo, Nismo TECH
Base price: $30,815 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $30,940
Engine: 3.7-liter V-6, 332 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/26 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Porsche Boxster ($53,095)
2016 Porsche Cayman ($53,595)
2016 Ford Mustang V-6 Fastback ($24,795)
Fun-O-Meter: 9.0

When I look at the 2016 Nissan 370Z, I can’t help remembering back through the Nissan Z cars of my career, which, by the way, does not go back to the first, groundbreaking, 150-horsepower 1969 240Z. My favorite of the lot came thirty years later, after wildly successful sales, numerous amateur and national racing championships (Paul Newman set several track records in 1985), and a sudden drop in sales as America fell out of love with sports cars for a sudden affair with minivans and sport-utility vehicles. Sad times indeed.

But Nissan came roaring back in 1990 with the 300ZX Twin Turbo, an absolute smash hit that took the Big Four national car magazines—Car and Driver, Automobile, Road & Track, and Motor Trend—by storm. This fourth-generation Z car had an all-new 3.0-liter V-6 that produced 300 horsepower, and it was blisteringly fast, a beast that drew untoward constabulary attention to my spirited driving on more than one unfortunate occasion, convincing me finally to use my cruise control regularly. Those were the days.

Year after year, the enthusiast car mags heaped on the Best of the Best of Everything Fabulous on that 300ZX Twin Turbo as horsepower grew to 365 in 1995 (the Z’s twenty-fifth anniversary), until 1996, when Nissan pulled the plug and almost went under as a company. Renault rode in and picked Nissan up in 1999, creating one shaky company out of two shaky companies, but at least the Z returned in 2002, passing its 45th anniversary last year.

God bless Nissan for keeping the performance driving flame alive by continuing to build and sell the two-seat 370Z—and at a price that is well below its closest competitors. The only option on the coupe I drove was a $125 set of carpeted floor mats, in fact, for an as-tested price just over $30,000. For the price of a boring car, you could have this.
My memory may have unjustifiably placed the 1990 300Z Twin Turbo in the pantheon of the greatest cars I have ever driven. Well, it’s my memory.

My memory may have unjustifiably placed the 1990 300Z Twin Turbo in the pantheon of the greatest cars I have ever driven. Well, it’s my memory. At least it was quicker and cooler than any of its competition at the time. Today’s 332-horsepower, non-turbocharged 370Z is still a very special car for a very special driver: one who has no need for a back seat and doesn’t need cargo space for anything but a couple of pieces of luggage or a few grocery bags. There's a carpeted nook behind each of the front seats that could hold a modest purse or briefcase. But the 370Z is for traveling light.
You can tell just from looking at it, can’t you?

The short overhangs, the steep rake of the rear hatch, the big black ten-spoke eighteen-inch wheels shoved out to the corners. All of that gives the 370Z a personal snug-as-a-bug-in-a-rug look. One with an edge, for sure.

Graphics are simple, clean. The deep front hood meets a low, large black intake. Slices of light decorate each of the four corners, and the door handle is a simple vertical slash of satin-finish chrome. And then there’s the mark of Zorro—the slashing Z logo—behind the front doors on the rear fender arches.
It looks mean. It is mean.

The 370Z is purpose built for someone who believes that the very act of driving is the destination. It wraps around the driver like a second skin, with deep, contoured seats that are bolstered at the sides to hold driver and passenger tight as the road calls for more spirited driving.

The engine is familiar to Nissan performance fans. Its very enthusiastic 3.7-Iiter, 332-horsepower V-6 mates to a six-speed manual or seven-speed automatic transmission. The manual transmission in the 370Z I drove leapt into action no matter what gear I was in. Our test car didn’t have downshift rev matching (introduced by Nissan, for the first time ever in a production car, in the 2009 sixth-generation 370Z). It’s a great feature that allows for fast, precise downshifts, so I had to count on my own ability to keep those downshifts clean and neat.

If you want to feel like a hero driver, you have to spend an extra $3,580 for the 370Z Sport model to get SynchroRev Match, but at least it also comes with extra performance enhancements like a limited-slip differential and bigger brakes. I would recommend you at least test a car with rev matching to experience the thrill. There are those that would argue the superior speed of the automatic with rev matching. It will also add only $1,300 to the base 370Z. I have to admit, that automatic transmission is good, and certainly the only way I’d ever consider an automatic.

But there’s a perfectly great manual available for no extra charge. The shift quality of the 370Z’s manual is exceptional, a hallmark of a car built for driving fun. Shifts are decisive and crisp. The steering wheel, another key component of a true driver’s car, is smallish in diameter, nicely padded with beautiful leather, and fairly linear in delivery.

The instrument cluster is simple, with large, clear gauges. The speedometer is marked to 180 mph for your amusement. An additional set of important gauges—water temperature and oil pressure—join an analog clock in a small cluster mounted atop the center of the dash and angled toward the driver.

You won’t find much extraneous distraction in a base 370Z. You won’t find modern driver assist safety technologies. No blind spot monitoring, but there is smart cruise control, along with modern HID xenon headlamps. No rearview camera, but Bluetooth hands-free phone, ABS braking, and a sophisticated double-wishbone suspension are standard equipment. For another $11,000, you can buy the convertible roadster version.
The four additional 370Z coupes add in technical bells and whistles, the luxury amenities and trappings, all the way to a pumped-up 350-horsepower Nismo version with a jaunty little rear wing.
Buy one of those if you must. But you will find the real heart and soul, the eternal Z-car flame, alive and well for the price of an entry-level ticket.

title: 5 Cool Things: Hyundai Virtual Guide
subTitle: Hyundai takes one more step toward the future with a 3D virtual guide for the Sonata.
promoTeaserSmall: Hyundai takes one more step toward the future with a 3D virtual guide for the Sonata.
promoTeaser: Hyundai takes one more step toward the future with a 3D virtual guide for the Sonata.
metaDescription: Hyundai takes one more step toward the future with a 3D virtual guide for the Sonata.

pageElements.text: You think of the owner's manual as that brick-shaped volume you never take out of the glove box after the first day you own the car. The Hyundai Virtual Guide is the intriguing successor to that.

Lately you can look up your owner's manual online, which is very handy. But the Hyundai Virtual Guide goes far beyond that to create a tablet experience. Here are five cool things about this newly announced feature, which will be on the 2016 Sonata and, later, the 2016 Tucson.

1. Hold the tablet up to your car, and everything it sees will be labeled.
This is the best part of the app: you are interacting with your own car. More than forty-five features are highlighted in the app, and we can assume Hyundai will add more as it perfects the Virtual Guide idea.

2. Watch walk-throughs of basic maintenance functions on your phone or tablet.
This is not an app that will teach you to give your car a brake job, but for very simple but important tasks—replacing the washer fluid, for example—the app will walk you through it, step by step. There are some fifty informational guides on this app.

3. No more flipping through an index!
The best part about the Hyundai Virtual Guide is how it frees you from looking through a paper or online owner's manual. Those owner's manuals in PDF form are great, but they also run to hundreds of pages. The Virtual Guide cuts to the chase by showing you the maintenance and feature information you are most likely to need, and you gain access to it in the same way you'd browse any website, which feels more natural, these days, than using an actual book.

4. 3D images!
This is the best-looking owner's manual you'll see, and certainly the most portable. Hyundai calls it "augmented reality," which is a stretch—for now—but the 3D overlay images of six areas of the vehicle are, we hope, the wave of the future for owner's manuals.

5. Easily downloaded on Apple App Store and Google Play.
It's not out yet, but you Sonata (and, soon, Tucson) owners will be able to start using it before the New Year, Hyundai says.

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-passenger, front-wheel-drive minivan
Trim levels: LX, EX, SE, EX-L, Touring, Touring Elite
Base price: $30,175 (LX) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $45,650
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 248 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/28 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick (2015 model)
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Chrysler Town & Country Limited Platinum ($41,640)
2016 Kia Sedona SXL ($40,795)
2015 Toyota Sienna Limited Premium ($45,955)

Fun-O-Meter: 6 for the driver, 8 for the kids

The Honda Odyssey is a perennial success in a world in which minivans’ popularity has continued to shrink. That’s because Honda knows its audience. The Odyssey was already a big improvement on its competition fifteen years ago when it was introduced to admiring American moms and dads, and it continues to ride at the top of the segment. Honda figured out exactly why people liked the original minivans, the Chrysler Town & Country and Dodge Caravan: how you sat up high in it, how carlike it was to maneuver, and how nice it was to have that low load floor not only to step in, but to load in kids and cargo..
Then they improved everything, making everything seriously better.

As the Odyssey approaches the end of its fourth generation, with an all-new model expected in 2017, it’s still very desirable, at least for those who need the size and passenger capacity of a  minivan.

The very first Odyssey was more of a tall MPV, but by the second generation, making its debut in 1999, it was a full-fledged minivan. It didn’t take long before Honda Odysseys were lined up in front of every child care center, elementary school, and soccer field in the land.
If there is any vehicle that is completely focused on creating the most exquisite experience for the passengers, especially the ones in the back seat, the Odyssey is it.
And why not? If there is any vehicle that is completely focused on creating the most exquisite experience for the passengers, especially the ones in the back seat, the Odyssey is it.

Having said that, if the back-seat passengers are happy and entertained, the driver wins, too. The seating for up to eight, the entertainment, the clever seats reconfigurability, the ease of getting in and out, the flexible center console that serves both front and back seat—no wonder this minivan is so coveted.

The 2016 Honda Odyssey is a carryover model with some improvements, but you can tell this model is due to be updated. The fact that there’s only one USB connection, up by the driver, is a dead giveaway. As for active safety technology, the 2016 Odyssey doesn’t have adaptive cruise control or road departure mitigation, as in the Honda Sensing suite of technologies you can get on the 2016 Accord, Pilot, and Civic. The Touring Elite model I tested does offer lane departure and forward collision warning, as well as Honda’s unbeatable multi-view rearview camera.

One of the very best things about the Odyssey is its movable center console in the front row. You can remove it and have a pass-through, desirable especially for parents of babies and toddlers. In place, the bin is big enough for a medium-size purse, while the top is cleverly designed for fast food fans. It will hold two cups in front, two in back, and the center part is designed to hold a typical fast-food tray if you’re lucky enough to live in In-N-Out Burger territory.
There’s a flip-down trash ring, too, something you won’t find elsewhere.

That same amazing flexibility is true of the seats. Believe it or not, if you want to put three people or car seats in the second row, you can. Heaven forbid. Just what you wanted, to be chosen as the permanent field trip mom for the preschool.

The fold-down 16.2-inch DVD rear entertainment system above the second row is a wonder to behold, and it comes with two pairs of headphones. At some point you will want to take a break and sit in the back seat and watch. I can’t resist thinking it would also be great for date night for the grownups.

Honda’s clever seat-folding technology gives you near-instantaneous one-touch access to the third row. Press the button and watch the second-row seat move up to let someone clamber in the back. Or just press the upper part of it and create a recline. In the second row, you can slide both outboard seats toward the doors to make room to put three child safety seats in the row. You can also move the center seat forward to bring it closer to the front row or fold it down to reveal a center console. The Magic Seat 60/40 split-folding rear seats drop down into the floor nearly instantly when you pull the “magic” straps on the seatback. It really is kind of like magic. Once everyone in the back rows gets seated, they’ll enjoy the fact that the Honda Odyssey Touring Elite offers tri-zone climate control.

So all the passengers are covered; what about the driver? I love the dual infotainment screens. The tendency (the correct one) will be to keep your eyes up on the top screen for all the important stuff, instead of looking down at your phone (the wrong one). Voice recognition for phone calling is fairly simple, although a little confusing at first because, once paired, the screen will show random names from your contacts list as an example of how to word your request, using a different name every time, and your first thought is “No, I don’t want to call P.J. O’Rourke!” At the top, you quickly realize, is the real number you’re calling.

If you’re not used to parking a minivan, the Odyssey has a small learning curve. It is very easy to drive, but it’s so long that you may have to relearn parking. The steering is light enough that you can pull into a straight spot, but you may find yourself needing to back out and pull back in despite the reasonable 36.7-foot turning radius. This is where the rearview camera, standard on all Odysseys, comes in handy. Honda’s LaneWatch is part of the package on the Touring Elite model. Put on the right turn signal, and a camera in the passenger’s-side door mirror shows what’s behind your vehicle to the right. is an invaluable aid for people with a vanload of distraction, a.k.a. the eight passengers it can hold.

The sliding side doors and rear liftgate are all electric. When you first get in the car, you’ll notice a panel of controls to the left of the steering wheel to operate them. The liftgate also opens or closes using the key fob. My only complaint is that it’s not height adjustable, meaning you’ll want to consider before opening it inside a garage. I also think every vehicle with a big hatch should adopt some form of automatic opening, without the need even to press a button, such as Ford’s kick-foot method or Hyundai’s proximity key. When you’re dealing with kids and packages in a vehicle like that, it’s the ultimate in luxury.

The brakes are well modulated. As long as you’re not going 70 mph down a side street, you’re going to make that stop sign with no drama. The ride is drama-free as well. The suspension is quite refined, and there was no bouncing or school-bus feeling to the Odyssey.

There are eight trim levels, with a $15,500 range between the base model and the top trim level we drove. The details on the top Touring Elite model are exquisite, particularly the Cool Box, which sits below the infotainment screens. Using the car’s air conditioning, the box will keep your juice boxes, Frappuccinos, sandwiches, and snacks cool while you travel. They need to start out cold, however. The Touring Elite also gets the HondaVAC, a built-in vacuum that lives in the back of the vehicle behind the third row. 
 
You could just about buy the base model, the LX ($30,175) and pick up a base Honda Fit on the side ($16,625) for the $45,650 price of the Touring Elite, but the options on the top-end Odyssey are highly desirable. Check out the high-value Special Edition model ($34,275), new for 2016, to get some of those features at a lower price. Case in point? The HondaVAC is on the SE. God, I love that thing. Then again, I am a little OCD about my automotive environment. But people who need that vac will love it, too. It reaches everywhere in the vehicle, it’s built in, and it works like a charm on those errant Cheerios. What other vehicle do you know that has one? That would be none.

Another small but significant reason to consider the Odyssey is that it has the best fuel economy in the minivan category, at 19 mpg in town and 26 mpg on the highway. The Chrysler Town & Country and the Toyota Sienna both get 25 mpg on the highway, while the Kia Sedona gets 22 mpg.

I wouldn’t own a Honda Odyssey if I didn’t have kids or some other reason to need the space and number of seats. It’s a purpose-built vehicle. But driving it is certainly a totally pleasant experience. Especially at the top Touring Elite level, equipped with very nice leather and amenities. There’s no sense driving a bus if you don’t need one, but the minivan environment is the only perfect conveyance for families with little kids. My husband always had a minivan because he was a tradesman. He, of course, totally trashed the interior with all of his tradesman crap. And dog. Between the Magic Seats, the third row that folds down, the second row that flips up, you can create a fairly massive deep spot that can hold a lot, including a big cooler. When everything folds down, it’s a flat floor. I can’t overstate the importance to me of the flat load floor, which lets me put a kennel back there. Where there’s a bump between the two, it can be very tippy. I don’t want my dog on an angle; it upsets him.

There aren’t many minivans left, and the ones that are around are successful because they’ve mastered the platform. Their makers have figured out what their clients not only need, but what they desire. In Honda’s case, they’ve amped that up by imagining things you never dreamed you could find. When you’re talking about eight passengers, you’re talking about a bus, but with the Odyssey it’s a bus that drives like a very nice car.

images.caption: HondaVac in the 2016 Honda Odyssey Touring Elite.

subTitle: No diesel this year, but an all-new version of the popular compact car.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact sedan
Price range: $17,495 – $23,995
Trim revels: L, LS, LT, Premier
Engine: Turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder, 153 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual, six-speed automatic
Fuel economy (estimated): 28 mpg city/42 mpg highway (manual transmission), 26/39 mpg (automatic transmission)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Notable standard features on this model: Stop/start system to save fuel, rearview camera
Notable options on this model: Heated front seats, heated leather-wrapped steering wheel, heated leather-trimmed rear seats; side blind zone alert, lane keeping assist, rear cross-traffic alert, forward collision alert; eight-inch Chevrolet MyLink infotainment screen (seven-inch screen is standard); OnStar with 4GLTE connectivity that provides a Wi-Fi hot spot for seven devices; Android Auto and Apple CarPlay smartphone connectivity
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Mazda3, Toyota Corolla

All new for 2016, the compact Chevrolet Cruze has streamlined its proportions, losing 250 pounds in the process. It's 2.7 inches longer, an inch lower, and features more rear legroom, always a good thing in a compact car. It has also lost the diesel model, giving diesel fans even less choice at a confusing time with the Volkswagen scandal at a fever pitch. But don't worry; there's a diesel Cruze coming back, in the 2017 model year.
Shopping for a Cruze this year is a bit confusing. The Cruze Limited is the previous-generation model, being kept around mainly for fleet sales but still available at retail.

The LT and Premier models get the most options choices, among them a larger eight-inch touchscreen, Bose premium audio with nine speakers, heated cloth front seats (LT) and wireless phone charging (Premier). Push-button start and the ultimate cold-weather luxury, a heated steering wheel, are standard on the Premier model. Active safety features—side blind zone alert with lane change alert, rear cross-traffic alert, and rear park assist—are options on both LT and Premier models, while only the Premier get Forward Collision Alert and Intellibeam headlamps as options.

New for 2016

The Cruze is all new for 2016, with a new turbocharged 1.4-liter engine and an added RS personalization package.
The diesel Cruze goes on hiatus, with a new model expected in the 2017 model year.

More about the Chevrolet Cruze

subTitle: An all-new version of the mid-size stalwart, plus a hybrid promising 48 mpg in town.

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Price range: $22,500 – $32,290 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: L, LS, LT, Hybrid, Premier
Engine: Turbocharged 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 160 horsepower; turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 250 horsepower; 1.8-liter four-cylinder with two-motor drive (Hybrid), total 182 horsepower

You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Hyundai Sonata, Toyota Camry

The Chevrolet Malibu is a car that feels to have been around absolutely forever. That's pretty much true, actually, The name dates back to the 1960s, with the current front-wheel-drive Malibu dating to 1997. Chevrolet unveiled a completely redone version of its long-lived Malibu at the New York Auto Show this spring, and it goes on sale by year's end, with a hybrid version coming in the spring. The all-new Malibu is bigger, sleeker-looking, and loaded with technological choices. The big news is more space inside, with 1.3 more inches of rear legroom and a four-inch improvement in the car's wheelbase. The other big news is a Malibu Hybrid, built on a version of the Chevrolet Volt's powertrain and its regenerative braking system, with a battery pack that can run the Malibu up to 55 mph on electricity alone. OnStar with a 4G LTE Wi-Fi hot spot is available on all models, and wireless smartphone charging is an option on upper-level models. The strong slate of active safety features includes automatic parking assist, rear cross-traffic alert, and forward collision alert. A new Teen Driver feature lets parents keep track of their children's driving habits and set maximum speeds using the car's infotainment system.

New in 2016

The Malibu is all new for the 2016 model year.

More about the Malibu

New York Auto Show: 2016 Chevrolet Malibu April 1, 2015

Price range: $28,090 – $41,085
Trim levels: WT, LS, LT, LT Z71, LTZ, LTZ Z71, High Country
Engines: 4.3-liter V-6, 285 horsepower; 5.3-liter V-8, 355 horsepower; 6.2-liter V-8, 420 horsepower

You might also be considering: Ford F-150, GMC Sierra, Ram 1500

Shopping for a pickup truck is one of the most complex of pursuits, with the variety of engine sizes, body types, seating configurations, bed lengths, and towing packages. The full-size truck market is highly competitive, with Chevrolet fans and those who favor another brand. If Chevrolet is your brand, and you are in the market for a full-size truck, you already have a clear idea of your needs. The Silverado lineup can satisfy them, no matter what they are, with a regular-cab model with a standard or long truck box; a double-cab model with a short box; or a crew cab with either short or standard box length. You can also get the Silverado with rear- or all-wheel drive and in a choice of seven trim levels. The base WT dresses up with a Black Out Edition this year ($1,595), which should appeal to young entry-level buyers with its 20-inch black-painted wheels, blacked-out grille surround, front bumper and grille, and even black Chevrolet bowtie emblems. At the opposite end of the price scale is the dressy High Country version, with its heated and ventilated leather seating, an eight-inch touchscreen with navigation, park assist, wireless phone charging, a remote locking tailgate, and chrome wheels and grille.

New for 2016:

Lighting changes: LED head- and taillights (LTZ, High Country); HID projector headlamps with LED signature (WT, LS, LT)
Grille design varies by model
Remote locking tailgate (optional) and power-articulating assist steps (optional on High Country)
Eight-speed automatic transmission (optional on 5.3-liter V-8 versions of LTZ and High Country)
New front designs with bold horizontal elements, sculpted hood and LED signature lighting Apple CarPlay and Android Auto capability
Wireless phone charging (on all models with front bucket seats)

title: 2016 Honda Civic Coupe
subTitle: The sexiest version to date of the all-new Civic.
promoTeaserSmall: The sexiest version to date of the all-new Civic.
promoTeaser: The sexiest version to date of the all-new Civic.
keywords: 2016 Honda Civic Coupe - LA Auto Show
metaKeywords: Honda at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: The sexiest version to date of the all-new Civic.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger compact coupe
Release date: March 2016
Estimated price range: $19,000
Competes against: Hyundai Elantra, Kia Forte Koup, Scion tC
What's most interesting: Smartphone app integration

The Honda Civic is a practical car for practical people, but this fresh coupe version of the all-new tenth-generation Civic is just plain sexy. It’s also right up to date with a new touchscreen infotainment system that supports Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, so you can run some of your favorite smartphone apps on the car’s screen. Compared with the 2015 Civic Coupe, it has a lower roofline, but more interior room, including more than five more inches of legroom in the back seat.

A first for a Civic Coupe is a turbo engine choice, a 1.5-liter four-cylinder making 174 horsepower. The standard engine is a 2.0-liter four-cylinder that makes 158 horsepower, yielding an expected 41 mpg on the highway. Most Civic Coupes have a continuously variable automatic transmission, but the base model is available with a six-speed manual.

The whole Honda Civic lineup is all new for 2016, so if a coupe is not exactly your thing, there is something—from the 41 mpg on the highway you'll get in the sedan to the fun you'll have in the upcoming Type-R performance model—that you'll find worthy of your interest.

title: 2016 Volkswagen Beetle Dune
subTitle: Something simple and happy out of VW. Refreshing!
promoTeaserSmall: Something simple and happy out of VW. Refreshing!
promoTeaser: Something simple and happy out of VW. Refreshing!
metaDescription: Something simple and happy out of VW. Refreshing!

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-passenger, front-wheel-drive two-door compact sedan or convertible
Release date: Early 2016 (sedan); fall 2016 (convertible)
Estimated price range: High $20,000s
Competes against: Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Kia Soul, Mini Cooper
What’s most interesting: Sits a little higher off the ground

Volkswagen is always good for a special-edition Beetle. The bulbous car just makes you want to decorate it, somehow. In the past few years since the current version came out in 2011, there have been pink ones, denim-colored ones, a Fender guitar edition, and a set of Beetle convertibles based on 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s design themes.

But the Beetle Dune is not a mere gold color scheme; it is an homage to the Baja Bugs of the 1960s, which were not just no-frills but anti-frills vehicles. The 2016 Beetle Dune started out as a concept, shown at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit in January 2014, but soon you'll be able to buy one.

At least, the Beetle Dune attempts to channel the "iconic spirit" of those legendary VWs. It does this with 0.4 inch more in ground clearance, a central air intake in the front bumper, a rear spoiler, special side moldings, and wheel-arch extensions. It gets special eighteen-inch Canyon aluminum wheels. Both doors get "Dune" graphics, and the taillights are LEDs. An optional Technology package adds bi-xenon headlights with LED daytime running lights and LED lighting around the license plate. (Not quite something you can picture on a vintage Baja Bug.) The engine is the standard Beetle's turbocharged 1.8-liter four-cylinder making 170 horsepower, teamed with a six-speed automatic transmission.

Sport seats get contrasting orange stitching, and there's a standard 6.3-inch infotainment screen with a rearview camera and parking distance sensors. Apple CarPlay and Android Auto connectivity are standard. A Technology package can be added to get a tilting and sliding sunroof, push-button start with keyless access, and dual-zone automatic climate control, as well as Fender premium audio.  No pricing has been released yet.
You can get the Beetle Dune in the Sandstorm Yellow shown here, or in white or black pearl. The yellow Dune has body-color upper door and dashboard trim; the others get black.

images.caption: 2016 Volkswagen Beetle Dune: coupe and convertible.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2016 Subaru Forester 2.5i Premium

Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive crossover/wagon
Trim levels: 2.5i, 2.5i Premium, Limited, Touring; 2.0XT Premium and Touring
Base price: $25,645 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $28,540
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 170 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/32 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated (2015 model was Top Safety Pick Plus)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, panoramic power moonroof, roof rails, 7.0-inch infotainment screen, Bluetooth connectivity
Notable options on this model: All-Weather package (includes heated front seats and side mirrors, windshield wiper de-icer, steering-responsive fog lights, Starlink navigation system, and EyeSight driver assist system ($1,895); continuously variable transmission ($1,000)
You might also be considering (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Ford Escape SE AWD ($27,945)
2016 Honda CR-V SE AWD ($26,595)
2016 Hyundai Tucson Sport AWD ($28,445)
2016 Jeep Cherokee Latitude AWD ($28,190)
2016 Mazda CX-5 Touring AWD ($27,345)
Fun-O-Meter: 6

The compact crossover/sport-utility vehicle category is more crowded than ever, which means you have more choice than ever. All good news! But actually, if you’re looking to ride up high in a five-passenger, all-wheel-drive vehicle, the choices can look alarmingly similar. One exception is the Subaru Forester, which remains refreshingly station-wagon-like despite the general move to a boxier silhouette.

We tested the second of six trim levels, the 2.5i Premium. Even at this economical price point, the Forester was equipped with full-time all-wheel drive, an infotainment screen, navigation, and some of the latest active safety features. Its as-tested price of $28,540 including destination charge is a compelling sales proposition.
Even Consumer Reports describes its interior as austere, and that’s not a publication that prizes bling. You might say “dowdy,” depending on how much you prize bling.

The Forester is the smaller of Subaru’s five-passenger crossovers, built on the platform of the Impreza, while the Outback is based off the Legacy sedan. As such, the Forester is the choice you’d look at if you’re also considering the Honda CR-V, the Toyota RAV4, the Ford Escape, and other compact crossovers. All practical vehicles, but of them all, the Forester is the most timeless-looking inside and out—even Consumer Reports describes its interior as “austere,” and that’s not exactly a publication that prizes bling. You might say “dowdy,” depending on how much you prize bling.

Who is the kind of person who buys a Subaru? For starters, someone interested in being a savvy consumer. Consumer Reports says the most frequently researched vehicle on its website is the Forester. In fact, 40 percent more viewers look it up than the #2 vehicle….which is also a Subaru crossover, the larger Outback.

The interior reflects the general understated appeal of the Forester, with a lot of plastic but a feeling of durability and a rejection of faddishness. There’s an analog clock, for example, and an old-school center console that may restrict your ability to stow a large handbag. But it has a comfortable sliding armrest top that you don’t always see in the competition. On the other hand, I strongly disliked the large, textured metal rotary HVAC dials, which were stiff and hard to turn. Yes, they are sturdy and will probably last until the end of time. But anyone with arthritis will dislike them even more than I did.

In contrast, the sleek glass touchscreen in the center of the dash was as easy to use as anything I’ve tried, as easy as brushing your fingertips across your chosen icon. Really lovely. But only when the sun isn’t glaring off it, making it impossible to read. The smaller screen above it has an anti-glare matte surface. Just saying.

Speaking of visibility, Consumer Reports, again, praises the Forester for the best outward visibility of any vehicle. Out of five sides—including the massive sunroof, when the shade is opened—you get a gloriously uninterrupted view. That, plus the generous 8.7 inches of ground clearance, gives an open-sleigh feeling, especially in the snow we had in southeast Michigan while testing the Forester.
The Forester is still not a laugh riot to drive, but it’s much more entertaining than the humorless Subarus of yore.

The snow didn’t last long on the Interstate, so we had a good chance to drive the Forester at speed. The carryover 2.5-liter flat-four engine still produces a respectable 170 horsepower, respectable because it’s optimally managed by a continuously variable transmission instead of the disinterested four-speed automatic transmission it was saddled with through 2013, when I last drove a Forester. I had modest expectations as I hit the highway and was totally surprised. The Forester is still not a laugh riot to drive, but it’s much more entertaining than the humorless Subarus of yore.

One complaint: As I pressed the accelerator at 70 mph, the Forester pulled slightly right. As I lifted my foot a touch, it pulled left. It was a tiny adjustment in mass that was almost imperceptible. But it was there, and it bothered me.

Subaru is justly praised for its EyeSight active safety package, available as an option on select models of the Forester, Impreza, Legacy, Outback, and Crosstrek. It includes adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, lane sway warning (when you’re wandering too much within your lane), and pre-collision warning and braking. The package deal is very popular with the practical-minded Subaru shopper. Subaru says 24 percent of Foresters and 31 percent of total Subarus are sold equipped with EyeSight.

On the Forester we tested, EyeSight was part of an overall option package ($1,895) that bundled navigation, SiriusXM satellite radio, and an All-Weather group that included heated front seats and side mirrors and a windshield wiper de-icer. The All-Weather part of the equation was extremely handy when a foot of snow fell overnight and the Forester was buried. Turn the key, get the defrosters going, and before you’ve scraped the first side window, those heated side mirrors are radiating the winter right off the side of the vehicle. In its entirety, we’d call that feature bundle a helluva good deal.

If what you want is a five-passenger crossover, Subaru has two excellent choices: this Forester and the more upscale mid-size Outback. But there’s no seven-passenger choice in Subaru’s admittedly quirky lineup. It’s coming, though, in the 2018 model year, and it will be built in the United States at Subaru of Indiana Automotive. This three-row vehicle doesn’t have a name yet, but Subaru announced earlier this month that it will get a title “synonymous with outdoor adventure.” That’s good, because in Japan the three-row crossover is called the Exiga, which sounds a little too Wall Street for Subaru’s more earthy clientele.

These cars are bestsellers year in and year out. They aren’t sexy. Then again, if you want to get somewhere on bad roads without a moment’s worry, maybe the Forester has just the right amount of allure. Context is everything.

title: 5 Reasons to Spring for Winter Tires
subTitle: If it gets below freezing where you live, consider putting winter tires on your vehicle. Here’s why.
promoTitle: 5 Reasons to Spring for Winter Tires
promoTeaserSmall: If it gets below freezing where you live, consider putting winter tires on your vehicle. Here’s why.
promoTeaser: If it gets below freezing where you live, consider putting winter tires on your vehicle. Here’s why.
keywords: 5 Reasons to Spring for Winter Tires
metaTitle: 5 Reasons to Spring for Winter Tires - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: If it gets below freezing where you live, consider putting winter tires on your vehicle. Here’s why.

pageElements.text: If you’re like most people, your vehicle has a set of all-season radial tires. If you ever had snow tires, it was years ago, before tire technology was as advanced as it is today. Right? It’s time to rethink that, now that winter tires are better than they’ve ever been. All-season tires are great, but, well, to quote the tire experts at mega tire supplier Tire Rack, they can be jack of all trades, master of none.

If you want to be at your safest and most confident all year round, your best bet is to alternate all-season tires in the warm months with winter-rated tires from late fall to spring. Even if you aren’t in the Snow Belt, but go skiing on weekends or occasionally encounter snowy conditions, winter tires are a good investment.
Here are five reasons why.

1. Winter tires remain more pliable in the snow. All-season tires are stiffer than winter tires. So, as the weather drops below 40 degrees and the roads get more frozen, an all-season tire becomes like hard plastic on the road. Winter tires are made of a softer compound, so they remain pliable at lower temperatures.

2. Winter tires are built right to push the snow out. On winter roads, your tires have to cope with a film of water over the road when it’s slushy, wet, or icy. Today’s modern studless ice and snow tires have aggressive tread patterns, with more sipes, or grooves, to take the fluid in and wick it back out. Winter tires have many sipes (deep cuts in the tread) to grab the snow and keep you in control. It’s like black magic.

3. No technology can improve your grip the way the right tires can. A front-wheel-drive or all-wheel-drive vehicle is more stable in the snow and ice. Anti-lock brakes and traction control will improve the car’s handling. But the tires are where grip comes from. Snow tires have more “bite” to grip the way you need them to on snow and ice.

4. On winter tires, you can stop, accelerate, and turn better. Stopping, going, and turn distance are all improved in slushy, wet, and icy conditions with winter tires. In a test on ice comparing all-season versus winter cars, Tire Rack found that the winter-tire-clad car stopped 18.5 feet quicker, could corner 3 mph faster without hitting cones on the course, and could accelerate from a stop 25 percent faster than the car with all-season tires. That’s reason enough to consider winter tires this time of year.

5. It’s not even more expensive in the long run. Tire Rack says alternating summer and winter tires “means having the best tires to overcome driving challenges all year round, and helps extend the combined years of service drivers get from both sets.” Rather than use a set of all-season tires all year round and replace them sooner, you can alternate winter with all-season tires and get longer life out of both sets. That switchover in spring and fall is totally worth it when you realize you’re driving with more confidence all year round.

title: Gifts: JBL Trip

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: If Santa is not flush enough to deliver a brand-new car to you this year, you can hope for the JBL Trip. This Bluetooth speaker will transform your non-Bluetooth-enabled vehicle into a rolling conference room. Hands-free technology for $99, even if you're driving a clunker.

Why is the speaker any different than every other Bluetooth speaker in the universe? First and foremost, the Trip is designed specifically for use in cars. A magnetic mounting system clips to the visor to easily attach the speaker. The speaker has buttons that face the driver to allow you to accept and end calls, adjust volume, and best of all access Siri and Google speech. I am swooning over the idea of bossing around Siri while driving down the highway in a 1957 Chevrolet Bel Air convertible. And this little pill-shaped speaker has noise-canceling technology to combat the wind when I choose to put the top down.

The speaker can be used to broadcast apps on your phone. I personally used Google Maps and Pandora simultaneously. If your car already has a great sound system, you can use the Trip for navigation while still rockin’ out to your factory-installed radio. It is charged via a micro-USB cord and delivers twenty hours of talk time and 800 hours of standby. It is annoying to have to charge a speaker, but if you talk for twenty hours straight, you will need to rest your voice for a while anyway.

The fun doesn’t have to stop when the navigation announces that you have reached your destination. Simply remove the speaker and walk away. I used mine to listen to books via the Audible app as I moved around my house cleaning.

My only disappointment, and it's a small one, is that there's no carrying bag to go along with the Trip. This product was just introduced this fall at a European technology fair, so an aftermarket carrying bag won't be long in making itself available.
So, if the only reason you want a new car is for Bluetooth technology, I just saved you tens of thousands of dollars. You’re welcome.
You can order the Trip online from Crutchfield ($99.95) or straight from JBL.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: How do you maintain an appropriate following distance from the car in front of you? I prefer two seconds; here’s what I do. I pick a fixed point on the side of the road, like a signpost, and when the car in front of me passes it, I begin counting “one one-thousand, two one-thousand.” If I get to the signpost before I’m done, I’m too close. I repeat that exercise until I have a very good visual in my mind of how far two seconds is. One second is not far enough, if you ask me. And, sadly, three seconds gives too much space for the impatient idiot on your right to jam in.

My signpost method is the idea behind “smart,” or adaptive, cruise control. This is an active safety feature that is increasingly available on a wide range of new vehicles. Using radar or cameras that point forward, the system monitors and corrects the distance between your car and the one ahead of you. Many have low-speed functionality for traffic jams and bumper-to-bumper traffic, while others don’t kick in until you’re going around 25 mph.
Manufacturers are calling this technology by various names, but all of them are a great supplement to your own personal signpost-counting ritual, and they can make driving easier to do well.
Why would you spend the extra money to get a safety package that includes adaptive cruise control? Let us count the ways.
Manufacturers are calling this technology by various names, but all of them supplement your own personal signpost-counting ritual and can make driving easier to do well.

1. If you like cruise control, you’ll love adaptive cruise control. It helps you maintain a set speed. No car in front of you? You’re cruising along at your chosen speed, just like with regular cruise control. But it goes one better and also continuously scans the traffic ahead of you, using front-mounted cameras or radar. Then it adjusts your speed to what traffic is doing in front of you.

2. No more canceling and restarting, canceling and restarting your cruise control as other traffic comes and goes. Don’t you hate that? Adaptive cruise control will slow you down when traffic in front requires it, and speed you up again when there’s room to do so. You spend less time adjusting. What’s that worth in your daily commute?

3. You’re still driving the car. Set it, and forget it, or you can shut it off, so there’s nothing “autonomous” about it. You’re still totally in control. You can also choose to use “regular” cruise control and set a speed for your car but not a following distance. That’s still available on cars with the adaptive cruise control capability.

4. Feel confident about your following distance all the time. You have control over the time interval between you and the next car. Volvo has a choice of five distance intervals; BMW, Hyundai, and Ford have four. Generally this is displayed on your car’s information screen (or, as on some Hyundai models, on the head-up display), and you can choose how many "bars" of distance separate you. As an example, using Hyundai’s Smart Cruise Control, if your set cruise control speed is 56 mph, Distance 4 is 170 feet and Distance 1 is 82 feet from the car in front of you.

5. A growing number of systems will work at very low speed, so your nerves are spared in traffic jams. Well, you’re not off the hook entirely; you still have to pay attention, but tech packages such as Acura’s Low-Speed Follow, BMW’s Stop & Go, Chrysler’s Adaptive Cruise Control-Plus with Full Stop, and Audi’s Traffic Jam Assist (coming on the 2017 Q7) will maintain a safe following distance down below 25 mph, such as in bumper-to-bumper situations.

6. Look carefully to identify adaptive cruise control, since it goes by many names. Some of its other monikers are: Distronic Plus (Mercedes-Benz), Active Cruise Control (BMW), Smart Cruise Control (Hyundai), and Intelligent Cruise Control (Nissan and Infiniti).

7. And the big question, how much does it cost? Look for adaptive cruise control as a standard feature on higher-end cars, including the Hyundai Equus and the Volkswagen Touareg Executive. It’s generally part of a safety or technology package on other models. Examples: It’s part of the $1,750 Ultimate package on the 2016 Hyundai Sonata Limited, part of the $1,800 Convenience package on the 2016 Volvo XC90, and part of the $2,885 Driver Assist package on the 2016 Cadillac ATS. With the adaptive cruise control, you’ll generally get such other useful features as automatic braking and lane departure warning.

The next frontier is definitely autonomous. We can all see it coming. Cadillac has announced it’s bringing out Super Cruise on the 2017 CT6, which will be a hands-off, feet-off experience. Whether or not you’re ready to go there, adaptive cruise control is a safety feature worth trying, if only to give your nerves a bit of a rest on the highway.
