pageElements.text:
2016 Chevrolet Malibu 1LT

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Trim levels: L, LS, 1LT, 2LT, Premier
Base price: $22,500 (base model), $25,895 (1LT)
Price as tested: $29,685
Engine: Turbocharged 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 160 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/37 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Stop/start technology
Options I can’t live without: Teen Driver
Notable standard features on this model: Power driver’s seat, seven-inch touchscreen, radio, rearview camera, Apple Car Play/Android Auto, 4G LTE connectivity with wireless hot spot, cruise control, push-button start, LED daytime running lights
Notable options on this model: Sun and Wheels package (power sunroof, 18-inch alloy wheels, home remote), $1,500; Convenience/Technology package (remote start, auto-dimming mirror, 120-volt power outlet, MyLink radio, wireless charging with two rear seat USB ports, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob), $895; Leather package (heated front seats, power passenger seat, Bose premium audio), $1,395; Driver Confidence package (front automatic braking and front pedestrian braking, front and rear park assist, side blind zone alert, lane change alert, lane keep assist, following distance indicator, forward collision alert, rear cross-traffic alert), $1,195
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Hyundai Sonata, Kia Optima, Mazda 6, Nissan Altima, Toyota Camry, Volkswagen Passat

Like many models with a lengthy history—the name first appeared in 1964, as a Chevelle variant—the Malibu has gone through a dizzying number of identities in its eight generations. Now, with the all-new sixth-generation 2016 Chevrolet Malibu, it is adopting a very attractive new personality.

Over the years the Malibu has run from Type A—a 396-cubic-inch big-block V-8 model that rumbled onto the scene in the mid-1960s, the golden age of American muscle—to the forgettable models of the recent past, popular primarily with rental fleets.

That last is changing as we speak, thanks to this all-new Malibu, which is beginning to appear in the U.S. showrooms as we speak. Another bit of proof that it's a notable new model: It has just been named one of three finalists for the North American Car of the Year award, the winner of which will be named in January during the Detroit auto show. (The other two are the Mazda MX-5 Miata and the Honda Civic.)
Bigger, roomier, handsome, quiet, and eminently competent, the personality and presence of the 2016 Malibu gives Chevrolet a stronger entry in the mid-size-sedan segment.

Bigger, roomier, handsome, quiet, and eminently competent, the personality and presence of the 2016 Malibu is certain to give Chevrolet a stronger entry in the mid-size-sedan category. It addresses the key areas where the 2015 Malibu was particularly weak—eye appeal, rear-seat comfort—and adds interior sophistication, enhanced infotainment, more safety features, and a serious hybrid model.

Most contemporary make-overs include dimensional increases that barely merit mention. But two Malibu chassis statistics stand out. The wheelbase has been stretched four inches, an unusually big increase for a mid-size sedan. Overall, the Malibu is 2.3 inches longer, and there’s less of it extending beyond the front axle, a benefit to the car’s proportions.

Just as important, the longer wheelbase adds up to a 1.3-inch increase in rear-seat legroom. Don’t get too excited—you won’t confuse this with a limo. But with the exception of NBA players, adult knees will no longer rub against the front-seat backs. Although the rear center seating position is tenable for only short trips—unless it’s someone you don’t like—the outboard seats are good for long-haul comfort: Chicago to Minneapolis, say, or Omaha to somewhere west of Laramie.

An impressive footnote to the dimensional increases: in addition to adding inches, the design engineers managed to pare about 300 pounds from the Malibu’s curb weights, depending on trim level and feature content. Also impressive: the weight loss wasn’t achieved at the expense of structure. Chevy claims a 17 percent improvement in structural rigidity, the starting point for all vehicle dynamics. And the Malibu’s dynamic scorecard is very good.

It’s not inaccurate to characterize the outgoing Malibu as a bit dowdy, and the packaging for the new car makes that conclusion inescapable. With its more athletic proportions, sporty nose, and sculpted side panels, the new Malibu goes from wallflower to one of the most attractive entries in the mid-size sedan class, and yet it is still instantly recognizable as a Chevy.

Like most new interiors, the Malibu’s is distinguished by higher-quality materials, lots of soft-touch surfaces, and enhanced infotainment. A touchscreen dominates the center of the dashboard, seven inches in these early models (an eight-inch option is due in February), with big icons that make for a higher level of user-friendliness than some systems. And there are also conventional switches and knobs.

Chief engineer Jesse Ortega sums it up: “When a button will do the job, we give you a button,” a design philosophy that warms my heart, since my personal automotive history dates to the time when AM radio was the one and only infotainment option.

In addition to a wholesale upgrade of the Malibu’s features and furnishings, Chevrolet has also added a new trim level—Premier—with interior design and details that would not be out of place in an Audi.

There are two engine choices, both turbocharged four-cylinders. The standard powerplant is a new 1.5-liter, one of GM’s new high-efficiency small engines, generating 160 horsepower and paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 27 mpg in the city, 37 mpg on the highway. For more urgency, the optional engine is a 2.0-liter version that makes 250 horsepower, sending thrust to the front wheels via a new eight-speed automatic transmission—22 mpg city/32 mpg highway, according to the EPA.

The 2.0-liter engine is capable of propelling the Malibu to 60 mph in a wink or two over six seconds, which is tolerably brisk, although to be candid V-6 versions of the Honda Accord and Toyota Camry are a little quicker. On the other hand, the new eight-speed is the personification of smooth, and how fast do you need to go?

If fuel economy is the top priority, stand by for the new hybrid, a gasoline-electric combo rated for total system output of 182 horsepower and capable of 48 mpg in the city, 45 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. Those are prodigious numbers for a mid-size sedan, and infinitely better than the "mild hybrid" version of the previous Malibu.
We’ll take a closer look at the hybrid when it becomes available early next year. Note to shoppers: Chevrolet is also continuing to offer the outgoing model, renaming it as the 2016 Malibu Limited.

In the meantime, based on a half-day of driving in northern California, we can say that the two non-hybrid versions are very pleasant traveling companions. Ride quality is smooth, quick directional changes are achieved without drama, tire adhesion seems better than average, brake performance seems even better than that, and the steering provides a stronger sense of what the front wheels are doing than most in this new age of electric power systems.

Power is respectable with the 2.0-liter engine, a notch or two better than adequate with the 1.5-liter, throttle response is prompt with both (some turbo engines still exhibit a little hesitation when the driver floors the throttle at low speeds), and the operation of both transmissions is commendably transparent.

Ride quality edges toward the softer side, although it’s far from pillowy, and pretty close to perfect by contemporary family sedan standards. If there’s any marginal mark on the dynamic scorecard it’s for interior noise levels. Though generally quiet, with zero wind sound, a bit of road noise can creep into the cabin on certain types of pavement. However, this is not an uncommon phenomenon.

The Malibu keeps pace in terms of contemporary safety features, including pedestrian detection and automatic braking, and adds something new to the mix. It’s called Teen Driver, and basically it allows parents to track how the car is being driven—speed, distance—as well as whether various passive safety systems, such as seatbelts, are engaged, and whether active systems such as antilock braking have been triggered. Teen Driver is programmed into the young driver’s key fob, and is activated by a PIN in the Settings section of the Malibu’s MyLink system, Chevrolet’s infotainment array.

Spanning five trim levels (L, LS, LT, Hybrid, and Premier), Malibu MSRPs range from $22,500 to $31,795, and there are a number of option packages. And as you’d expect, the pricing stacks up competitively with segment bestsellers like Accord and Camry.
Long an also-ran, Chevy’s thorough and thoughtful overhaul of the Malibu puts this enduring brand name back into front-running contention among a flock of very good mid-size sedans.

Remember the old Chevy theme song, made famous by Dinah Shore in the 1950s? See the USA, in your Chevrolet. Along with the Chevy Impala, the new Malibu is a car that will make you want to do just that.

pageElements.text: Welcome to Five Cool Things from JeanKnowsCars.com!
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/3mg9CQULbew?autoplay=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Welcome to the 2016 Honda Civic. Thirty-five million people worldwide have bought Civics. You may be surprised to find out that Honda is offering Honda Sensing on the new Civic, which will basically give the Civic all the cameras and radar that drivers will wonder how they ever lived without.
This is the tenth-generation Civic. It is back, and it's better than ever.

1. There's an all-new 1.5-liter four-cylinder engine for EX-T level Civics and above. This is the first turbocharged engine available on a U.S. Honda, and it makes 174 horsepower, which is more than any Civic that wasn't a performance Si model. Is there anything cooler than more horsepower?
2. This is clearly the time to call out the heated rear seats. Are you feeling the Civic yet? It's all grown up.

3. Remote engine start has come to Civic, and I'm sending this one back to the family and friends back home up North. Stay in your house, drinking your coffee in your jammies, and watch the snow come down. Then point your key fob out the window, watch for the headlights to flash, you'll see the engine come on, take another sip of coffee while your car warms up. This is worth its weight in gold, people.

4. Rain-sensing wipers. They've never been on a Civic before. No more turn the wipers on, wait three swipes, turn them off. They know what to do and when to do it. Available to those of you willing to spring for the Touring model.
5. I saved this for last. The Civic's exterior styling is so dramatic, I just want to let the camera give it the close-up it deserves.
Pick your own cool things about the new Civic at automobiles.honda.com/10th-gen-civic.

title: 5 Cool Things from the Consumer Electronics Show
subTitle: Our new favorites from BMW, Cadillac, Ford, Volkswagen, Volvo, and their tech partners.
promoTitle: 5 Cool Things from the Consumer Electronics Show
promoTeaserSmall: Our new favorites from BMW, Cadillac, Ford, Volkswagen, Volvo, and their tech partners.
promoTeaser: Our new favorites from BMW, Cadillac, Ford, Volkswagen, Volvo, and their tech partners.
keywords: 5 Cool Things from the Consumer Electronics Show
metaTitle: 5 Cool Things from the Consumer Electronics Show - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Our new favorites from BMW, Cadillac, Ford, Volkswagen, Volvo, and their tech partners.

pageElements.text: Good news if you like lots of technology with your new car. Maybe your very next vehicle purchase won't have the kind of smartphone-integrating, autonomous-enabled, gesture-recognizing technology these manufacturers are showing off—but maybe it will, and there's little doubt we'll all find ourselves in cars featuring this tech eventually. Here are our five favorite new developments from the humongous Consumer Electronics Show, happening this week in Las Vegas.

1. Better Connectivity from Ford.
Ford, following in the footsteps of General Motors, is going to put 4G LTE wireless on board, but its better idea is making it free for five years. Ford’s already much improved Sync system becomes Sync Connect on the 2017 Escape, coming out this spring, and will be rolled out to the full lineup after that. You’ll be able to use Sync Connect to remotely lock, unlock, and start your vehicle from anywhere, locate your parked car on a map, and look up fuel, battery, and tire pressure information, all from your smartphone. Ford targets getting Sync Connect in more than 10 million Fords worldwide by the end of the decade.
Imagine a highway full of autonomous cars with their occupants sitting back watching their favorite TV shows in high definition," Volvo's Anders Tylman says.

2. Volvo Says, Sit Back and Watch a Movie.
A show like CES is an occasion to reflect about the future. Is it possible, as the latest study from McKinsey projects, that the future will see autonomous vehicles in the majority, leading to daytime car sharing on a massive scale and cutting down the urban traffic scene by 80 percent? No more parking lots filled with stationary cars? Volvo has an intriguing project with Ericsson known as Intelligent Media Streaming. It will deliver interruption-free, high-definition video while your car drives you. "Imagine a highway full of autonomous cars with their occupants sitting back watching their favorite TV shows in high definition," Volvo's Anders Tylman says. We'll leave it to you to decide if that's a dream or a nightmare. And Volvo is planning public-road trials of autonomous vehicles in the next few years, so it's probably coming sooner than you think.

3. Delphi Connects Your Vehicle to Everything, Starting with a Cadillac.
Meanwhile, powerhouse automotive supplier Delphi is focusing on communication between your car and its environment, with its V2E technology (which stands for Vehicle to Everything). Delphi's automated vehicle at CES is showing off its combination of radar, smartphone chips, and short-range communication technology to tell your car when pedestrians are chatting on smartphones and about to walk into your path, anticipate when a light is about to turn yellow or red, and alert you when someone's about to change lanes. It will even tell your friends and family where your vehicle is so they can ask you for a ride—assuming that's something you want, of course.

If you want to see this on a real car, Delphi's vehicle-to-vehicle technology is coming out on the 2017 Cadillac CTS as Super Cruise, which will be capable of limited autonomous operation. (Here's more about this and other forms of "smart" cruise control.)

4. BMW Re-Envisions the Rearview Mirror and Gives Your Hands New Power.
This whole camera thing is reaching its logical conclusion now, as the BMW i8 is appearing at CES without any mirrors, only cameras. No more blind spots! Plus, the system will warn you if the cameras spot an approaching danger. Images from three cameras are combined on a display where you'd expect a rearview mirror to be. Meanwhile, the smaller i3 gets a slightly more conventional setup that adds images from a roof-mounted camera to the rearview mirror.

Still more intriguing is Air Touch, which will let you wave your hands meaningfully to make things happen—meaning you can use the features of your touchscreen without actually reaching over and touching anything. This is an expansion on the Gesture Control already available on the BMW 7 Series.


At CES, BMW showed AirTouch on a good-looking concept, the i Vision Future Interaction, with a high-resolution twenty-one-inch panoramic display that recognizes movement. There's lots more interesting technology on board, including three selectable drive modes to take you from Pure Drive (what we'd call normal), through Assist (active safety features) to Auto Mode.

5. Volkswagen and Others Point to an Affordable EV Future.
Volkswagen announced the all-electric, 373-mile-range Budd-E at CES on Tuesday. With a large 101-kWh battery and some up-to-the-minute tech features including gesture control and Smart Home connectivity, it's not your hippie great-aunt's VW Microbus, yet in styling and feel, it kind of is.

At 181 inches in length, it's bigger than the Golf and more the size of a Chevrolet Cruze or a Toyota Corolla. You've got to love the way the information display is organized, into Drive, Control, and Consume sections. What else is there, after all? VW has promised "a new era" of affordable long-distance range, which starts with the Budd-E, and it sure looks appealing.

Meanwhile, the subcompact 2017 Chevrolet Bolt EV, first seen at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit last year, is making its production debut at CES, and Chinese-backed startup Faraday is reportedly introducing a 1,000-horsepower electric car concept during the show. So, whether you're going for electric technology for reasons of nostalgia, economics, or Tesla envy, CES has something worth looking at this year.

See our related story: 5 Cool Things from the Consumer Electronics Show (CES)

title: 7 Things to Look for at Detroit
subTitle: Concepts and production cars we're looking forward to from Acura, Volvo, Chrysler, and more.
promoTitle: 7 Things to Look for at Detroit
promoTeaserSmall: Concepts and production cars we're looking forward to from Acura, Volvo, Chrysler, and more.
promoTeaser: Concepts and production cars we're looking forward to from Acura, Volvo, Chrysler, and more.
keywords: 7 Things to Look for at Detroit
metaTitle: 7 Things to Look for at Detroit Auto Show - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Concepts and production cars we're looking forward to from Acura, Volvo, Chrysler, and more.

pageElements.text:
1. Acura Precision Concept
The upscale Honda division has been showing off this teaser photo since December, part of a 2016 plan that includes the launch of an all-new NSX in the spring. This one, though, is more Integra than supercar. It's intended to signal what the next generation of performance/luxury sedans will look like.

2. 2017 Chrysler Town & Country
It's not the end of the minivan, no matter what the plethora of crossovers on your local streets is telling you. In fact, an all-new version of the minivan that started it all is coming from Chrysler. The 2017 Town & Country will be the sixth generation of the classic family carrier. Details will be out before breakfast on Monday morning, but meanwhile, it's expected to have one of those foot-operated door openers for the side and rear doors, and it's also expected to go on sale in the second quarter of the year.

3. 2017 Honda Ridgeline
For mid-size-pickup buyers, the Ridgeline was unconventional-looking. According to the partial view here, it won't be anymore when the 2017 model makes its debut in Detroit next week. In place of the somewhat odd-looking unit body, the new Ridgeline appears to be more traditional-looking. It will be interesting to see how it performs against the popular competitors from General Motors, the Chevrolet Colorado and GMC Canyon.

4. Kia Telluride Concept
A little more soul from the maker of the Soul seems to be coming with this sport-utility vehicle concept. The teaser image of the concept, which was developed in Kia's California design facility, looks squarish and muscular. Kia released an image of an all-digital dashboard on Friday along with the concept's name. It's going to have some of the latest active safety features. That lines up with Kia's just-announced Drive Wise sub-brand initiative, which aims at getting semi-autonomous cars into the showroom within a few years.
It also gets 3D-printed components on the dashboard, steering wheel, and door panels and "health and wellness technology" in the cabin. Take your blood pressure while you drive?

5. 2017 Lincoln Continental
It has been fifteen years since the last Lincoln Continental rolled American roads, but the Continental Concept (pictured) shown at the New York Auto Show last spring made it clear that it's coming back. At Detroit next week, the big Continental sedan will make its debut, reportedly with a twin-turbo V-6 engine and enough plush luxury to appeal to both American buyers and the important China market.

6. Lexus LC500
The follow-up to the LF-FC Concept (pictured here) shown at the Tokyo Auto Show this fall, this LC is a high-end, V-8-powered luxury coupe to compete against the Mercedes-Benz SL and its ilk. Expect it to be gorgeous, with an ultramodern drivetrain and a high price.

7. 2017 Volvo S90
Volvo is going full speed ahead into autonomous and semi-autonomous driving features, and this all-new big sedan is no exception. Although Volvo design chief Thomas Ingenlath acknowledges that S90 buyers are in a "rather conservative segment," this is an innovative car. It will have plug-in hybrid power and Pilot Assist, which manages your steering to keep the car in its lane at speeds up to 80 mph. More than that, it is marking the world debut of large animal detection, which can spot animals such as horses and moose, or more likely in North America, deer, that might get out in front of your vehicle.

title: Buick Avista Concept
subTitle: As the jewel of a coupe made its debut, we met the guys behind that Dark Sapphire Jewel paint job.
promoTeaserSmall: As the jewel of a coupe made its debut, we met the guys behind that Dark Sapphire Jewel paint job.
promoTeaser: As the jewel of a coupe made its debut, we met the guys behind that Dark Sapphire Jewel paint job.
metaDescription: As the jewel of a coupe made its debut, we met the guys behind that Dark Sapphire Jewel paint job.

pageElements.text:
Type: 2+2-passenger, rear-wheel-drive sport coupe concept
Engine: Twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6, 400 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
What's most interesting: Flowing center console, elegant lines

General Motors design chief Ed Welburn had good reason to be smiling as he introduced the Buick Avista concept, which was a bit of a surprise introduction at the GM division's event in Detroit's Eastern Market on Sunday night. For the second year in a row, Buick was showing off an extremely attractive concept—last year, it was the Avenir, which led to the all-new LaCrosse that goes on sale this summer. This year, it's the gorgeous Avista two-plus-two sport coupe, powered by a twin-turbo engine, that captured all the attention.

The Dark Jewel Sapphire paint color set off the sinuous lines of the Avista to great effect. Jean took one look and called that color "candy blue." We were lucky enough to shake the hands of the actual guys who made it happen: Matt Ayers and Gene Guenther, a pair of experimental laboratory paint technicians from the GM Tech Center's color design department. They and David Bolognino, director of GM Design Fabrication, told us about the creative process involved in creating a show-ready paint job. "It's a one-off special color," Ayers told us, mixed to the specifications of Sharon Gauci, Buick's director of design for global color and trim. Ayers and Guenther spent hundreds of hours preparing and thirteen hours painting the Avista concept, and that hard work definitely paid off.
The Avista concept shows off some of the luxury features a Buick might be expected to carry, such as ionic air purifiers, aromatherapy, and noise cancellation technology.

The Avista concept shows off some of the luxury features a Buick might be expected to carry, such as ionic air purifiers, aromatherapy, and noise cancellation technology. The swoopy center console has "a future vision" of the already good IntelliLink infotainment system with a wide screen and touch controls.The door and seat trim have 3D-printed elements. The powertrain also features cylinder deactivation and stop/start technology to save fuel.  But the twin-turbocharged V-6 engine and magnetic ride control show the sporting aspirations for this luxury concept.

Buick also showed the 2017 Envision premium crossover, which is intended to sit between the compact Encore and the mid-size Enclave. Buick sold 147,000 Envision vehicles in China last year, and since the Encore and Enclave make up 60 percent of U.S. Buick sales, it makes sense for the Envision to come here, too.

Two more Buicks on display in Detroit will reach dealers this year. First, the Cascada convertible, which made its debut at Detroit a year ago, will reach dealers within the next few weeks. Buick global sales chief Duncan Aldred noted that dealers have already requested ten times the initial production run of the Cascada before a single one has been delivered. The 2017 LaCrosse goes on sale this summer. Altogether, Buick will have seven new or revised models on sale by 2018.

images.caption: GM design chief Ed Welburn with the Avista concept.
The team behind that great paint job.

title: 2016 GMC Terrain Denali
subTitle: GMC’s smallest ute squeaks out another year. Its seventh.
promoTeaserSmall: GMC’s smallest ute squeaks out another year. Its seventh.
promoTeaser: GMC’s smallest ute squeaks out another year. Its seventh.
metaDescription: GMC’s smallest ute squeaks out another year. Its seventh.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive compact sport-utility vehicle
Trim levels: SL, SLE-1, SLE-2, SLT, Denali
Base price: $24,900 (SL, front-wheel drive) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $36,850
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6, 301 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/23 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: 2016 Top Safety Pick
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Ford Escape Titanium AWD ($31,890)
2016 Hyundai Santa Fe Sport AWD ($27,595)
2016 Jeep Cherokee Limited 4x4 ($31,890)
2016 Mazda CX-5 Grand Touring AWD ($30,350)

Fun-O-Meter: 5

GMC, the General Motors division that brands itself as Professional Grade, can be excused for being a little hard around the edges. If you’re shopping for a GMC sport-utility vehicle, you probably know that already and are OK with it. From the Terrain—the smallest of the three SUVs in the GMC lineup—to the popular full-size Sierra pickup, GMC makes tall, boxy, chrome-laden, ruthlessly efficient work vehicles.

But GMC also appeals to upscale crossover buyers, including in the heavily competitive compact segment. The Terrain was first introduced in the 2010 model year and has been modestly upgraded for 2016. It’s the second most popular GMC vehicle after the Sierra pickup, and it also has the highest number of female buyers of any GMC product, at 44 percent. The Denali name is given to the top-end version of GMCs, and you’ll find a Denali version of the mid-size Acadia and full-size Yukon SUV as well as the Sierra pickup.

Therefore, the 2016 GMC Terrain Denali that I tested is the most luxurious Terrain model. If you’re expecting buttery leather and soft-touch surfaces, though, you should look elsewhere. The Terrain looks like a member of a truck lineup and feels like one.

The front end was redone for the 2016, with the freshened model making its debut at the 2015 New York Auto Show. A revised grille, LED daytime running lights, and C-shaped lower chrome trim were all added. Many of the changes for 2016 favor people who want to buy a mid-range model rather than spring for the Denali. The SLE and SLT models add several cosmetic upgrades, including an optional Saddle Up leather interior on the SLT, premium cloth interior now standard on the SLE, and chrome-accented grilles for SLE and SLT.

The standard engine on the Terrain is a 2.4-liter four-cylinder, but I wouldn’t go there, even if it does claim better fuel economy, with the all-wheel-drive model getting 20 mpg in the city and 29 mpg on the highway. The Terrain Denali has the 3.6-liter V-6 with an EPA mpg rating of 16 city/23 highway, while making 301 horsepower. With it, you can tow up to 3,500 pounds. With either engine, you get a six-speed automatic transmission. Neither the V-6 engine nor transmission, however, could be called amusing.

I expected more from the V-6, but it didn’t much like the 4,200-plus pounds it was moving around, and the transmission huffed and puffed through the gears in a bit of a snit. It makes me anxious when I drive a vehicle with a cheesed-off powertrain that doesn’t much want to be there. We all feel better when we lose a little weight.
The Terrain is the second most popular GMC vehicle after the Sierra pickup, and it also has the highest number of female buyers of any GMC product, at 44 percent.

The interior is also a little disappointing, featuring a lot of hard plastic of different colors. The only softness comes from a leather pad on the dashboard, surrounded by hard plastic around the center console. There were some rough spots, notably a gaping space in the steering column sheathing around the adjustable steering wheel release knob. My searching fingers plunged right into the gap, and I thought a major piece of plastic trim was missing. But it wasn’t so. They might want to reconsider saving money in that particular area.

General Motors has a lot to offer in the connectivity/infotainment area, and the Terrain Denali is no exception. GM’s excellent IntelliLink infotainment screen comes with OnStar and 4G LTE that makes the Terrain into a wireless hot spot. I personally had trouble getting IntelliLink to understand my voice commands. The touchscreen feels far away, and the controls are hard to read, even in the daylight. A hood over the center screen shades it from glare, which is one saving grace.

The 2016 Terrain has keyless entry, but no push-button start. A programmable liftgate is also standard on the Denali, a feature that is very much appreciated by shorter people (I’m not one of those) because you can program how far up it opens to fit your garage or your arm reach. That’s available on the SLT model as an option.

Active safety features are something that crossover buyers will increasingly expect to have on board. The 2016 Terrain Denali, as the top Denali trim level, has a full set:  forward collision alert, lane departure warning, side blind zone alert, and rear cross-traffic alert are all standard. There’s also a standard rearview camera. The only one I truly noticed was the blind spot monitoring, which was not obtrusive. Side blind zone alert and rear cross-traffic alert are now options on SLE and SLT models.

GMC sold over 100,000 Terrain SUVs in 2015, which represented almost 20 percent of the division’s total sales. That’s still only about a third of the annual sales of the Ford Escape or the Honda CR-V, though.

This is an SUV that’s holding on another year until the big fabulous redesign. The 2016 Terrain is certainly acceptable, but it’s out of sync with the competitive set new-model cadence. I can come up with five small utes off the top of my head that are more modern, more fun to drive, and less expensive. So until the 2017 Terrain arrives (we’re hoping the rumors are true and it will be soon), make sure you do your homework and take your favorites for a test spin before deciding.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, four-door front-wheel-drive compact electric sedan
Release date: Late 2016
Estimated price range: $30,000 after federal tax credits
Competes against: Ford C-Max Energi, Nissan Leaf
What's most interesting: 200 miles of range on a charge
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/qJBR4un7s5U?list=PLDtKaZSQcnJCZY-Ge8vAaMITVtB0ZsrMJ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

I had never met Stuart Norris, managing director of General Motors Korea Design, before doing this walkaround at the Detroit auto show. (He only looked slightly nervous.) In this video walkaround, he made his point that the Bolt is not just an EV, but also a versatile everyday car, with its flat load floor—thanks to a well-designed battery pack—and its 200 miles of range on a charge. That's without mentioning the spacious center console that looks big enough to hold a purse, and the big 10.2-inch touchscreen that will support Android Auto and Apple CarPlay. The Bolt goes into production later this year.

More to Read

2017 Chevrolet Bolt and Cruze Debuts: 2016 North American International Auto Show

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact sedan
Trim levels: SE, Limited; Eco (coming spring 2016)
Base price: $17,150 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $27,710
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 147 horsepower; 1.4-liter four-cylinder, 128 horsepower (Eco)
Transmission: Six-speed automatic (SE, Limited) or six-speed manual (SE); seven-speed dual-clutch automatic (Eco)
Fuel economy: 29 mpg city/38 mpg highway (2.0-liter engine)
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Notable standard features: Drive Mode Select with Eco, Normal, and Sport modes
Options I can’t live without: Power tilting and sliding sunroof, heated rear seats, HID headlights with dynamic bending
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Ford Focus Titanium ($24,100)
2016 Honda Civic EX-L with Honda Sensing ($25,535)
2016 Mazda 3 s Grand Touring ($26,615)
2016 Toyota Corolla S Premium ($23,960)

Fun-O-Meter: 7.5

If you are shopping for a compact car these days, your expectations have probably changed since the first Hyundai Elantra arrived in 1990. Dave Zuchowski, president and chief executive officer of Hyundai Motor America, explained it like this. People no longer use their head alone when buying an inexpensive car; no longer do they shop small because that’s all they can afford. These days, he says, people want personality, a car that’s fun to drive with fashion-forward styling and versatility. And they want all the “bells and whistles.”

A simple glance at the front of the 2017 Hyundai Elantra begins our tour of the Elantra’s most recent metamorphosis. The new car—categorized as a compact despite its subcompact $17,150 base price— is now roughly the dimensions of a Ford Focus. It’s a tad longer than the last Elantra, but it’s the extra inch of width that makes the visual statement. A slick-looking vertical strip of LED daytime running lights flank an inlet on each side of the classic Hyundai grille. The inlets are an aerodynamic aid that take air hitting the front and send it smoothly out through the front wheel arches. Hyundai calls the feature a Wheel Air Curtain. They’ve also covered the underbody of the car almost completely and added a spoiler that manages the way air passes over the car.

The headlamps now have available dynamic bending; they turn with the steering wheel. It’s a much cleaner and stronger overall look that carries around to the more upscale, less frenetic side sheetmetal.

The trunk deck lid adds to improved aerodynamics and looks good, too. The trunk is hands-free, using a proximity key (it can stay in your pocket or purse) to signal your arrival and pop it open without the need for you to do anything but hover there for a moment in breathless anticipation.

Much has been made of how spacious the Elantra is for a compact car. Its passenger volume is equivalent to a Cadillac CTS, a BMW 3 Series, or an Audi A4. It feels big starting in the driver’s seat, with a horizontal dash layout that gives more visual width to the cabin. There’s legroom for five Jeans here, which makes this Jean very happy, and you could probably stack another five Jeans in the trunk. The EPA measured it all and declared the Elantra mid-size in volume.

The 2017 Elantra will be available with two engines. Our test car was a fully loaded, absolutely-nothing-left-to-add Limited model with a 147-horsepower, 2.0-liter four-cylinder. The exceptional six-speed automatic is new, and it’s just one more of many aids to the Elantra’s improved EPA rating of 29 mpg city/38 mpg highway. (The 2016 Limited with the 2.0-liter four-cylinder got 24 mpg city and 35 mpg highway.) The Eco model, due this spring, will have a turbocharged 128-horsepower 1.4-liter engine exclusively, with a seven-speed dual-clutch transmission. I didn’t have a chance to drive that car, but just looking at the level of torque produced—the measure of how forcefully it pushes you down the road—it’s impressive at 156 pound-feet, compared with 132 pound-feet on the 2.0-liter engine.

The 2.0-liter is a satisfying powerplant for the Elantra, if not all that sporty. The experience is more luxurious, bolstered by a significantly retuned suspension and a more rigid structure. Everyone is using more high-strength steel these days to take out weight and increase both torsional and bending rigidity. The 2017 Elantra jumps from last model’s 2 percent high-strength steel to 53 percent, and you can feel it. Hyundai, like other manufacturers, has also massively increased the use of structural adhesive, from a nominal 10 feet to 394 feet. It’s a huge deal. By replacing welds and rivets, the car becomes quieter and also lighter. The extensive use of the super-strength adhesive also allows thinner metal without sacrificing strength. If you’re worried that Super Glue doesn’t always work for you at home, keep in mind that structural adhesive works very well for rockets in space. Don’t be alarmed; it’s supplied by Dow, which is experienced in the aerospace industry.

The Elantra is also amazingly quiet because of  improvements in the carpeting, thicker door glass, and the extra effort Hyundai made in making smaller holes in the firewall for wiring in the dashboard to reduce the amount of sound that gets in. That’s a lot of change for a car in this class.
In Sport mode, the effect on the steering was immediate and impressive enough to grab my attention and to ensure that I only drove in Sport mode for the entire day.

It all adds up to an Elantra that is much better to drive, and Hyundai’s 200-mile test route confidently sent us from south of San Diego north and east on roads that twisted up into the Otay Mountains, down to the San Vicente Reservoir, back up and around the Gold Rush country of Julian, and back to Imperial Beach on the Mexican border.

It was an impressive display of the satisfying engine and seamless transmission. The brakes can be easily modulated, and the steering is nicely weighted. There are three drive modes: Eco, Normal, and Sport. Switching among drive modes affects the torque, the shifting, and in Sport mode only, also the steering. In Sport mode, the effect on the steering was immediate and impressive enough to grab my attention and to ensure that I only drove in Sport mode for the entire day.

About those bells and whistles? Hyundai is ahead of the curve in this respect, and so is the 2017 Elantra. It even delivers some tech firsts in the category, which is something that Hyundai has become known for lately. Zuchowski calls it “the democratization of technology.” I really appreciate the little details that you would not expect in a car at this price. For example, there are little “welcome” lights that come on in the door handles as you approach the car. Among the attractive options are memory driver’s seat and mirror control, a first in this segment. Even better, this is the only car in the segment that you can get with pedestrian detection and full automated emergency braking.

To get those and other active safety features, you need to choose the Limited and add the optional Tech package ($2,500) and Ultimate package ($1,900). These will get you great safety features, including the high-intensity-discharge headlamps with Dynamic Bending to suit the light to the road ahead, plus smart cruise control, lane keeping assist, and blind spot detection with rear cross-traffic alert. In the comfort department, these option packages add a power sunroof, heated rear seats, and Infinity premium audio with the fabulous Clari-Fi music restoration technology.
If you’re someone who has gone back to vinyl, you’ll appreciate the opportunity Clari-Fi technology gives you to do the same in the car. It is magic.

Let me tell you a little more about this Clari-Fi technology, from audio specialist Harman Kardon (under the Infinity brand on the Elantra). It analyzes digital audio files as you play the music, and then automatically rebuilds the sound to make it sound closer to the original recording. If you’re someone who has gone back to vinyl, you’ll appreciate the opportunity to do the same in the car. It is magic.

The Elantra Limited has a seven-inch touchscreen as standard; the eight-inch screen with navigation in the one I tested is included in the optional Tech package. Both are HD. To get a seven-inch screen in the SE model, you’ll choose the Popular Equipment package ($800). The 2017 Elantra Limited also has next-generation BlueLink connected technology as standard, which expands beyond the smartphone to work with your wearable devices such as the Apple Watch. BlueLink offers a very deep menu of what you can do between your car and other devices and technology. (I confess that this made me want my low-tech, cheater-emissions 2016 Golf Sportwagen TDI to do all that stuff.)  BlueLink is only available on the Limited for now.

Why no heated steering wheel? This inquiring girl from the Midwest wants to know. Because the level of interest for a rear heated seat over a steering wheel was much higher when the car was clinicked, said Dave Z.

The Elantra GT model, a five-door, is still available as a 2016 carryover, but it won’t be joining the 2017 lineup. But how about a coupe, available from some competitors, including the Ford Focus and the Honda Civic? Hyundai’s Zuchowski says there are no plans for one, but a Hyundai Elantra Sport is coming that will take the place of a coupe to meet your stylish/sporty car needs. Good answer!

The Verdict:

I love the fact that this totally loaded Elantra is under $30,000 with destination charge, and I don’t mean $29,995. Fully loaded, with destination charge, the top-level Elantra Limited we tested costs $27,710. That to me is amazing. You can’t get any more than what’s on it. For that amount of money, you can get things that aren’t even an option on other cars in the class, like the heated rear seats and sophisticated automatic emergency braking with pedestrian detection. This is major bang for the buck.

Even so, Hyundai knows that the SE, equipped with automatic transmission, will continue to be the biggest seller. A few of the best goodies are optional on the SE—for example, the proximity key with push-button start, the hands-free trunk, some of the active safety features, and heated front seats—but you can get those by adding the SE Tech and Popular Equipment packages, still bringing in the Elantra at $21,085 (including destination charge). BlueLink will soon be available on the SE, and it’s certainly worth considering.

As for me, if I was waiting to order my dream Elantra, it would be that next performance-tuned Elantra Sport. I would have a long wait, though. It is expected to make its debut in November, at the 2016 SEMA show in Las Vegas.

title: 2016 Cadillac CT6 Platinum
subTitle: A princely sedan that takes Cadillac a step closer to full resurrection.
promoTeaserSmall: A princely sedan that takes Cadillac a step closer to full resurrection.
promoTeaser: A princely sedan that takes Cadillac a step closer to full resurrection.
metaDescription: A princely sedan that takes Cadillac a step closer to full resurrection.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive full-size luxury sedan
Base price: $65,390 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $88,460
Engine: Twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6, 404 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/26 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Bose Panaray audio with 34 speakers (Platinum model)
Option I can’t live without: Active Chassis Control (Platinum edition)
Notable standard features on this model: Active Chassis package (on Platinum model): Magnetic Ride Control, active rear steering, 20-inch wheels and tires; driver vision and assistance features (on Platinum model): Full-speed adaptive cruise control, side blind zone alert, rear cross-traffic alert, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, forward collision alert, following distance indicator, low-speed auto front and rear braking
Notable options on this model: Vision and Comfort package ($2,205): High-definition rearview camera in mirror, panoramic power sunroof, ventilated front seats, heated rear outboard seats
You might also be considering (prices include destination charge):
2016 Audi A8 L ($81,500)
2016 BMW 740i ($82,295)
2016 Jaguar XJ R-Sport ($75,395)
2016 Lexus LS460 ($73,470)

The golden age of Cadillac may have been a while ago, but the Cadillac name still does command respect, particularly with its recent sedan offerings. But not as much respect as Cadillac president Johan de Nysschen wants for GM’s top division, something that can be said for the entirety of General Motors management, from CEO Mary Barra on down.
The objective is to achieve parity—in performance and in public perception—with the dominators of the luxury-sedan market, specifically the Audi A8, BMW 7 Series, and Mercedes S-Class.
That’s the top rung in this class. Has the CT6 ascended to the heights?

In a way, the new Caddy begs that question. Although it supplants the XTS as the biggest of current Cadillac sedans, it’s a little smaller than the above-named German competitors in the full-size sedan category. On the other hand, it’s bigger than the mid-size four-doors like the Audi A6 and the BMW 5 Series.

The 2016 Cadillac CT6 is a handsomely furnished sedan with impressive dynamics, distinctive Cadillac good looks, and plenty of room. It’s not quite as voluminous as one of the high-end Germans—or, for that matter, a Jaguar XJ or a Lexus LS—but unless your personal dimensions qualify you for the NBA, space is plentiful. And the only issue for those in the stratospheric height category might be headroom. But that’s true for just about any sedan you care to name.

The CT6 is new from the ground up. The Platinum model we tested sits at the top of the CT6 lineup, and it includes everything from the option cupboard. The aluminum-intensive body shell is comparatively light for a car in this general category. The curb weight ranges from 3,657 to just over 4,000 pounds. A car weighing in at over two tons is obviously no sylph, but even so the CT6 is lighter than its top-end rivals.
The 2016 Cadillac CT6 is a handsomely furnished sedan with impressive dynamics, distinctive Cadillac good looks, and plenty of room.

Lighter is always a good thing in vehicle dynamics, especially when the formula includes high chassis rigidity—which is the case here. It also includes the availability of Cadillac’s magnetic ride control auto-adjusting suspension, as effective as any system going, and a new rear-steering feature that enhances handiness at parking lot speeds and amplifies confidence when the pace picks up.

There are three engine choices: a 265-horsepower 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder; a 335-hp 3.6-liter V-6 (non-turbo); and a new 404-hp 3.0-liter V-6 that includes start/stop technology (shuts itself down at stoplights) and cylinder deactivation (shuts down half the engine in light load cruising). All three engines are paired with a new eight-speed automatic transmission, and the V-6 models include all-wheel drive; the four-cylinder is rear-wheel-drive only.

The CT6 scores higher on this scale than any previous Cadillac, right down to the basic CT6 (which is a long way from basic). Materials are rich and tasteful—various woods, leather of course, tasteful décor treatments, hardly a hard surface in the entire car, beautiful electroluminescent instruments, a 10.2-inch screen in mid-dash for infotainment, navigation, audio control.
The Bose Panaray edition has thirty-four speakers, some of them under the floor. This system, visceral as well as auditory, must be experienced to be believed.

GM’s computer geeks have improved the Cadillac User Experience (CUE) touchscreen system—it needed it—and there are three Bose audio choices, culminating in the Panaray edition: thirty-four speakers, some of them under the floor. This system, visceral as well as auditory, must be experienced to be believed. It’s standard with the CT6 Platinum and a $3,700 option in the other trims. If someone like your humble narrator, his hearing diminished by too many years hanging around motor racing tracks, is seduced by this system, true audiophiles will perceive it as a bargain.

Other nifty features: the rear seats adjust fore and aft, the seatbacks recline, and there’s an available massage function. The available rear-seat infotainment system includes a pair of 10.2-inch screens morticed into the front-seat backs, and as noted there’s stretch-out legroom back there.

A new color head-up display helps the driver keep eyes on the road, there’s a camera integrated with the inside rearview mirror, and a new triggered video option allows the owner to record up to thirty-two hours of driving. This could well produce some of the most boring video in history—imagine a visual record of cruising I-80 across Nebraska—but could be useful in, say, accident documentation.

Demerits? The touchpad control located just ahead of the center armrest is a little behind the times, with gesture control coming into vogue, and its location isn’t ideal—the driver has to be careful about dangling fingers. The seats, although comfortable, could offer a little more lateral support in hard cornering, and the CT6 isn’t on the cutting edge of current developments on the road to autonomous driving—although change is near on that front.
But these are minor issues, heavily outweighed by plaudits.

For example, the sheetmetal surrounding the posh interior is yet another handsome expression of the bold Art and Science design language Cadillac established in 1999. It’s not as edgy as some interpretations of the discipline—the styling of many of these high-end sedans tends toward conservative—but the big egg-crate grille and waterfall LED running lights on the front fenders are unmistakably Cadillac.

Beyond that, the proportions are athletic and modern—long hood, suggesting plenty of power, short front overhang—not much car extending beyond the front wheels. The skin seems tightly wrapped, and the wheels extend right out to the edge of the fenders and fill up the wheel wells.

There are some who see the car’s rear end styling as a little underdone. I'm neutral about it, and so is the rear of this car. Is this a bad thing? Here’s the deal: when you pull up to the valet at Café Merveilleux, no one will be looking at the Caddy’s rear end.
The CT6 is distinctive and handsome, and like the German high rollers, it has an upscale presence. What else do you need?
When it comes to dynamics, carmakers seeking recognition in this league had better bring their A game, and the CT6 does just that.

When it comes to dynamics, carmakers seeking recognition in this league had better bring their A game, and the CT6 does just that—within power limits. Some models of the top German sedans bring heavyweight punch to the arena, 500 horsepower and more, not to mention diesels. But Cadillac’s new 3.0-liter turbo V-6 is capable of propelling the two-ton CT6 Platinum to 60 mph in about five seconds.
That’s not slow, and even the 2.0-liter moves briskly, thanks to its relatively modest mass.

However, the real virtues here are grace and agility, two traits the CT6 possesses in gratifying quantities. Body motions are nicely controlled in any of the three driving modes, steering is nicely weighted and dead-bang accurate, and even the basic CT6 is a willing companion on a twisty back road.

But the combination of the Active Chassis Control (with rear steering and magnetic ride), all-wheel drive, and the 3.0-liter twin-turbo lends real zeal to forward progress. The CT6 is one of those cars that inspires confidence at the first set of turns, nicely balanced, entertaining to drive, all-day comfortable, and quiet at all speeds on almost any surface.

The Verdict

As large cars go, the CT6 goes better than most, and holds its own with its target rivals on any grading scale—styling, content, execution, dynamics. And with a price ladder that ranges from $54,490 to $88,460, it barely overlaps the lower end of the price spectrum for the top German competitors. Johan de Nysschen says you can’t discount your way to prestige. But that’s not the CT6 story. Remember, at $88,460, the Platinum is all in—all the goodies.
It’s hard to think of cars in this general price range as bargains. But the CT6 has a case.

title: 2017 Ram Power Wagon
subTitle: An off-roader tough enough in looks and capability to rescue people who aren't as cool as you.
promoTeaserSmall: An off-roader tough enough in looks and capability to rescue people who aren't as cool as you.
promoTeaser: An off-roader tough enough in looks and capability to rescue people who aren't as cool as you.
metaDescription: An off-roader tough enough in looks and capability to rescue people who aren't as cool as you.

pageElements.text:
Type: All-wheel-drive heavy-duty pickup truck
Release date: Late 2016
Engine: 5.3-liter Hemi V-8, 410 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Competes against: Chevrolet Silverado, Ford Super Duty, GMC Sierra
What's most interesting: The blend of muscle-car good looks with heavy-duty off-road capability

Looking at the Ram Power Wagon as it was driven down a set of steep steps at the Chicago Auto Show, I was forcibly reminded of Crocodile Dundee's famous line: "That's not a knife. That's a knife." Owners of this heavy-duty off-roader will be in danger of putting on just that air of superiority when comparing the Power Wagon to a "regular" truck. It might sound arrogant, but it was actually good fun to hear Ram Brand chief Bob Hegbloom tell the assembled media that the Power Wagon's winch will be good for "rescuing people who are stuck in the mud in competitive trucks."

Speaking of the Eighties, the TV show "Simon & Simon" had one of the Power Wagons of that era, and the 2017 Power Wagon gets the same kind of muscle-car-style large graphics it displayed. A lot of the overall look of the Power Wagon comes from the popular Ram Rebel that was introduced last year. There are black powder-coat elements, notably the grille and the wheel arches. There are projector headlamps with LED marker lights. There are two tow hooks and an electronically disconnecting "smart" sway bar.

The 2017 Ram Power Wagon is powered by a 6.4-liter Hemi V-8 making 410 horsepower and 429 pound-feet of torque, with a six-speed automatic transmission and a part-time manually engaged transfer case. Want to go down steps like at the auto show introduction? Who wouldn't? A set of Hill Descent Control buttons on the column shifter let you control the speed without using your feet.

Finishing off the list of impressively macho numbers, the Power Wagon has a 14.3-inch ground clearance, 27 degrees of axle articulation—tops in the segment, Hegbloom said—and a set of 33-inch tires. A Tradesman Power Wagon, a little more subdued-looking with a lower price range, will be available for those who want to use this for work purposes.
The Power Wagon name dates back to World War II, and it's nice to see it back.
